title: The Best of Lisa Gerrard
label: 4AD
description: Former Dead Can Dance singer boasts an expansive, enigmatic voice. So why boil it down to a banal best-of?

title: Epic Fits
label: Skin Graft
description: London punk band adds elements of fun and the X-Ray Spex to the ultra-distorted, merry-go-round grind of contemporaries like HEALTH and Sightings.

title: Ragged Rubble
label: Stationary Heart
description: Baltimore trio's sparse punk rock is minimal by design and bolstered by trenchant commentary.

title: Liferz
label: Social Registry
description: Steeped in classic indie rock, this muscular trio makes no bones about blasting faux-Pixies or Sonic Youth songs well into the red.

title: Jukebox
label: Matador
description: A sort of sequel to 2000's The Covers Record, Cat Power's Jukebox reaffirms what Chan Marshall has gained during her 21st century musical growth spurt, and what she's lost. Among the artists she tackles: Hank Williams, James Brown, and Billie Holiday.

title: Level Live Wires
label: Anticon
description: The Anticon producer strikes an equitable balance with a tightly constructed soundscape that hangs together better than anything he's conceived to date.

title: Melodii Tuvi: Throat Songs and Folk Tunes from Tuva
label: Dust-to-Digital
description: Continuing to expand its focus beyond American folk idioms, the outstanding Dust-to-Digital label here collects Tuvan throat songs and instrumentals originally made in the USSR in 1969 for a state-run company.

title: The Brit Box: U.K. Indie, Shoegaze and Brit-Pop Gems of the Last Millennium
label: Rhino
description: Rhino attempts to map almost a quarter-century of UK indie music, focusing on shoegaze, Britpop, and 1980s "120 Minutes" staples.

title: Soldier On EP
label: Fargo
description: This lengthy EP compiled to coincide with his latest round of eco-friendly touring gathers a demo, a remix, and many other artifacts from Andrew Bird's past couple of years of recording.

title: Boscoe / Gently Down Your Stream / Appetizer – Soup’s On / Propinquity
label: Asterisk
description: Four reissues from the Numero Group subsidiary Asterisk resurrects forgotten albums that range from avant-funk (Boscoe) to acoustic 1970s folk (Propiniquity), with the sharp packaging and liner notes the imprint is known for.

title: Blink of a Nihilist
label: One Little Indian
description: Philadelphia-based twentysomething songwriter Brian Christinzio aims for Brian Wilson's childlike innocence and Ben Folds' shit-talking realism but winds up peddling the rote quirkiness of a big-budget Wes Anderson knockoff.

title: Juices!
label: Upper Class
description: Steroid puns intended, this Toronto band's second full-length is a less immediate approach to its analog synth-heavy electro-pop.

title: Disco Not Disco: Post Punk, Electro & Leftfield Disco Classics 1974-1986
label: Strut
description: The third volume in this storied series of leftfield disco appears a few years after-- rather than, like the first two volumes, a year or two on the other side of-- a revolution whose most important battles have already been fought and won.

title: Tank Tapes / "'Burgers" b/w "The Punjab"
label: Fuck It Tapes
description: A cassette-only album and a 12" single on Paw Tracks capture the band's most flattering tendencies without forcing listeners through the murk so imprecisely revered by devotees.

title: The Leak EP
label: Interscope
description: This EP-- ranging in quality from absolute bangers to intriguing sketches-- hit online stores like iTunes and Amazon on Christmas Day with zero fanfare, and it seems to tell us little about how Weezy's forthcoming Tha Carter 3 might eventually sound

title: First Steps Into...
label: Memphis Industries
description: After making a lush folksy record with a pre-New Young Pony Club Tahita Bulmer and a rote UK indie record with a guy who sounds like an Oasis cover-band frontman, Andy Dragazis returns to the sound of his debut: A conglomeration of downtempo, cinematic instrumentals.

title: Ecstatic Eyes Glow Glossy
label: Sick Room
description: The band's 2005 debut owed much of its cerebral post-punk to contemporaries like Q and Not U and 31 Knots; here, they attempt to expand their minds with a heavy dose of psychedelic rock.

title: Run From Safety
label: White Whale
description: The second album from Vancouver's Octoberman finds Marc Morrissette stretching out a bit, if not quite to parts unknown then certainly to parts worth a few listens.

title: Four Songs by Arthur Russell
label: Rough Trade
description: This Jens Lekman-compiled covers EP highlights the songwriting talents of the multi-faceted, late Arthur Russell.

title: Sound of Light EP
label: iTunes
description: With four 15-minute tracks, this expansive release from the Swedish minimal techno mastero-- commissioned by a Stockholm hotel and released via iTunes-- is an EP in name only.

title: Silver Storms
label: Vagrant
description: Second album from Philly-based guitar-pop band with orchestral inclinations is their first for Vagrant.

title: Hi-Teknology 3: Underground
label: Babygrande
description: Third album in the producer's series is heavier on lesser-known rap talent from his native Ohio, though it also features Ghostface, Raekwon, Talib Kweli, and Young Buck.

title: Ancestral Swamp
label: Gnomonsong
description: The elusive folk legend finds a home (at least temporarily) on Devendra Banhart and Andy Cabic's Gnomonsong label, offering here a collection of new and old tunes that all feature Hurley's backporch bluster and homey picking and fiddling.

title: Sea From Shore
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Field Music's David Brewis sets off on his own for a Thrill Jockey-released disc of down and dirty art-pop.

title: Meet the Eels: Essential Eels Vol. I / Useless Trinkets: B-Sides, Soundtracks, Rarities and Unreleased
label: Geffen
description: With an introductory best-of for newbies and a(nother) B-sides compilation for fans, Eels suggest reasons why they became a successful cult act and thank those who helped them gain that status.

title: The Captain's Table
label: Orange Twin
description: Indebted to the Velvet Underground, this Athens, Ga., band has no pretensions whatsoever, coming off a bit like a refreshing blast of an opening act when you get to the club a little too early for the headliner.

title: Deuteronomy
label: In the Red
description: The A-Frames' Lars Finberg branches out and offers his tidiest, most civilized work-- even if it still (thankfully) retains most of his signature post-punk bile.

title: Strictly Leakage
label: Rhymesayers
description: This free internet download is a great gift to fans, a nice out-of-nowhere mini-album with its own continuous-mix backbone, and a fine complement to the three EPs (Bad Summer, Bad Fall and Bad Winter) Slug has dropped over the last six months.

title: Private Times in Public Places / Nor'easter
label: Western Vinyl
description: Private Times in Public Places / Nor'easter

title: Distortion
label: Nonesuch
description: Distortion

title: Gangsta Grillz: The Album
label: Atlantic
description: The maestro behind the Gangsta Grillz mixtapes gets a major-label shot to replicate his ear for the Now-- including fantastic tracks by Outkast and Project Pat.

title: Dark on Fire
label: Source
description: Fourth full-length confirms that this London outfit has completely moved on from their roots as an acoustic duo.

title: You, Me & Everyone
label: Mush
description: London's James Rutledge abandons his folktronica roots by eschewing sprightly minimalism and trading restraint for unchecked bombast.

title: The Heavy Metal Box
label: Rhino
description: Focusing primarily on crossover and pop metal, Rhino compiles a grindcore/death metal-less box tracing of hard rock.

title: Englabörn
label: Touch
description: Englabörn

title: Anyway You Choose to Give It EP
label: IAMSOUND
description: Former Simian vocalist Simon Lord teams with ex-Wiseguys DJ Theo Keating to create a sort of sugarcoated Simain Mobile Disco, aiming to craft pop songs using dance music only as foundation.

title: Nothing Is Free
label: Mint
description: Canadian singer-songwriter Carolyn Mark is alt-country by default since she sings with a warm, subtle twang to go with her cutting sense of humor.

title: Scottish Fiction: The Best of Idlewild, 1997-2007
label: Parlophone
description: Fans of the Scottish band won't find anything new here, but this is a fantastic introduction to a quietly productive and underrated group.

title: Here Comes the Future
label: Sincerely Yours
description: Marrying the shimmery indie-dance of Saint Etienne and the Field Mice's starry-eyed earnestness, Swedish singer/songwriter Mikael Carlsson's full-length debut is a staggering monument to gentle loners everywhere.

title: ...And All the Pieces Matter: Five Years of Music From The Wire / Beyond Hamsterdam: Baltimore Tracks from The Wire
label: Nonesuch
description: ...And All the Pieces Matter: Five Years of Music From The Wire / Beyond Hamsterdam: Baltimore Tracks from The Wire

title: Wedding Day EP
label: Standard
description: Best known as a sidewoman for Jay-Z, Kanye West, Sufjan Stevens, the National, and My Brightest Diamond, this Wisconsin violinist finally steps out of the shadows on this Stevens-produced debut.

label: Southern
description: Karate's first official live album-- a recording of the band's 595th show, performed in Leuven, Belgium-- shows how far they evolved as musicians during their decade-long run.

title: Let's Talk About It EP
label: self-released
description: The Meaty, Beaty, Bloggy, and Buzzy Austin trio's first EP.

title: Sandwiches & Cats
label: JDub
description: Mixing stand-up, skits, and musical numbers, this veteran indie comedy writer-performer's first album ably demonstrates the range of his talent.

title: Death Is This Communion
label: Relapse
description: Death Is This Communion

title: Little Hours
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Jagjaguwar band has a sense of consecration in their humble piano, strings, and guitar, and a quiet air of unrushed ritual in their contemplative movement.

title: Endless Coast
label: No Fun
description: L.A. noise stars combine with Norway's Jazkamer, alias John Hegre and Lasse Marhaug, who enlist here the bass-synth thuggery of No Fun's Carlos Giffoni, on this No Fun release.

title: Super Gangster (Extraordinary Gentleman)
label: Koch
description: Just a year after his sophomore album came and went without fanfare, Styles regroups, signs with Koch, and issues the spiritual successor to 2002's underrated A Gangster and a Gentleman.

title: Frelen Mas: Be He Me B-Sides
label: Ace Fu
description: Before web sensations Annuals make their jump to the majors this fall, we're given this B-side stopgap.

title: The Cool
label: Atlantic
description: Not quite the concept album we were promised, The Cool still features isolated moments of widescreen drama-- and Fiasco's storytelling abilities, lyrical dextrousness, and willingness to submerge himself in the theatre of it all make for a rewarding sophomore album.

title: Prints
label: Temporary Residence
description: Multi-instrumentalists Kenseth Thibideau and Zac Nelson produce intricate, full-bodied tracks that draw from psychedelia, pop, and electronica, at their best evoking the hypnotic splay of the Beta Band.

title: The Boy Who Couldn't Stop Dreaming
label: Labrador
description: This warm, tender-hearted acoustic pop album is another fine example of Labrador Records' often unsung and understated approach to indie songcraft.

title: Life Goes On
label: Rap-A-Lot
description: On his fourth album, Houston rapper and Screwed Up Click affiliate moves from gruffness and nihilism to a weary expression of mourning and loss.

title: Downtown 81 OST
label: Recall
description: The soundtrack to a movie made during New York's 80s prime showcases the city as a gathering place for scenesters into art, fashion, design, dance, and especially music.

title: Rufus Does Judy Live at Carnegie Hall
label: Geffen
description: Backed by a 36-piece orchestra, Rufus Wainwright puts on the Ritz and pays a track-by-track tribute to Judy Garland's 1961 Carnegie Hall performance, which has been dubbed the "greatest night in showbusiness history."

title: Summer Above
label: Burnt Brown Sounds
description: This often lovely debut, recorded in John McEntire's Soma Studios, inches along, with very little rhythm to propel it and only the barest vocals to direct it.

title: Scared Famous
label: self-released
description: Culling 17 tracks from a 2002 double-cassette that falls somewhere between The Doldrums and House Arrest in Pink's dodgy Haunted Graffiti series, Scared Famous mixes random brilliance with sonic bullshit.

title: Sole and the Skyrider Band
label: Anticon
description: Thanks to the urgency of his proclamations and the craftiness of Skyrider's backing, Sole's fourth album is his most consistently engaging record to date.

title: Krankenhaus? EP
label: Rough Trade
description: After a stellar debut and a lackluster follow-up, British Sea Power prep us for their third album with this EP-- the first recording to capture the anarchic joy of the band's live performances.

title: Testify
label: Shout! Factory
description: This compilation collects songs from "Simpsons" seasons 11 through 18, a period roundly acknowledged as right about when the show's quality began to slip perceptibly.

title: Teardrop Sweetheart
label: Tomlab
description: Misha wowed us with "Summersend" last year, but the Brooklyn duo's latest album is the work of an indie pop band inhabiting less dramatic territory than that track suggests, trying instead for something moodier and subtler.

title: Change!
label: La Société Expéditionnaire
description: Crisper and more pared down than their previous releases, albeit with slightly less variation among the songs, Change! sounds luminously cinematic, like Pinetop Seven or the soundtrack work of Nick Cave and Warren Ellis.

title: MADE
label: Rap-A-Lot
description: The former Geto Boys and Def Jam star finally follows 2002's The Fix, an epic about love and death in America's ghettos, with a record for Rap-A-Lot, the venerable Houston indie that first launched his career nearly 20 years ago.

title: The Very Best of Ethiopiques: Hypnotic Grooves From the Legendary Series
label: Manteca
description: With more than 20 volumes and counting, the Éthiopiques series on France's Buda Musique has been an invaluable source for Ethiopian music; this 28-track, 2xCD record takes on the uneviable task of attempting to serve as a primer.

title: Y34RZ3R0R3M1X3D
label: Interscope
description: To craft this reconfiguration of last year's Year Zero, Trent Reznor assembled an impressive roster of remixers-- including the Knife, Fennesz, Kronos Quartet, the Faint, and Stephen Morris and Gillian Gilbert of New Order.

title: Polysics or Die!!! Vista
label: MySpace
description: MySpace Records adopts these Japanese spaz-rockers, here offering basically a compilation of compilations, a record that culls most of its material from the last three Polysics records and a few stray singles.

title: Strangers in Our House
label: Troubleman Unlimited
description: With its weird chord voicings, yelpy vocals, and insistent, fractured energy, Strangers in Our House is full of classic 90s indie rock signifiers-- ones that are all too often brushed aside in this decade.

title: A Brighter Beat
label: Full Time Hobby
description: Best known as one-half of the defunct Arab Strap, Malcolm Middleton returns with his third solo album.

title: The Singles, Volume Four: 1966-1967
label: Hip-O Select
description: Hip-O Select continues its vital mail-order-only series by collecting all of James Brown's 1966 and 1967 singles.

title: There Will Be Blood OST
label: Nonesuch
description: Radiohead renaissance man Jonny Greenwood makes his Hollywood film score debut with this soundtrack to director Paul Thomas Anderson's latest outing, set in a desolate California town circa 1920.

title: This Fool Can Die Now
label: Too Pure
description: Nottingham-born singer returns on Too Pure with her fifth album, a grim, sexy, and sad folk album featuring four duets with Will Oldham.

title: Leaves in the River
label: Dangerbird
description: Former Irving member Alex Brown Church follows his Get to the River Before It Runs Too Low EP with a Phil Ek-produced debut full-length of highly civilized, autumnal singer-songwriter tunes.

title: Two Hunters
label: Southern Lord
description: This rough and potent offering from rural Washington State combines black metal ferocity with operatic post-rock.

title: The Complete Motown Singles, Vol. 8: 1968
label: Hip-O Select
description: Hip-O Select continues to collect every Motown single, here presenting the label's output from 1968, a year in which the company moved to a downtown office, Berry Gordy left Detroit for Los Angeles, the Holland-Dozier-Holland writing and production team was no longer in the label's employ, and Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated.

title: In Rainbows [CD 2]
label: self-released
description: Shop talk about the industry of In Rainbows has largely pulled focus off the bonus CD tucked into Radiohead's $80 discbox-- but maybe that's for the best.

title: Ditherer
label: Lex
description: Ditherer

title: Walkin' Bank Roll
label: Koch
description: Memphis rapper, six proper albums and a few mixtapes into his career, laces observations about grim and violent street reality with gallows humor.

title: The Big Stiff Box Set
label: Salvo
description: The Big Stiff Box Set anthologizes Stiff Records' legendary nine-year run, and includes more than its share of incredible tracks, both well-known and waiting to be discovered. Among the artists featured are  Elvis Costello, the Damned, the Pogues, Motörhead, Devo, the Go-Go's, and Nick Lowe.

title: Alone: The Home Recordings of Rivers Cuomo
label: Geffen
description: After three safe and predictable records, the Weezer leader goes the opposite route, collecting demos of all sorts of goofy and indulgent ideas, and reminding us why we fell for dorks with horn-rimmed glasses and flying-V guitars in the first place.

title: Corn Meal Dance / Alphaville Suite
artist: William ParkerÕs Raining on the Moon
label: AUM Fidelity
description: Corn Meal Dance / Alphaville Suite

title: 4th & Wall
label: Milan
description: L.A. hype band sticks firmly within the realm of sun-drenched escapism and celestial sonics-- a gossamer soft-rock keyboard vibe cataloging the sex and danger pocking L.A.'s streets.

title: Heaven
label: Misra
description: Brooklyn electro-pop band's second full-length is even bubblier and more straight-laced than its predecessor.

title: EP of Bees EP
label: Hello Sir
description: Spazzy math-rock outfit from Athens, Ga., follows up their debut album with a comparatively intense EP that includes a live show and documentary on a bonus DVD.

title: Bionik
label: Cocoon
description: A deft mixer and singles artist par excellence, Dominik Eulberg tries his hand at crafting an album for a third time, releasing his latest on Sven Väth's Cocoon label.

title: Plum
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Chicago's Thrill Jockey celebrates its 15th anniversary with a lovingly packaged and limited-run box containing 10 seven-inch singles, each featuring associated artists covering songs from the label's catalogue.

title: Say Something
label: SideCho
description: Brooklyn quartet's full-length debut is a catchy and ornate tapestry of pop produced by Spoon's Jim Eno.

title: Nightly Things
label: Locust
description: Begushkin singer Dan Smith shares some of Will Oldham's peculiar tone and twisted phrasing but his band manages to carve out a space of their own on their debut album.

title: Saw a Halo
label: Load
description: Here on their Load debut, the noisy Brooklyn guitar/drums/electronics duo hold firm to what made them innovative and interesting while managing to make their sound new and forceful all over again.

title: 8 Diagrams
label: SRC
description: After a six-year absence and the death of Ol' Dirty Bastard, Wu-Tang return with a psych-tinged record that's divisive-- even within their own camp.

title: Brazil 70: After Tropicália – New Directions in Brazilian Music in the 1970s
label: Soul Jazz
description: Soul Jazz's Brazil 70 compilation is the sequel to its outstanding 2005 Tropicália compilation, and it uses 19 tracks to give a general picture of the way Tropicália's influence permeated Brazilian popular music as the 1970s progressed.

title: Cavalier
label: Fat Cat
description: Prolific North Dakota-raised singer/songwriter returns here to a markedly spare sound, working through well-worn folk themes like star-crossed love and suicide with just his voice and guitar.

title: The Forms
label: Three Spheres
description: Although they ostensibly draw inspiration from the D.C. underground, Brooklyn's the Forms reign in the more envelope-pushing elements of bands like Shudder to Think or Dismemberment Plan, salvaging a sort of introspective bedroom math-rock from their otherwise rowdy post-punk.

title: Spring a Leak
label: Matinee
description: Australian indie-pop band's generous vault-clearing is an excellent warts-and-all overview and a treat for longtime fans, even though it's not the best place for neophytes to start.

title: The Art of Field Recording, Vol. 1
label: Dust-to-Digital
description: Dust-to-Digital's latest box is an indispensable counterpoint to Harry Smith's Anthology of American Folk Music or its own flagship release, Goodbye, Babylon: Even if you've got a pretty good grip on how these songs worked in a recording studio, hearing them performed in the field-- in churches and homes, by non-professional musicians, complete with spoken asides, slips, yelps, groans-- is revelatory.

title: Oh, By the Way
label: EMI
description: This limited-edition 14-album, 16xCD box set immaculately repackages Pink Floyd's studio album discography but offers little to entice buyers other than its design and packaging.

title: Catch the Brass Ring
label: Nettwerk
description: New Americana singer-songwriter here comes across like a demurely disheveled young man slouched in an overstuffed leather chair, reading Steinbeck and picking at his acoustic guitar.

title: Take Music
label: Friends
description: Q and Not U guitarist goes the solo route, with an ear for unusual rhythms and an omnivorous feel for genre that sometimes seems like a lo-fi bedroom version of Stereolab.

title: Cotton Eyed Joe: The Loop Tapes - Live in Boulder - 1962
label: Delmore
description: This 2xCD/1xDVD set of intimate club recordings is a boon for Karen Dalton enthusiasts as well as those who discovered her from last year's reissue of In My Own Time.

title: The Solution
label: Def Jam
description: The Philly rapper follows his urgent 2004 album The B.Coming with a schizophrenic record split between bottle-popping and money-spending and the darker, more introspective stuff at which he excels.

title: Exodus: 30th Anniversary Edition
label: Interscope
description: Bob Marley's best-selling studio album features a good chunk of the songs you can find on the reggae singer's venerable cash-cow Legend, but that's no reason for newcomers to overlook it. This reissue adds a DVD featuring Marley's legendary 1977 London Rainbow performance in its entirety.

title: Elegies to Lessons Learnt
label: Beggars Banquet
description: Inspired by horrible historic events, iLiKETRAiNS specialize in the pressing weight of the inevitable, which may be why, for all its strengths, this otherwise strong debut has a been-there-done-that vibe about it.

title: How You Sell Soul to a Souless People Who Sold Their Soul???
label: Slam Jamz
description: Awkward titles are a given at this point, but the legendary hip-hop outfit brings the musical goods this time out, resulting in their best album in years.

title: Spinning Pieces
label: Locust
description: Taking recordings of bells, player pianos, and music boxes, this Portland, Ore., experimentalist digitally kneads his sources into extended, wordless compositions.

title: The Knee Plays
label: ECM
description: Originally conceived as one part of Robert Wilson's ambitious, avant-garde opera The CIVIL warS, this 1984 work is being issued for the first time on CD, with the addition of eight previously unreleased tracks and dense liner notes by David Byrne himself.

title: The Big Doe Rehab
label: Def Jam
description: Continuing with the harrowing narrative fervor that defined last year's compelling Fishscale and the old-soul loops that have defined much of his career, Ghost's new album may not uncover many new darts but, even 11 years after his solo debut, there's no denying one of hip-hop's most vibrant voices in its comfort zone.

title: Close to Paradise
label: Secret City
description: Like a Disneyfied Michel Gondry, this Polaris Prize winner is often preoccupied with the bewildering logic of what happens when we sleep, but only to the extent that he can extract a magical sense of fairy-tale escapism from it.

title: My Last Day
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: Rune Grammofon visual designer offers his fourth full-length for Smalltown Supersound, and it's crafted by minimal beats, plain chords, and small melodic accents in primal combinations.

title: Babylon Rules
label: Load
description: Clockcleaner have a bass-heavy lurch akin to the Jesus Lizard and Flipper, but this Philadelphia outfit isn't just emulating the sound of those bands-- there's a genuine desire to make listeners uncomfortable here.

title: Marina Gasolina EP
label: Domino
description: Marina Gasolina EP

title: Live
label: Capitol
description: Live

title: The Hunt for the Gingerbread Man
label: Class A
description: Subterranean MC with an aversion to quality control releases his fourth LP in two years and it's a concept piece about an anthropomorphic gingerbread man.

title: The Syliphone Years
label: Sterns Africa
description: This compilation gathers singles recorded in the 1960s and 70s, when Bembeya Jazz National was Guinea's national orchestra; the group combined Congolese rumba with Guinea folk styles.

title: Dance Party in the Balkans
label: Regular Beat
description: Beirut pal and Alaska in Winter auteur Brandon Bethancourt hybridizes a far-flung variety of forms into chilly, beat-oriented, downtempo hymns.

title: Free at Last
label: Roc-A-Fella
description: After a lengthy hiatus, the distinctive MC returns with a record reminiscent of Beanie Sigel's The B. Coming, one that's alternately boastful and ruminative, and on which he mostly avoids misguided attempts to become a crossover star. Jay-Z, Scarface, Jadakiss, and 50 Cent all guest.

title: Time for Heroes: The Best of The Libertines
label: Rough Trade
description: Three years after the band's dissolution, Time for Heroes cherrypicks the Libertines' singles, B-sides and fan favorites, but digs up no real novelties, and suggests a group mythically rich but musically meager.

title: The London Book of the Dead
label: Six Degrees
description: With the archness of Stephin Merritt or Momus, UK singer-songwriter Stephen Coates delivers a foggy concoction of cocktail-soaked big band, ragtime, lounge, bluegrass, and electronic pop.

title: Collected Works
label: Mountain
description: As they dabble in Tangerine Dream-style synth wanderings, drowsy disco rhythms, and pomo sampling, this UK band exists in roughly the same interzone as Swedish duo Studio, albeit with a less clearly pronounced debt to dance music.

label: Rune Grammofon
description: Less rhythmic and frenetic than 1-3 or 4, more aggressive than 5, and the best proof yet that 6-- the most accessible record in their catalog-- was an anomaly, this is another austere, rewarding record from Arve Henriksen's Scandinavian collective.

title: B/E/A/T/B/O/X
label: Italians Do It Better
description: A fall-tour exclusive (currently available in limited quantities through the Troubleman Unlimited website), B/E/A/T/B/O/X boasts nine tracks and over 40 minutes of exclusive material from one of the Italians Do It Better label's flagship artists.

title: The Joshua Tree: Deluxe Edition
label: Interscope
description: Twenty years ago, U2 graduated to superstardom with The Joshua Tree, an album that's survived all those years in the spotlight as a masterpiece. Now the disc gets the requisite set of B-sides and rarities, plus a DVD.

title: Through the Wilderness: A Tribute to Madonna
label: Manimal Vinyl
description: Artists such as Lavender Diamond, Giant Drag, Ariel Pink, and Jeremy Jay take turns covering Madonna with proceeds going to charity Raising Malawi.

title: Jukebox Explosion Rockin' Mid-90s Punkers!
label: In the Red
description: This collection of In the Red singles and a handful of rarities speaks to Spencer's sense of history and controlled irreverence.

title: X
label: Parlophone
description: On her post-cancer comeback album, Kylie Minogue seems as if she's crafted a revision primer for those who've ignored the past few years of chart pop, when more of what she does best would have been preferred.

title: I Wanna Go Backwards
label: Yep Roc
description: Robyn Hitchcock covered a great deal of stylistic ground over a dizzying number of albums, and this 5xCD set-- featuring three of his early solo albums and two discs of demos and outtakes-- attempts to make sense of his unique musical persona.

title: Radiance of Shadows / Guilted by the Sun
label: Alien8
description: This Toronto-based electro-metal duo has released four records in 2007; these represent the good and bad extremes of the band's frantic year.

title: I Was Submerged
label: Park the Van
description: Massachusetts band is sometimes evocative of My Morning Jacket, with a countrified rock sound that includes loud guitars, lots of reverb, and soaring vocals.

title: Out There
label: Now Again
description: Last heard guesting on DJ Shadow's The Outsider, UK band's debut full-length touches on funk, Afrobeat, soul-fusion-era jazz, and 1960s film soundtracks.

title: Iron Curtain Innocence / Harvest of Dreams
label: Vengeance
description: Iron Curtain Innocence / Harvest of Dreams

title: Thisisme Then: The Best of Common
label: Columbia Legacy
description: This compilation cherrypicks the best of Common's work for Relativity, for whom the hungry, young MC delivered three varied albums that displayed a compelling dedication to craft.

title: Believo!
label: SeeThru Broadcasting
description: Believo!

title: Gone Faded
label: Academy Fight Song
description: Brooklyn band looks to Britpop and shoegaze for inspiration, with mixed results.

title: Aluminum Lake
label: Drag City
description: Tim Green, best known for his work in the Fucking Champs and more recently with Citay, offers an enjoyable tour of the many places he's been.

title: Cry-Baby
label: Ever
description: Eclectic Norwegians, cramming into their long songs as many digressions, tangents, and asides as possible, are both the freaks and the geeks, deviants deciding their fates with a ten-sided die before cramming for that trig exam.

title: Gyrate Plus
label: dB
description: The legendary Athens band goes from being hipster homework to being easily appreciated thanks to a DFA reissue that includes every song from both versions of Gyrate, plus a few singles and extras.

title: David Bowie Box
label: Columbia Legacy
description: Perhaps oddly, David Bowie's hit-and-miss 1990s output is collected and re-released as a box set with each album expanded to double-disc sets containing a mostly negligible collection of catalog detritus.

title: Placelessness
label: 54º40' or Fight!
description: Singer-songwriter follows her Prettier in the Dark EP with a full-length of evocative, lyrical images and sparse arrangements.

title: Pale Young Gentlemen
label: self-released
description: With a DIY release and a penny orchestra sound, this Madison band should appeal to fans of Beirut and Clap Your Hands Say Yeah-- and their self-released LP should serve as a springboard to something greater.

title: Lovers, Lead the Way!/The Heat Can Melt Your Brain
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: Viva Voce's second and third albums-- complex, classy, and memorable home recordings-- thankfully resurface in a convenient 2xCD package.

title: The Hollows EP
label: Anticon
description: The Hollows EP

title: Sawdust
label: Island
description: The Killers follow Sam's Town with this odds'n'sods collection, a hodgepodge of everything they've tried in the past as well as a few things they'll no doubt try again in the future.

title: The Patron
label: Kranky
description: On its first album for Kranky, Minneapolis-based duo creates a concept album of sorts, using voice, guitar, and lots of computer processing.

title: Teenager
label: Virgin
description: For its third album, the Dublin band abandons Southern California to camp out in British Columbia, and accordingly the record feels much less geographically inspired than the band's previous work, focusing instead on the deep prickles of nostalgia.

title: Red Bloom of the Boom
label: Hometapes
description: Moving from ambient washes of synth and samples to sludgy, pseudo-anthemic passages of throat-straining emotion, this band's debut brings to mind both early post-rock outfits Bark Psychosis and Disco Inferno as well as mid-70s krautrock.

title: Causes 1
label: Waxploitation
description: This mixture of rarities and exclusive tracks from artists such as the Cure, Bright Eyes, the Shins, Death Cab for Cutie, Spoon, Bloc Party, and Animal Collective gives much-needed funds to the Darfur-related efforts of Doctors Without Borders, Human Rights Watch, and Oxfam America.

title: Ask Forgiveness
label: Drag City
description: This eight-song mini-LP-- which consists of seven far-flung covers, including tracks originally by Björk and Thom Yorke, R. Kelly, Phil Ochs, and Danzig, plus one original-- recalls Will Oldham's laidback and largely acoustic 1995 Hope EP.

title: Getback
label: ABB
description: After the finger-waggling of the divisive The Minstrel Show, Little Brother's third official full-length-- and first without 9th Wonder-- represents an attempt at figuring out just why the duo are rapping, and for whom.

title: Places
label: Saddle Creek
description: Former Q and Not U drummer John Davis' first proper full length alongside D.C. singer-songwriter Laura Burhenn as Georgie James is Saddle Creek-released bridge-bridge-chorus-heavy power pop, as blissfully laid-back as his former group was wound up.

title: The Valerie Project
label: Drag City
description: As a tribute to the cult Czech film Valerie and Her Week of Wonders, a collective led by Espers' Greg Weeks have created and performed an alternate soundtrack to accompany 35-mm projections of the film.

title: Shelter From the Ash
label: Drag City
description: Ben Chasny's third Six Organs of Admittance Drag City release in three years is a a bright if humdrum collection of tracks that shine beneath the same layered production Tim Green recently lent to Citay's adventurous Little Kingdom.

title: Mutantes ao Vivo: Barbican Theatre, Londres 2006
label: Luaka Bop
description: This 2xCD live collection documents the famed Brazilian group's first reunion show, at London's Barbican Theatre in May 2006, and despite missing original singer Rita Lee, it still finds the band in full voice.

title: Hexes For Exes
label: Metropolis
description: Los Angeles trio and dancepunk survivors Moving Units here suffer from a pretty nasty Cure streak that runs through nearly every track.

title: Prism of the Eternal Now
label: Kranky
description: Portland's Adam Forkner is a busy guy; after founding both Yume Bitsu and Surface of Eceyon, this is his fifth solo album in three years as White Rainbow, his alias for exploring minimalism and drones inspired by Terry Riley and Brian Eno.

title: Parades
label: Leaf
description: Where this Danish band previously garnered comparisons to Sigur Rós and Rachel's, they now skew closer to the skyward, communal missives of Danielson or Arcade Fire.

title: Red Carpet Massacre
label: Epic
description: Duran Duran hook up with Timbaland and Justin Timberlake in a further bid for the immortality the band deservedly achieved three decades ago.

title: Alive 2007
label: Virgin
description: Playing like a flawlessly sequenced and paced greatest hits album, this live set finds Thomas Bangalter and Guy-Manuel de Homem-Christo connecting the booms among their three albums while officially cementing one of the year's most rewarding and welcomed comebacks.

title: Beyond the Neighbourhood
label: Astralwerks
description: Latest record from Coldplay soundalikes who comes across like a band that believes David Gray's malnourished, defeated A New Day at Midnight remains the climax of singer/songwriter flirtation with technology.

title: Neighbor Singing
label: Hometapes
description: Former leader of Medicine and Electric Company makes his own version of a psychedelic folk-rock record, quietly slipping into 2007's sunny electro-psych-revival with Caribou and Panda Bear.

title: Discovered: A Collection of Daft Funk Samples
label: Rapster
description: This collection of Daft Punk sample source material indicates that they're transformative reinterpreters, and in more than a few cases, flat-out miracle workers.

title: D Sides
label: EMI
description: Damon Albarn's cartoon band bows out with a double-disc set of B-sides, outtakes, and remixes.

label: Rhymesayers
description: This Kansas City MC tackles everyman melancholoy and social realism on his Rhymesayers debut.

title: Mountain Home
label: Language of Stone
description: Spooky faux-traditional folk that falls eerily close to the real thing, Mountain Home, like its titular inspiration, helps you tune out the rest of the world.

title: To All Dead Sailors
label: Camera Obscura
description: Indie-folk balladeer Christian Kiefer and Northern Californian sound artist Jefferson Pitcher team for a nautically themed collaboration, which purportedly draws inspiration from the poetry of Pablo Neruda and the fiction of Jose Saramago.

title: Black Hollywood
label: Traffic Entertainment
description: It's five years since their last proper full-length, but not much has changed for the New York duo of Sonny Chiba and Geechie Suede, as they continue to stack images and loaded code words while drawing musical inspiration from old soul and funk.

title: Read & Burn 03
label: Pinkflag
description: Five years after the first two Read & Burn EPs, which were partially compiled in 2003 on the Send album in the U.S., Wire release part three and it features four songs that feel unique within the band's catalog.

title: The Black and White Album
label: A&M
description: The Hives ditch their native Sweden to record in Mississippi, working with  producers such as Pharrell Williams, Jacknife Lee, and Dennis Herring (Modest Mouse, Elvis Costello). They expand their thrashing guitar sound to include more bass and songs that clock in over three minutes.

title: Heavy Deavy Skull Lover
label: Tee Pee
description: West Coast neo-psych band aim to follow peers like Black Rebel Motorcycle Club or Brian Jonestown Massacre to fame-- or, at least, notoriety.

title: Shooting Spires
label: Cardboard
description: Working alone, Parts & Labor member creates hazy, playful, and rhythmically complex rock, his lyrics obscured by heavy reverb and white-noise guitar.

title: Mount Eerie Pts. 6 & 7
label: P.W. Elverum & Sun
description: Four years after Mount Eerie, Phil Elverum returns with the self-professed sequel, pressed onto a 10" picture disc and tucked between the pages of a massive, 132-page photobook.

title: Public Enemy #1
label: Diplomat
description: Just a few years after career peak Purple Haze, Cam'ron's music has come to reflect the hysterical insecurities of a man losing ground not only within hip-hop but within his own crew. Here he tries to get back on track with a 2xCD freebie mixtape.

title: The Complete On the Corner Sessions
label: Columbia
description: Another year, another indispensable Miles Davis box. This season's gift from Columbia/Legacy is a 6xCD set of every track put to tape by Davis' revolving cast of players bewteen 1972-75.

title: Waitin' Our Turn
label: Coughee Brothaz Entertainment
description: A fun, low-budget companion piece to Houston rapper Devin the Dude's last solo album, created with a massive band of friends, colleagues, and former Odd Squad comrades, most of whom seem to share the Dude's affinity for weed.

title: LP
label: Young Turks
description: Working through a process of improvisation and refinement, this dynamic instrumental band makes a monumental leap on its second album, an exciting blend of aggressive rhythm and nuanced, skillfully manipulated noise.

title: Frank
label: Island
description: Originally released in the UK four years ago and subsequently dissed by the artist herself, Amy Winehouse's debut finally lands on U.S. shores.

title: Fruit Tree
label: Island
description: This Nick Drake box-- originally issued in 1979-- still features the troubadour's three studio albums, but replaces rarities collection Time of No Reply with new and exhaustive liner notes and a DVD containing Jeroen Berkvens' 1999 documentary A Skin Too Few.

title: Galactic Zoo Dossier #7: Teenage Meadows of Infinity: Rare Psychs and Stomps / From the Ashes Perfect Attainment Shall Be: Modern Freaked Sounds
label: Drag City
description: The seventh collection from these psych-rock cratediggers is a 2xCD set that accompanies the excellent handwritten and illustrated zine. The Stooges, Devendra Banhart, and Charalambides are all featured, alongside a barrelful of relative unknowns.

title: Threads Rope Spell Making Your Bones
label: Carpark
description: Baltimore band bundles digital noise and tasteful drumming with unstable organ drones and long stretches of shaped hiss, evoking urbanity with a loose, folk-like quality.

title: Hangin' Nothin' But Our Hands Down
label: Sargent House
description: Originally hailing from Idaho but claiming temporary residency in Southern California and Chicago, this indie band's second album comes with its own set of eccentricities to justify an otherwise grandiose, ambitious, Radiohead/Muse sound.

title: Home Blitz
label: Gulcher
description: Though the sound is rough and the playing often sloppy, this garage-rock outfit manages to transcend the affectations of lo-fi with sharply observed songwriting and sheer exuberance.

title: Untrue
label: Hyperdub
description: The dubstep artist follows his critically acclaimed debut with the even richer*,* more complex, and more enveloping Untrue, a record of reverb-heavy and mournful songs that feel almost like beautiful secrets being whispered to a listener.

title: Volume 1
label: Break Glass
description: A patient, languid counterpoint to the frantic, anthemic pop that would soon make Montreal famous, Besnard Lakes' debut album is reissued, with distribution help from Jagjaguwar.

title: Sweep the Leg
label: Definitive Jux
description: Second album from New York rap crew on Definitive Jux is filled with double-time flows and occasionally tantalizing production, but more problematic elements dominate.

title: Emotionalism
label: Ramseur
description: North Carolina neo-bluegrass outfit write uncommonly affecting songs as they stumble through country, bluegrass, orchestral pop, and early Beatles-style pop-rock.

title: Karhunainen
label: Huume
description: On his latest excellent Uusitalo release, Sasu Ripatti (Luomo, Vladislav Delay) continues the gradual, tectonic drift from dub-techno abstraction toward the more disciplined sound of tech-house.

title: Mothership
label: Atlantic
description: Essentially a primer for those who actually might not be familiar with the Led Zeppelin catalog, this is a collection of unimpeachable songs in search of an audience.

title: Greatest Hits
label: Columbia
description: Greatest Hits

title: We Sing of Only Blood or Love
label: Fat Possum
description: Former lead singer of sludge-metal band Acid Bath-- working under his own name for the first time after heading up projects including Deadboy & the Elephantmen-- combines goth, blues, and psychedelia in songs about death and dying.

title: Everyone Wore White
label: 54º40' or Fight!
description: In the tradition of her hometown of Washington, D.C., Bui has made a punk-bred record where the guitar is loud but the tunes prevail.

title: Situation
label: Strange Famous
description: Canadian rapper Buck 65's latest is a vivid, long look backward to 1957, an indication that many of our half-century-old absurdities and anxieties haven't dissipated.

title: The Inevitable Rise and Liberation of NiggyTardust!
label: Fader
description: This Trent Reznor-produced record is following the In Rainbows price model, but just as importantly is the work of one of the few artists who can pull off the hip-hop/rock interchange.

title: The Virginian / Furnace Room Lullaby / Blacklisted / Fox Confessor Brings the Flood [Bonus Disc Edition]
label: Mint
description: The Virginian / Furnace Room Lullaby / Blacklisted / Fox Confessor Brings the Flood [Bonus Disc Edition]

title: Randall of Nazareth
label: Drag City
description: Randall Huth, on holiday from his power trio Pearls & Brass, largely avoids the hit-or-miss indulgence typical of solo projects as he crafts modest songs featuring his voice and steel-string resonator guitar.

title: The World Is Yours
label: Interscope
description: The former Stone Roses singer is now nearly 10 years into his post-Stone Roses solo career, and he still sounds like he hasn't left the late-90s.

title: Through the Panama
label: Load
description: This Brooklyn trio made their name with brutal records and performances that had the ineffable aura of performance art, but here they imbue their noise with No Wave's seizures and sharp angles, dance rhythms, clearer mixing, and subtly shaded dynamics.

title: Smith EP
label: Paper Bag
description: Before moving on to Saddle Creek and their long-awaited debut full-length, Tokyo Police Club issue this finely tuned Paper Bag EP.

title: American Gangster
label: Def Jam
description: Inspired by the Ridley Scott crime epic, Jay-Z's quickly-made drug kingpin record isn't as conceptually tight as he'd have liked, but it rips Jay out of the royal materialistic old-man haze that ruined Kingdom Come and recalls the titanic, invincible snarl that made him great in the first place.

title: Hera Ma Nono
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The second album from the U.S./Kenya Afropop hybrid thankfully keeps the emphasis on Africa, with ideal results.

title: Well Deep: Ten Years of Big Dada Recordings
label: Big Dada
description: London-based Big Dada celebrates 10 years of underground rap and avant-garde abstractionists with a label collection. Featured artists include Roots Manuva, TTC, Wiley, and Mike Ladd.

title: Guns Babes Lemonade
label: Modular
description: Modular's Muscles follows in a long line of everyday guys making party tracks for dancefloors and house parties alike-- think New Order, the Streets, "Born Slippy", the "hooligan house" of Audio Bullys, or his more-stylish fellow Australians in Cut Copy.

title: Businessmen & Ghosts
artist: Working for a Nuclear Free City
label: Melodic
description: The UK quartet's first American release-- which recalls Madchester, Primal Scream, and German-leaning contemporaries Caribou and Fujiya & Miyagi-- is an ambitious 2xCD record that somehow doesn't feel bloated.

title: Hvarf/Heim
label: XL
description: The companion disc to the concert film/doc Heima, this 2xCD set features two sides to Sigur Rós: new recordings of mostly unreleased old songs and, even rarer and more unlikely, an acoustic set.

title: Fresh Rot
label: Flameshovel
description: This Chicago band's unpolished assault on hard-to-get girls, crusty establishments, and the 9-to-5 lifestyle rightfully earns comparison to the Stones and Stooges.

title: 15 Again
label: Astralwerks
description: The first album in four years (five if you account for the one-year gap it took to cross the Atlantic) from the French dance band draws significantly from the funk, electro, post-punk, synth-pop, and techno movements that stretched across the span of the 1980s.

title: Hungry Beat
label: Acute
description: One of Scotland's forgotten post-punk pioneers, the Fire Engines are compiled to make a case for the hip company they keep alongside Orange Juice and Josef K.

title: Little Kingdom
label: Dead Oceans
description: Ezra Feinberg's typically instrumental psychedelic pop-rock group follows a model of easy-going inclusion on its latest and best album, a record gloriously embossed with shimmering solos and high-times harmonies.

title: Friend EP
label: Warp
description: The tracklist suggests it's just a collection of odds and ends, but that's a trick: Actually a well-disguised 31-minute mini-LP of newly recorded (and largely newly written) material, Friend marks Grizzly Bear's greatest leap forward yet, transforming them from purveyors of delicate fairytale psych to steamrolling rock juggernauts.

title: Make Sure They See My Face
label: Interscope
description: After a series of tough breaks, Kenna returns with a would-be breakthrough boosted by production from his pals and longtime supporters the Neptunes.

title: Brought to You By Nebraskafish
label: Team Love
description: Omaha band's debut mixes indie-folk, sound collage, politicized punk, and streamlined guitar pop.

title: Red State
label: Cardboard
description: Like those on Mountain Goats' We Shall All Be Healed, the songs on Gowns' dark, trembly, electronics-laden folk album are about people so unbelievably narcotized that they're barely cognizant of their surroundings.

title: HEALTH
label: Lovepump United
description: The self-titled debut by L.A. quartet HEALTH mixes the bombastic pound of Boredoms, the skewed structures of Deerhoof, and the tribal thump of Liars.

title: Big Change: Songs for FINCA
label: iTunes
description: Curated by actress Natalie Portman, this charity CD features work by the Shins, Devendra Banhart, Beirut, M. Ward, Antony & the Johnsons, and Rogue Wave, among others. It's worth your money, though perhaps not your full attention.

title: Couples Therapy EP
label: Plant Music
description: New York dance-rock outfit returns with a jittery, sullen seven-track EP that sort of rocks and doesn't really dance.

title: American Hearts
label: Superphonic
description: Though at times heavy-handed, there's a dark gravity to this album from the former Verbena singer, who now seems reborn as a southern preacher type, steeping blues-folk sermons in Biblical imagery.

title: Kings of Electro
label: Rapster
description: A 2xCD compilation mixed by Playgroup (former Output Records owner Trevor Jackson) and Alter Ego pauses to consider what we mean when we speak of "electro."

title: BBC Radio 1: Established 1967
label: Unknown
description: BBC Radio 1 celebrates itself by asking the hot bands of today (you know, Razorlight, Calvin Harris, Paolo Nutini) to cover the hits of yesteryear. Also involved are the Raconteurs, Lily Allen, Klaxons, the Streets, Foo Fighters, and Kylie Minogue.

title: Tonto+ EP
label: Warp
description: One of the year's best rock albums now has a companion EP-- complete with remixes from the Field and Four Tet, as well as a contribution from Joell Ortiz and a pair of videos.

title: I Created Disco
label: Columbia
description: Calvin Harris didn't create disco, duh. He didn't create electro-house, either, but in a year full of cranked synths, proud hedonism, and Daft Punk shows, the UK music-buying public has decided to befriend the Scottish producer and singer-songwriter.

title: 100 Days, 100 Nights
label: Daptone
description: Band's third album of convincingly vintage-sounding soul is slightly smoother and more refined than its predecessors, tending to evoke late-1960s Motown rather than early-70s r&b.

title: Worried Noodles
label: Tomlab
description: Visual artist David Shrigley has a book of his lyrics set to music by 39 artists over two CDs; among those featured are Liars, Grizzly Bear, Franz Ferdinand, Hot Chip, David Byrne, Final Fantasy, and Dirty Projectors.

title: Twilight & Ghost Stories / Between Them, A Forest Grew, Trackless and Quiet
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: Twilight & Ghost Stories / Between Them, A Forest Grew, Trackless and Quiet

title: Smoke
label: Domino
description: After successful tours with Dan Deacon and Girl Talk, White Williams issues a debut album layered with impeccable influences-- including Roxy Music, Beck, and T. Rex-- and a sense of calculated disaffection.

title: Jack of Diamonds
label: Varese Saraband
description: Cobbled together from various early 1970s sessions, Jack of Diamonds approximates what might have been the King of Cali-rock's second solo album.

title: Soft Pow'r
label: Rad
description: This short, sweet, and mostly acoustic offering is more austere than many of bandleader Kyle Field's prior records but no less affecting.

title: Fill Up the Room
label: K
description: Pop-rock fusionists release their seventh full-length and first for K Records, harnessing the disparate lo-fi and 1960s rock influences they've explored in their career thus far.

title: V Live
label: Different
description: Despite one album to his name, the easy availability of free mp3 bootlegs of DJ sets, and the relatively greater rewards of mixes, Pascal Arbez has decided to issue a live CD.

title: If He Is Protecting Our Nation, Then Who Will Protect Big Oil, Our Children?
label: Track & Field
description: If He Is Protecting Our Nation, Then Who Will Protect Big Oil, Our Children?

title: Hideout
label: Beggars Banquet
description: With an almost charming defiance, Bay Area foursome Film School are long on whooshy, gliding guitar lines and Kevin Shields impersonations.

title: Population
label: Arts & Crafts
description: Like Broken Social Scene, the Most Serene Republic blow up private bedroom ballads to marching band proportions and play up a revolving-door policy for vocalists.

title: In the Vines
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: Ray Raposa's gothic Americana remains obsessed with death and departure and inevitability on his latest Asthmatic Kitty release.

title: I'm Not There OST
label: Sony
description: The soundtrack to Todd Haynes' unorthodox Bob Dylan biopic casts more than two dozen artists-- including Stephen Malkmus, Sufjan Stevens, Jeff Tweedy, Cat Power, Sonic Youth, and Yo La Tengo, among many others-- to re-create the singer's singular voice in all its permutations and variations.

title: Anthology
label: Mute
description: Anthology

title: With My Left Hand, I Raise the Dead
label: Brassland
description: Second album by Thomas Bartlett builds on the hushed melancholy of his debut, but also shows an increased interest in texture, as proper songs alternate with varied instrumental interludes.

title: Necessary Evil
label: Eleven Seven
description: On her first solo album in more than a decade, Blondie's iconic frontwoman offers rare perspective from a 63-year-old woman in the rock world.

title: Environ Maiden
label: Rainbow Quartz
description: The long-mysterious and beloved Dean Wells prepares for his close-up by stepping into the world of live performance and issuing another record of understated Guided by Voices-like indie pop.

title: Likeness
label: Kranky
description: Tom and Christina Carter's latest album strikes a savvy balance between tradition-based songcraft and open-ended psych-folk expression.

title: Unknown Pleasures / Closer / Still
label: Factory
description: Tied to a film-related renewed interest in the band, Joy Division's three formative, formidable works get cleaned up and reissued in deluxe form.

title: Misbegotten Man
label: I and Ear
description: Second album by technically proficient Brooklyn duo with art-rock leanings puts a verbose and intellectual spin on dense, spasmodic musical structures.

title: Once Upon a Time in the West
label: Atlantic
description: The UK band follows its Clash-referencing debut with a record that proves to be a throwback not to 1979, but 1997: Here the group finds itself pitching every song to the bleachers at Wembley, open to electronic rhythmic enhancements and over-inflated with a sense of conviction and self-belief.

title: The Dream Merchant 2
label: 6 Hole
description: Early 1990s-style rap traditionalism colors a record complacent in the idea that evoking years past in a deeply personal and nostalgic way is enough to sustain an album. Mos Def, Little Brother, Jean Grae, and Saigon all make appearances.

title: Oblivion With Bells
label: ATO
description: Underworld offer their second album since the departure of longtime member Darren Emerson-- and first since their lone misstep, 2002's A Hundred Days Off-- and it improves on its predecessor and recalls their early 90s sound.

title: Load Blown
label: Paw Tracks
description: Culled from singles for DFA and Paw Tracks, as well as five cuts from an EP released simultaneously with Load Blown, the Brooklyn band's fourth official LP is really more a singles collection than an album but it hangs together well regardless.

title: Gettin' Gone
label: Ecstatic Peace
description: Latest from Massachusetts-based improv folkies Matt Valentine and Erika Elder finds them paying homage to Neil Young, not entirely successfully.

title: Even in the Midst...
label: Cuneiform
description: On album number four, this Asheville, N.C., trio offers technically complex instrumental rock executed without studio fussiness.

title: Hello, Avalanche
label: Peek-A-Boo
description: Since their 2005 breakthrough One Ten Hundred Thousand Million, these electronics-loving Austinites have further refined their sound.

title: Hourglass
label: Mute
description: Depeche Mode singer issues a Pro-Tooled set of dark rock grooves and electronic buzzing that, although lacking any element of surprise, finds his songwriting assured and competent.

title: All Hour Cymbals
label: We Are Free
description: This Brooklyn four-piece follows its fantastic single "2080" with a debut packed with similar moments of pan-ethnic spiritualism. Like Midlake, Grizzly Bear, and Animal Collective-- who have all recently re-shaped tribal, primitive sounds into ultra-modern forms-- Yeasayer channel both a dystopian science-fiction sensibility and deep appreciation for the natural world.

title: War Elephant
label: Feow
description: The 21-year-old singer-songwriter John McCauley leads this band on its debut album, which demonstrates influence from both the alt-country and more straightforward indie rock spheres.

title: Peanut Butter Wolf Presents 2K8: B-Ball Zombie War
label: Stones Throw
description: Compiled by Peanut Butter Wolf, this video-game tie-in doubles as the latest in a long line of Stones Throw state-of-the-label comps. Talib Kweli, Q-Tip, J. Dilla, MF Doom, and Madlib are among those featured.

title: Sologne
label: Dear John
description: Second U.S. release from Emil Svanängen is another rustic variation on sugar-sweet Swedish pop, and it carries both a willful naivete and dreamy solitude.

title: Some Things Just Stick In Your Mind: Singles and Demos: 1964 to 1967
label: Fat Cat
description: DiCristina collects Bunyan's singles recorded in 1965 and 66 for Decca and Columbia with Rolling Stones producer Andrew Loog Oldham, a string of demos from the same period, and the full reel-to-reel of her first studio recordings from 1964.

title: Shotters Nation
label: Parlophone
description: On the second release from his post-Libertines group Babyshambles, Pete Doherty writes what he knows: bitterness, self-pity, and general apathy towards his own exhausting public displays of drug addiction.

title: Fire Escape
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: Here the ramshackle folk/improv collective-- eight strong, with two Vibracathedral Orchestra members and Hush Arbors' Keith Wood in tow-- work under the direction of Four Tet's Kieran Hebden, resulting in their most focused album yet.

title: People Take Warning! Murder Ballads & Disaster Songs, 1913-1938
label: Tompkins Square
description: Life got you feeling too good? This 3xCD box set containing songs ripped from the headlines of the day is packed with death, reminding us of when life was really, truly terrible.

title: Two Sevens Clash: The 30th Anniversary Edition
label: Joe Gibbs
description: A devoutly Rastafarian vocal group led by Joseph Hill, Culture released this, their debut album, in 1977; enshrined in the canon as a roots-reggae classic, the record has been reissued in expanded form with a new running order.

title: Follow the Lights EP
label: Lost Highway
description: On this new EP-- which features a few new songs, bonus tracks from previous albums, at least one worthwhile do-over, and an Alice in Chains cover-- Ryan Adams continues the more honed, focused work that he and his backup group, the Cardinals, began with this year's Easy Tiger.

title: Preparations / Interregnums
label: Warp
description: Prefuse 73 aims to recapture some of the goodwill squandered since the next-Shadow heights of his 2003 LP One Word Extinguisher and its companion piece, Extinguished: Outtakes, and he manages to do so thanks to a bonus disc.

title: Grimwood
label: self-released
description: This reissue of Yonkers' 1974 sophomore album follows four years after his equally obscure 1969 debut, Microminiature Love, made its CD bow; where the latter leans toward psychedelic rock, Grimwood is a soft-focus folk record with tiny avant-garde tendrils.

title: Oracular Spectacular
label: Columbia
description: Oracular Spectacular

title: The Modern Tribe
label: 4AD
description: This 4AD group's second album, produced by TV on the Radio's David Sitek, features appearances from TVOTR and Yeah Yeah Yeahs' Nick Zinner. That makes sense: Celebration is what it might sound like if those two bands merged.

title: Pride
label: Dead Oceans
description: This is the latest from Matthew Houck, and though he still sounds a hell of a lot like Will Oldham, his blend of harmonies-and-drone with delicate folk-pop is a perfect autumn sound.

title: La Cucaracha
label: Rounder
description: On cult favorites Dean and Gene Ween's ninth album, the overriding sentiment seems to be a New Age-y approach to getting in touch with one's "inner" self.

title: Lightning Strikes
label: Decon
description: West Coast rapper, a backpacker favorite, offers the first in a promised series of albums fusing hip-hop with other genres; here he explores reggae and dancehall.

title: Draw Breath
label: Cryptogramophone
description: Another diverse selection of instrumental tunes from the band led by Wilco guitarist Nels Cline, these tracks range from slanted hooks and warped melodicism to outward-bound jazz workouts.

title: Catharsis in Crisis
label: K
description: Seventh album by the Pacific NW avant-blues/garage-rock outfit is the final entry in a trilogy that began with 2004's Lost Light, the band's finest effort to date.

title: The Oxford American Music Issue 2007
label: Oxford American
description: Oxford American and its annual Music Issue features a 25-track CD encompassing strands of rock, bluegrass, folk, blues, country, jazz, soul, hip-hop, and pop. Among the artists featured are Thelonois Monk, Daniel Johnston, Van Dyke Parks, David Banner, Karen Dalton, the Clovers, and Iris DeMent.

title: A New Chance
label: Sincerely Yours
description: Like Jens Lekman, who recently sampled this Swedish group, spiritual forebear Jonathan Richman, or fellow electro pranksters the KLF, the Tough Alliance are hopeless and hopeful romantics with a willingness to plunder for inspiration.

title: Adrenaline Rush 2007
label: Atlantic
description: The high-speed Chicago rapper known to most for his many guest spots finds himself alone much of the time on his newest full-length, which reprises the title of his 1997 breakthrough.

title: God Luck and Good Speed
label: Southern Lord
description: On its third studio album and first for Southern Lord, Albini-produced trio from Wilmington, N.C., has a fondness for typical stoner metal subject matter, but they also display an appealing regional sensibility, evinced by a cover of Lynyrd Skynyrd's "Gimme Back My Bullets".

title: Total Magique
label: Dare to Care
description: Montreal dance-rock trio's second album improves on its debut, as the band continues to explore the dark, messy, and painful aspects of relationships.

title: Lady's Bridge
label: Mute
description: Sheffield singer-songwriter Richard Hawley gets less mileage from the same trip with his follow-up to the impressive baroque-pop LP Coles Corner.

title: Overpowered
label: EMI
description: The second solo album from ex-Moloko frontwoman Roísín Murphy is a superb collection of 21st century disco that will sadly, inexplicably struggle in the pop marketplace.

title: The Kush
label: Nature Sounds
description: One half of Mobb Deep offers his first solo album, but Havoc has a steep climb to match the recent debut from his bandmate, Prodigy.

title: Carrion EP
label: Gnomonsong
description: Devendra Banhart associate issues a six-song EP that is split between new songs and demos from this spring's There's No Home.

title: Paris-Berlin
label: Unknown
description: The long-running international indie pop group issues its best album in quite a while, thanks to a return to a back-to-basics live sound that is tight and loaded with precision and verve.

title: The Trentemøller Chronicles
label: Audiomatique
description: On this 2xCD release, the prolific Danish artist pairs a selection of personal favorites from his own back catalogue with 11 of his remixes, including reworks of the Knife, Röyksopp, Robyn, and Moby.

title: Chrome Dreams II
label: Reprise
description: Scrapped in 1977, the original Chrome Dreams is one of rock's great lost records; 30 years later, Neil Young has decided that his new album is a sequel to that career enigma, referencing a chapter only his most dedicated fans would know about.

title: Adrian Orange & Her Band
label: K
description: One of the founders of Pacific NW indie label Marriage, Adrian Orange has also recorded under the name Thanksgiving; here he tackles genres like Afrobeat and reggae with the help of a large band including Phil Elvrum of Microphones and Calvin Johnson.

title: Ordination of the Globetrotting Conscripts
label: Azul Discografica
description: Brooklyn band's proper debut after reams of self-recorded CD-Rs and LPs finds it using jazz-based improv in a rock context, at times evoking the raucous party-noise of Hal Russell or the Sun Ra Arkestra.

title: Coronation Thieves
label: Gigantic
description: Drawing comparisons to their friends and mentors TV on the Radio, this NYC band moves from space-age soul ballads to mutant prog-metal over the course of its David Sitek-produced debut.

title: Live
label: Warner Bros.
description: Live

title: Live From Austin TX
label: New West
description: Live From Austin TX

title: Now You Are This
label: Kill Rock Stars
description: From its twitchy pop beginnings early in the decade, this San Francisco band has gradually transformed into an outfit bent on undulating keyboards and repetition.

title: Turn My Teeth Up!
label: Godforsaken Music
description: Eighteen years after a Bernie Worrell keyboard hook anchored one of Prince Paul's most memorable beats, the P-Funk icon and one of hip-hop's most legendary producers form a deliriously funky side project, with guest spots from George Clinton, David Byrne, and Nona Hendryx.

title: Heresy and the Hotel Choir
label: Flameshovel
description: Former Promise Ringers (along with ex-Dismemberment Plan bassist Eric Axelson) follow their enthusiastically received sophomore album, We, the Vehicles, with a record that does very little to tamper with its formula.

title: Grass Geysers... Carbon Clouds
label: Touch and Go
description: After a lengthy gap between records, Enon return with a handful of songs that seem radio- and arena-ready, and that's probably where these tracks would sound best.

title: In Rainbows
label: self-released
description: In Rainbows

title: Washington Square Serenade
label: New West
description: On his 12th studio album, Steve Earle bids a final farewell to Guitar Town-- his nickname for Nashville and the title of his infamous 1986 debut-- and celebrates his move to the decidedly un-country town of New York City.

title: Populations
label: Hometapes
description: Washington, D.C. band releases its fourth album, and it's another mix of unusual melodic structures and more typical rock arrangements.

title: The Sultanic Verses
label: In the Red
description: The garage rock vet-- one half of King Khan & BBQ Show-- issues his first solo LP, a record that's part-rockabilly, part-garage rock, and soaked in late 1950s fuzz.

title: Lady Day: The Master Takes and Singles
label: Columbia
description: This 4xCD box set collects highlights from Billie Holiday's 1933-1944 tenure on Columbia, a time that includes both her "Lady Day" and "Lady Sings the Blues" years and finds her unforgettable vocals at the peak of their powers.

title: Digital Shades Vol. 1
label: Mute
description: In the first volume of his Digital Shades series, which will collect his ambient works, M83's maximalist composer Anthony Gonzalez attempts to get back to his minimal roots.

title: Wooden Shjips
label: Holy Mountain
description: San Francisco quartet finds inspiration in the California frontier sex-and-death cult mentality, as they blend 1960s-style desert mysticism with hypnotic jams sometimes reminiscent of Spacemen 3.

title: Further North
label: Reprise
description: Second album finds the New York-based singer getting a good amount of songwriting help from Rilo Kiley's Jenny Lewis, but this album's improvement relative to his debut has more to do with Rice's new approach to vocals.

title: The Ortolan
label: Dim Mak
description: Though they are from L.A., this band is more likely to evoke the kind of widescreen indie rock often associated with Montreal, as they build epic songs using instruments like accordion and glockenspiel.

title: Lifeline
label: Hydra Head
description: Justin Broadrick caps the most productive year in Jesu's history, by issuing his fifth release in six months-- a four-song EP for Hydra Head that finds him exploring gauzy, swirling guitars and ephemeral vocals.

title: Night Drive
label: Italians Do It Better
description: Like labelmates Glass Candy, the Chromatics recently ditched their early aggro/noise-punk beginnings. Switching labels from the art-rock institution Troubleman Unlimited to the sleeker Italians Do It Better imprint, the trio's gone even darker, feeding sultry, minimal disco-punk through spidery horror flick synths and scuffed guitars.

title: Kemialliset Ystävät
label: Fonal
description: Finnish electro-acoustic folk collective with an affinity for playful abstraction doesn't experiment with genres so much as hazard upon them, like children gone exploring.

title: The Classic Guinean Guitar Group
label: Sterns Africa
description: This comp of lyric acoustic guitar work from the Diabate family is the third Guinean release Sterns Africa has offered this year, alongside a reissue of a Bembeya Jazz Ensemble retrospective and a singles collection from the Guinean state-run label Syliphone.

title: Dropping the Writ
label: Domino
description: While two quality full-lengths and an EP haven't reserved him a spot on indie's marquee yet, Cass McCombs still possesses a prodigal glow, and this is his first release for Domino.

title: Widow City
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The Friedberger sibs consolidate some of their strengths on a record placed firmly in the 1970s, one that finds them veering between ramming through ersatz Led Zeppelin riffs on bass and keyboards and coaxing soft-rock and soul arrangements out of a wheezy Chamberlin organ.

title: A Bunch of Stuff EP / Fabriclive 36
label: Fabric
description: Rock's best post-punk/disco (not disco) group gathers B-sides, remixes, and rarities from its Sound of Silver singles for an iTunes-only EP, plus two members helm a Fabric mix. Apparently, bandleader James Murphy likes the music of the late 1970s and early 80s-- who knew?

title: Good Arrows
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The acoustic/electric duo decamp to Thrill Jockey and offer a record that's warmer and fuller-sounding than anything they've previously released.

title: Pieces of Peace
label: Scarab
description: DJ Shadow and the Quannum label rescue from obscurity this early-1970s gem from an unheralded but adventurous Chicago funk/soul band, some of whom later went on to play with Earth, Wind & Fire.

title: Block Ice & Propane
label: SkipStone Records
description: Cellist who has collaborated with John Zorn, Laurie Anderson, John Darnielle, and Courtney Love crafts a concept album of sorts about the American landscape and the power of memory.

title: Comicopera
label: Domino
description: Venerable art-rocker Robert Wyatt-- an almost anti-pop star in the Scott Walker mold-- releases a beautiful protest in three parts. Brian Eno, Paul Weller, and Roxy Music's Phil Manzanera all guest.

title: The Flying Club Cup
label: Ba Da Bing!
description: Zach Condon's horn and ukelele remain in Brooklyn for the bulk of his sophomore album, The Flying Club Cup. Instead, he returns to France-- the place where he was first exposed to the Balkan music that colored much of this debut, Gulag Orkestar.

title: Bitchin'
label: Purple Feather
description: The eighth (!) album from the veteran punk band offers plenty of indicators that it would hearld the return of the fun and bratty Donnas of years past. Instead, it sounds like a half-hearted compromise between what the group was and what the group wants to become.

title: We Are
label: Jade Tree
description: This Jade Tree four-piece is the latest in a long line of Richmond, Va., bands forging no-frills rock that builds upon the aggression and brevity of early hardcore.

title: The Scene of the Crime
label: Anti-
description: After her 2005 comeback I've Got My Own Hell to Raise, Bettye LaVette records her proper return, backed by the Drive-By Truckers and fueled by decades of frustration.

title: Coast to Coast Carpet of Love / Standard Gargoyle Decisions
label: Merge
description: Coast to Coast Carpet of Love / Standard Gargoyle Decisions

title: Cease to Begin
label: Sub Pop
description: A geographical move (from the Pacific Northwest to the Carolinas) and a more settled, comfortable sound both seem like logical progressions for the Sub Pop band, who here go for texture and shade over size and scale.

title: Age Old Hunger
description: On his debut album, this Arkansas singer-songwriter writes songs about westbound trains and hearts on fire and feeling all burned up inside, which he sings in a voice pitched somewhere between the winnowy whine of Jimmie Dale Gilmore and the more forceful yodel of Slim Whitman.

title: Last Light
label: Altitude
description: Despite betraying his own moniker by transplanting from Pennsylvania to Brooklyn a few years ago, as well as the constant reshuffling of his musicians, Pond remains convinced that slow, steady, and innocuous wins the race.

title: The Throne of the Third Heaven of the Nations Millennium General Assembly
label: Hardly Art
description: Hardly Art-- a Sub Pop-affiliated label-- issues the debut from a band with a promising rural-versus-urban, organic-versus-machinated, new-math sound.

title: Save the World
label: Kompakt
description: Kompakt's flagship acts-- Michael Mayer and Superpitcher--  team for an album many anticipated might be the ultimate statement of the Cologne label's emo-house aesthetic. Instead, it's a ramshackle assemblage of dancefloor tracks, eccentric stabs at pop, and cinematic interludes.

title: Wizard of Ahhhs EP
label: self-released
description: With just one self-released EP under their belt, this Jacksonville-based five-piece are revealing promise beyond its life as a band: It's not just they've already hit on their own distinctive, signature aesthetic; they've also created four single-worthy sing-alongs right out of the gate.

title: Eulogies
label: Dangerbird
description: Debut album from project helmed by L.A. songwriter Peter Walker collects tracks written in 2006 when, as a solo artist, he toured the U.S. opening for the British band Starsailor.

title: Zamazu
label: Enja
description: The Cuban pianist crafts a versatile album that seems to draw from Quincy Jones' late 1960s work, classic soul-jazz, and even vintage German television soundtracks, with a bit of Brazilian flavor thrown in.

title: BOSS
label: Ecstatic Peace
description: A bona-fide rock album from a noisy duo known for a killer live show and inconsistent records. Here they find success with straight-up rockers, punk rants, country-ish acoustic tunes, and even an aching piano ballad. Lee Ranaldo produces.

title: For Emma, Forever Ago
label: self-released
description: For Emma, Forever Ago

title: DYLAN
label: Sony
description: This new 3xCD box set from the oft-compiled Bob Dylan is long on old staples and short on imagination.

title: Drug Rug
label: Black and Greene
description: A male/female bedroom pop duo based in Cambridge, Mass., Drug Rug approaches the themes and structures of traditional Americana (Hank Sr., Carter Family) with an eccentric indie spirit.

title: Mabused
label: Magpie
description: For a band with a modest, barely-preserved history-- this is the Mabuses' first album since 1994's Melbourne Method-- Mabused is a grand, spare-no-expenses reintroduction to the world of Soft Boys-inspired indie pop.

title: Virgo Blaktro and the Movie Disco
label: Nettwerk
description: The Chicago house icon releases his first album in three years, an ambitious attempt to reintroduce the roots of black soul music into the club scene. It probably would've been a rousing success if he'd remembered to finish most of the songs.

title: Magic
label: Columbia
description: The Boss returns, with the E Street Band in tow, for a surprisingly complex album that hides its disillusionment deep within its music, mingling it with a weary optimism that has not diminished with age.

title: IV
label: Virgin
description: IV

title: The Movie
label: Frog Stand
description: Debut album from this Brooklyn band with orchestral pop inclinations includes contributions from Sufjan Stevens, Van Dyke Parks, and renowned harmonicist Gregoire Maret.

title: A Night at the Ritz
label: Scratchie
description: Chicago quintet's first album for James Iha's Scratchie label, a mix of new songs and remastered older material, weds big-sounding indie rock to late-1970s pop moves.

title: La Vie d'Artiste OST
label: Too Pure
description: Stereolab co-leader and one of his longtime collaborators, the High Llamas' Sean O'Hagan, team to provide the soundtrack to a Marc Fittousi-directed French comedy.

title: Obligatory Villagers
label: Hungry Mouse
description: Nellie McKay's third album, like its predecessors, features tunes that take advantage of any number of patterns and modulations used by her musical forefathers (Gershwin, Rodgers & Hart, Weill, Leiber & Stoller), yet manage to seem a little off-the-cuff.

title: And Who Shall Go to the Ball? And What Shall Go to the Ball?
label: 4AD
description: The reborn art-music crusader reprises himself as a curious classical composer and a singer whose vocal presence proves monumental in surprising ways.

title: The Western Lands
label: Warp
