description: Nick Talbot mines the pleasant middle between noise and folk, his experiments in gentle psychedelia a warm counterbalance to the menacing mood his songs otherwise strike.

title: North Star Deserter
label: Constellation
description: Joining forces with members of Godspeed You! Black Emperor and Fugazi, among others, the Georgia songwriter's 11th album is his first for Montreal's Constellation label.

title: Polytheistic Fragments
label: Drag City
description: Already more than a quarter-century into his career, guitarist Sir Richard Bishop issues his first record on Drag City and it's his widest-ranging one yet, a joyful trip through his many styles, influences, and obsessions.

title: My Aim Is True [Deluxe Edition]
label: Stuff
description: One of three versions of the Elvis Costello's debut album currently in print, this 2xCD "deluxe" version packs the original album, outtakes, and the singer-songwriter's solo demos on the first disc, as well as an entire 1977 live show from the Nashville Rooms (complete with soundcheck) on its second.

title: Random Spirit Lover
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Between Wolf Parade, Swan Lake, and Frog Eyes, Sunset Rubdown's Spencer Krug may be the most prolific indie rocker this side of Robert Pollard, but you'd never know from this album: Random Spirit Lover may be one of the most toiled-over releases of the year, featuring melodies so architecturally complex and harmoniously joined that the boundaries between them become erased.

title: Bolts of Melody
label: Hi-Speed Soul
description: Solo debut by the one-time frontman of shoegaze heavy hitters Swervedriver gets better the further Franklin gets from the blistering guitar attack of his earlier band.

title: Watch the Fireworks
label: 4AD
description: Former Delgados singer Emma Pollock makes a strong solo debut that nonetheless spills over with self-doubt. She needn't have worried.

title: Home Again
label: EMI
description: The one-time Orange Juice frontman returns from two brain hemorrhages and a bout with a superbug to complete his sixth and most affecting solo record yet.

title: Black Madonna
label: Hydra Head
description: This strong full-length debut by the New York duo of Thad Calabrese and Justin Foley finds them infusing the structure of metal with the abrasion of Big Black-style noise-rock as they construct mathematically precise riffs to match the steady pulse of their drum machine.

title: In Our Nature
label: Mute
description: On his sophomore album, the Swedish singer and guitarist takes the basic elements of an acoustic troubadour's craft and explores their possibilities, not only as ingredients of songs, but as sounds to be enjoyed in their own right.

title: The Historical Conquests of Josh Ritter
label: Sony
description: Latest record from the beloved, wordy singer-songwriter is more rambunctiously immediate than any of its predecessors while retaining its smart arrangements, but it's still a mostly love/hate affair.

title: Going Way Out With Heavy Trash
label: Yep Roc
description: Second album of raucous pre-Beatles rock'n'blooze revivalism from Jon Spencer and Matt Verta-Ray is punk-style irreverent without being entirely blasphemous.

title: Pilgrimage
label: Southern Lord
description: Third album of metal-inflected psych/drone from Al Cisneros and Chris Hakius forges a balance between the crushing and the meditative, offering something for fans of both stoner rock and Steve Reich.

title: Shocking Pinks
label: Astralwerks
description: Former Brunettes drummer Nick Harte's first DFA release is a 17-track, 45-minute compilation cherrypicked from two albums recorded for the legendary Flying Nun, and it apes the scruffy, emotionally vulnerable indie that made that New Zealand imprint famous.

title: Curses
label: Too Pure
description: Curses

title: Between the Devil and the Sea EP
label: Dim Mak
description: On this polished Dim Mak sampling the Austin trio almost entirely strips the electric circuits of its debut, instead legging up to twee-pop perhaps once and for all.

title: Invitation Songs
label: Matador
description: As the newest entrants to indie rock's ever-expanding campfire folk circle, Seattle's (and Matador's) the Cave Singers like to sing of god and country, though only in the vaguest terms. Bassist Derek Fudesco is a former member of both Murder City Devils and Pretty Girls Make Graves.

title: RAWWAR EP
label: Social Registry
description: This three-song EP-- which taps out at just over 20 minutes-- is the latest (and best) in a string of relatively low-key follow-ups to 2005's underrated God's Money.

title: Fabric 36
label: Fabric
description: A mix CD comprised of new Villalobos productions, Fabric 36 is in the unenviable position of both having to deliver the arc of a great DJ mix and to stand as the first multi-track collection of material from the Chilean producer in over a year. In both cases it can be judged a triumph.

title: Echoes, Silence, Patience and Grace
label: RCA
description: Ten years on, Dave Grohl and co. reunite with The Colour and the Shape producer Gil Norton for an album that aims to recapture the band's early, successful anthemic sound.

title: Only Trying to Help
label: Better Looking
description: Singer-songwriter and former No Knife member combines the superbad geek catchiness of all those mid-1990s Weezer wannabes (Superdrag and Harvey Danger especially come to mind) with the mawkish, Claritin-deprived whine of this decade's emo.

title: Höstluft
label: Make Mine
description: This Swedish project-- now a solo effort after the departure of Per Jardsell-- returns with a record even more spectral than its previous Max Richter-like efforts.

title: I'll Follow You
label: Merge
description: Fourth album in three years from the Brooklyn band again offers its take on honky-tonk and the blues, which to Oakley Hall means melancholy and dust.

title: Two Gallants
label: Saddle Creek
description: The Saddle Creek band's self-titled album is a breakup record of epic proportions, a collection of folk-rock songs exploring the awkward, agonizing aftermath of failed love.

title: The Shepherd's Dog
label: Sub Pop
description: After expanding his palette on both the superb Woman King EP and 2005's full-band collaboration with Calexico, In the Reins, Sam Beam finally completes his gradual journey from lo-fi home recordings to a full-band setup. The gorgeous results find Beam and producer Brian Deck deftly venturing into dub, blues, and West African music, among other styles.

title: Civilians
label: Anti-
description: Joe Henry takes a break from producing others and releases his first solo album in four years, but while all the pieces are in the right place, and the lyrics aim for the poetic, the music lacks spirit to match its mood.

title: Gueen's Head
label: Social Registry
description: Christy is a native Californian and indie rock veteran weaned on hard rock, while Emily graduated from Oberlin Conservatory of Music and has worked with numerous composers and artists, and teaches piano; together, the product of their work, isn't just "rock" versus "classical," but interpretive versus creative, mood versus hook, song versus sound.

title: There the Open Spaces
label: Misra
description: The brainchild of London's spectacularly named Markland Starkie, Sleeping States' debut LP is packed with gentle, lapping compositions (most comprised of electric guitar and sugary vocals, exclusively) that re-appropriate and re-imagine folk paradigms.

title: Go Go Smear the Poison Ivy
label: Fat Cat
description: The Icelandic band's first record since the departure of founding member and singer Kristín Anna Valtýsdóttir finds several members of the now seven-strong band pitching in vocals-- including male leads for the first time.

title: White Chalk
label: Island
description: Polly Jean Harvey has never made the same album twice, and neither has she ever made an album as bleak as White Chalk, which finds her trading guitar for piano and haunting her own house.

title: A Love of Shared Disasters
label: Invada
description: Performing material written by Electric Wizard drummer Justin Greaves, with Mogwai bassist Dominic Aitchison helping to set the tone, Crippled Black Phoenix offer a collection of apocalyptic hymns.

title: Pseudosix
label: Sonic Boom
description: Portland collective under the direction of Tim Perry includes members of the Joggers, the Standard, and Grails, and mixes the sounds of 1960s and 70s California pop (Beach Boys, Eagles) with contemporary lyrical concerns.

title: Somewhere, Anywhere
label: Arts & Crafts
description: Australia's Sally Seltmann-- who wrote Feist's "1 2 3 4" and is signed to Arts & Crafts-- issues her second album of intimate pop songs.

title: Love Is the Song We Sing: San Francisco Nuggets 1965-1970
label: Rhino
description: Rhino's fourth 4xCD Nuggets compilation-- complete with lavishly illustrated and beautifully printed liner notes-- steps laterally away from blasts of fuzzy pop and obscure singles to build a panoramic picture of what was happening in Bay Area rock music between 1965 and 1970.

title: Smokey Rolls Down Thunder Canyon
label: XL
description: The notoriously kooky singer/songwriter's fifth full-length picks up the thread of 2005's schizophrenic Cripple Crow, alternating between kitschy genre exercises and the sweetly emotive folk songs that have always been his greatest strength.

title: The International
label: Highwheel
description: Full-length debut by Chicago band is a mix of familiar underground sounds with peculiar execution, cobbling songs together from loose, jagged shards of melody, suggesting and insinuating hooks rather than laying them out for the listener.

title: You're Gonna Miss Me OST
label: Palm Pictures
description: The soundtrack to the 2005 documentary of the same name, You're Gonna Miss Me attempts to economically anthologize Roky Erickson, a man whose vast, scattered output all but defies anthologizing.

title: Red Album
label: Relapse
description: Another fantastic Georgia metal band, Baroness offers a fully realized record that is more ambitious, more accomplished, and simply bigger than anything they've done before.

title: Love's Miracle
label: Ipecac
description: Though it doesn't return unchecked violence and grit to indie rock, the new album from a band led by Jesus Lizard's David Yow is satisfyingly loud, far-flung, and fucked-up.

title: Love Is Simple
label: Young God
description: Michael Gira's Angels of Light backing band issues its latest Young God release-- an absurd, occasionally awkward celebration of humanity, love, and the natural world.

title: Our Way Is Revenge
label: Kanine
description: Containing members of the Rogers Sisters and Celebration-- and with production assistance from TV on the Radio's David Sitek-- this Brooklyn band fits snugly into the post-punk niche on their mini-LP debut.

title: Ulual Yyy
label: Fonal
description: On her third full-length, this Finnish singer-songwriter conjures a surreal landscape that veers from hushed, spooky neo-folk to more abstract noisemaking.

title: Piece Work/Fabric 35
label: Fabric
description: Two collections from the English producer integral to the development of electro-house. The first gathers together remixes, including versions of tracks from the Chemical Brothers, the Flaming Lips, and Depeche Mode; the second, Pearson's entry in the Fabric mix series, is a focused DJ set.

title: Our Ill Wills
label: Merge
description: Merge issues a U.S. version of the Shout Out Louds' latest album, a record that boasts sharper hooks and emotionally richer songwriting than its predecessor, the 2005 Capitol LP Howl Howl Gaff Gaff. Björn Yttling (of Peter Bjorn & John) produces.

title: Trees Outside the Academy
label: Ecstatic Peace
description: Sonic Youth's Thurston Moore follows his band's return to tunefulness, Rather Ripped, with his first formal LP since 1995's Psychic Hearts. Here he takes up an interesting challenge: What can a guy like Moore do with the bare and noiseless architecture of an acoustic guitar and a verse-chorus-verse set-up?

title: Sighs Trapped by Liars
label: Drag City
description: The venerable Mayo Thompson returns with an album of waifish folk-rock with a hint of psych-- his version of indie-pop, maybe-- in collaboration with conceptual outfit Art & Language.

title: Rap Music
label: Recordcollection
description: A DJ-MC partnership in the mold of Jazzy Jeff and the Fresh Prince, Brother Reade combine eerie, hallucinatory atmospherics with a bare-bones, Deep South take on boom-bap.

title: Whore Luck
label: Polyvinyl
description: Toronto-based Polyvinyl band mines music from the most extreme intersection of beauty and melancholy. Xiu Xiu's Jamie Stewart and ex-member Owen Pallett of Final Fantasy guest.

title: The Piper at the Gates of Dawn [40th Anniversary Edition]
label: EMI
description: The Piper at the Gates of Dawn [40th Anniversary Edition]

title: Let's Stay Friends
label: Frenchkiss
description: Les Savy Fav's first studio album since 2001's Go Forth is a pleasant surprise-- and not just because many of us thought they'd never record again. Rather than listlessly rehashing their past achievements or attempting a superficial overhaul, they're doing something much riskier: trying to become a better band.

title: Polluted Water
label: Babygrande
description: Raekwon assembles a crew, claims they're on his level, and "presents" their debut LP. Turns out he was mistaken about their quality.

title: The Wind and the Swell
label: American Dust
description: Port O'Brien continues indie-folk's fascination with nautical themes, but they've earned the right to the salt-crusted imagery: Band mainstay Van Pierszalowski, a California native and son of a commercial fisherman, spends his summers aboard an Alaskan salmon schooner.

title: Allure EP
label: Die Stadt
description: The third and final installment in Fovea Hex's Neither Speak Nor Remain Silent trilogy-- which features apperances by Robert Fripp and Nurse With Wound's Colin Potter-- closes the captivating series with an impressive balance and symmetry.

title: Happy Birthday!
label: Bpitch Control
description: Gernot Bronsert and Sebastian Szary-- together in various guises for almost 15 years-- fuse together the most unfashionable or discarded elements of electronic music's recent history on their second Modeseletor album. Radiohead's Thom Yorke, TTC, and Otto Von Schirach guest.

title: Spirit If...
label: Arts & Crafts
description: Backed by a 23-person guest list that includes Dinosaur Jr's J Mascis, Pavement's Spiral Stairs, and countless members of Broken Social Scene, the debut solo album from BSS leader/co-founder Kevin Drew could pass for a low-key follow-up to his band's 2005 self-titled record.

title: Jackals and Vipers in Envy of Man
label: Ninja Tune
description: Dubby instrumental hip-hop from Montreal by a familiar name from the late 1990s and early 2000s oddly works best when given less than full attention.

title: Solo
label: Editions Mego
description: Latest from the Japanese singer and producer, now based in Paris, is a patchwork of radio static, outdoor sounds, snippets of recorded strums, and the naked human voice, combining her interest in texture with a skewed pop sensibility.

title: In a Nutshell
label: Twentyseven
description: This Swedish pop artist, who formerly fronted the band Edson, writes imaginatively and wittily about his own career trials and travails, as well as the predicaments that accompany life in the pop trenches.

title: Asleep at Heaven's Gate
label: Brushfire
description: Having parted ways with Sub Pop, Rogue Wave's third album-- and second as a full band-- opens by promising their best work yet, but quickly runs out of steam.

title: The Modern Lovers
label: Beserkley
description: Jonathan Richman's debut with the Modern Lovers still sounds every bit as ahead of its time as the last time it was reissued, and the time before that, and the time before that.

title: Kurr
label: Ever
description: Veterans of multiple Sigur Rós tours, these four Icelandic women debut with crystalline string pieces that that diffidently betray their history as accompanists.

title: Map of Africa
label: Whatever We Want
description: Thomas Bullock (Rub 'N Tug, A.R.E. Weapons) and DJ Harvey's polarizing Map of Africa debut LP-- which, like records from contemporaries Arboretum and A Mountain of One, feels like a re-creation of the 70s rock record they couldn't find secondhand-- has a lot of ideas, but ultimately frustrates more than rewards.

title: Supermoon
label: Heads Up
description: Latest album from Belgian-Congolese auteur Marie Daulne uses polyrhythms and Saturday night exuberance to coat serious themes with a glaze of cheer.

title: Happiness Ltd.
label: Warner Bros.
description: On their third full-length album, Hot Hot Heat attempt to sound far-reaching and fully formed at the expense of the unhinged urgency that made them so engaging in the first place.

title: Kurt Cobain About a Son
label: Barsuk
description: The soundtrack to AJ Schnack's new Kurt Cobain documentary, About a Son-- a film that has the uncanny effect of making its subject seem like he's still alive-- itemizes the significant phases in the Nirvana singer's life with the songs that soundtracked them.

title: Best Friends in Love
label: Last Gang
description: This, the debut album by the Metric rhythm section, is essentially post-post-punk pastiche and barely disguised amateurism.

title: Sgt. Disco
label: Ipecac
description: Latest collaboration between Robert Pollard and former Guided by Voices producer Todd Tobias, their first for Mike Patton's Ipecac label, is relatively more rock-oriented than its predecessors, offering something for those outside the Pollard cult.

title: Simple Love
label: Team Love
description: Team Love artist and Bright Eyes influence's seventh album sort of shuffles around, hands in pockets-- faux-shucks posturing built on wry, self-deprecating lyrics and bare instrumentation.

title: Autumn of the Seraphs
label: Touch and Go
description: Rob Crow's consistently rewarding group offers another record built on the sophisticated interplay and Swiss-watch-slick rhythms between its main players.

title: Proof of Youth
label: Sub Pop
description: The Brighton band follows Ian Parton's explosive home project Thunder, Lightning, Strike with its first record as both a full-fledged, crowd-pleasing band and a Sub Pop-signed act.

title: Made of Bricks
label: Fiction
description: Lily Allen 2.0, Kate Nash has a gift for communicating confusing romance with a keen eye for detail and scene-stealing turns of phrase, but too little of that is conveyed on her debut LP.

title: 24->24 Music
label: Sleeping Bag
description: 24->24 Music

title: Curtis
label: Interscope
description: This week's other big hip-hop release finds the Queens rapper still pushing repetitive nihilism and G-Unit production styles instead of branching out and taking chances with his music.

title: Graduation
label: Def Jam
description: Though it doesn't quite match College Dropout or Late Registration in pleasure-center overload, Kanye West's third album is both his most consistent and most enterprising yet, indicating that he might actually deserve the legendary status he constantly ascribes to himself.

title: A
label: Kemado
description: A

title: Bring on the Comets
label: Astralwerks
description: Louisville band continues to traverse the path from disco to straight-ahead rock on its new album, which is tied together by ostentatious spot-the-influence moments.

title: London Town
description: After his commercially disappointing yet artistically successful debut Home Sweet Home, the UK rapper offers a sophomore record that replaces his appealing self-conscious anxiety and innocence with hollow angst, slackened intensity, and Damon Albarn.

title: Home Schooled: The ABCs of Kid Soul
label: Numero Group
description: Following the runaway success of the Jackson 5 at the turn of the 1970s, the search was on for more talented kids playing soul, funk, and r&b; this Numero Group compilation gathers some of the more interesting small-label obscurities from the era.

title: Help Wanted Nights
label: Saddle Creek
description: Tim Kasher's latest record as the Good Life is another pseudo-concept record on which the Cursive leader examines fleeting fictional moments and crafts big stories, from varying narrational perspectives.

title: Strawberry Jam
label: Domino
description: Already among the decade's most vital artists, Animal Collective cement their status with the spectacular Strawberry Jam. On its first true pop record, the band masters its distinctive experimental approach to songwriting, folding celebration, longing, doubt, loss, and acceptance into complex hooks and choruses.

title: Two of Diamonds
label: Mute
description: Nick Cave's right-hand man issues his fourth solo album, a typically moody amalgamation of originals and covers, with particular focus on songs from fellow Australians.

title: The Budos Band II
label: Daptone
description: Second album from Brooklyn crew crams Afrofunk, soul-jazz, 1970s blaxploitation soundtracks, 60s Now Sound LPs, Ethio-jazz, and plain old superbad funk into concise tracks stuffed with compact solos and big themes.

title: Bobby Bare Sings Lullabys, Legends & Lies (And More)
label: Ember
description: This 1973 collaboration between poet and songwriter Shel Silverstein and country vocalist Bobby Bare plays like the best hippie redneck adult children's album ever made.

title: From Dubplate to Download: The Best of Greensleeves Records
label: Greensleeves
description: Presenting 30 sterling hits stretching from the fading cries and laments of the last days of roots reggae to the deviousness of the latest dancehall tune from the yard, this 2xCD label compilation is another reminder-- as if one were needed-- that Greensleeves is not only one of the premiere Jamican labels of the past three decades, but one of the most dependable full stop.

title: Rise Above
label: Dead Oceans
description: A song-by-song "reimagining" of Black Flag's Damaged, the excellent new album by Dirty Projectors is, more importantly, the work of a band that is restructuring rock on a compositional level rather than a sonic one.

title: The Battle of Sealand
label: Highwheel
description: Experimental rockers from Chicago release their first full-length, a torrential, occasionally pretty mess of punk, ambient, noise, and typical rock.

title: City Morning Song
label: Minty Fresh
description: Second solo album from the former leader of Velocity Girl has songs in a classic pop style, revealing a debt to great American songbook composers like Cole Porter and Irving Berlin.

title: La Radiolina
label: Nacional
description: Singing in seven languages and bringing aspects of music from across Western Europe, North Africa, and the Americas into his polyglot sound, Manu Chao is a superstar in Europe and Latin America and has recently released this, his first studio album in three years.

title: Scum: 20th Anniversary Edition
label: Earache
description: One of the cornerstones of grindcore, the debut LP from Justin Broadrick's first fantastic metal band gets a 20th anniversary reissue on Earache.

title: Good Bad Not Evil
label: Vice
description: Black Lips are a go-to band for vintage lo-fi freaks, and their raucous live shows have helped them cross over outside of crusty dive bars. Good Bad Not Evil, however, is the record where naysayers, disinterested friends and aquaintances, people on the street, and anyone else within earshot has to sit up, shut up, and listen.

title: An Unknown Spring
label: Wonder
description: On his first solo outing in three years, Louis Philippe takes listeners to his sophisticated "pop fantasy world", and at a time when Scott Walker, Joanna Newsom, Sufjan Stevens, and Final Fantasy receive widespread critical acclaim, these majestic orchestral confections ought to find a properly appreciative audience.

title: A Hawk and a Hacksaw and the Hun Hangár Ensemble
label: Leaf
description: Limited edition EP from former Neutral Milk Hotel drummer Jeremy Barnes and violinist Heather Trost finds them collaborating with Hungarian musicians and Zach Condon of Beirut.

title: Hands Across the Void
label: Sub Pop
description: Full-length debut by Seattle singer-songwriter Jesy Fortino shares certain qualities with early Cat Power and Joanna Newsom, but Fortino's sense of yearning is less romantic and more spiritual.

title: Bluefinger
label: Cooking Vinyl
description: Returning to the Black Francis moniker for the first time since the early 1990s breakup of Pixies, the former Frank Black also returns here to rowdier, weirder, louder music.

title: Night Falls Over Kortedala
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Swedish singer-songwriter Jens Lekman returns for his genre-conquering second album, encompassing baroque pop, Northern soul, and Swedish beach-party disco. Like the Avalanches if they sang their own tunes, Lekman constructs lush, romantic worlds from vinyl-crackling LP samples, while his wry, melancholic lyrics-- his sharpest and most endearing yet-- prove him the true successor to indie's ultimate lovesick cynics, Jonathan Richman and Stephin Merritt.

title: Have Mercy
label: Elixia
description: Beset by personal tragedy, line-up changes, and label woes, the New York garage rock revivalists return at last, their once mighty catcall now reduced to a wistful sigh.

title: Down Below It's Chaos
label: Sub Pop
description: Seattle band moves from the spacey psychedelic marathons that previously defined the project into more immediately familiar proto-metal and rock.

title: One Man Band Man
label: Motown
description: One of the most dependable big-name producers in rap takes a turn as an MC, camouflaging his weaknesses and sometimes even turning them into strengths.

title: Mantaray
label: Decca
description: The iconic Siouxsie Sioux stakes new ground with her first official solo album, as-- for the first time in about a decade-- she's veering not toward her artiness or her sophistication, but her flat-out star power.

title: Hey Venus!
label: Rough Trade
description: The prolific and dependable Welsh band returns, with Broken Social Scene producer David Newfeld at the helm and impeccable string arrangements from the High Llamas' Sean O'Hagan.

title: Gauntlet
label: Editions Mego
description: Chicago's Kevin Drumm and Portland's Daniel Menche combine their main tools-- fuzzed-out distortion, insect-like drone, and chopping pulse-- to try to find any remaining drops of pigment in those faded colors.

title: Versatile Heart
label: Rounder
description: The second comeback release from always respected but just short of revered folk singer Linda Thompson exudes class and weepy emotion. Antony Hegarty and Rufus Wainwright offer assistance.

title: Fabric 34
label: Fabric
description: Following a party in her flat, Berlin techno star Ellen Allien mixed this entire set on vinyl, by hand-- an old-school gesture for a woman vividly alive to her city's place in dance music history.

title: Wattstax
label: Stax
description: Stax issues an expanded 3xCD box set commemorating what is arguably the definitive r&b festival, featuring handfuls of artists-- including Isaac Hayes, Rufus Thomas, Carla Thomas, and the Bar-Kays-- at the peaks of their careers.

title: A Place to Bury Strangers
label: Killer Pimp
description: Setting tinnitus-inducing noise-pop against a tension-wracked Joy Division-meets-Ministry backdrop, this Brooklyn trio drenches lovesick indie pop in sheets of deafening static and distortion. Plenty of bands may have tapped the trebly, ecstatic side of shoegaze in recent years, but none have imbued it with this band's frustrated aggression or lacerating, industrial feedback.

title: The Miracle Inn
label: Wichita
description: Third solo album from the leader of Welsh psych-pop wonders Gorky's Zygotic Mynci is a nostalgia trip, from its 1970s-pop dressing to lyrics full of wistful, coming-of-age remembrance.

title: The Hymn of the North Star
label: Family Vineyard
description: This hybrid of two recent Connors recordings is a cautiously romantic record, wide spaces floating between beautiful, sinister chords and torpid trickles of notes.

title: 30 Year Low/Final Remarks of the Legendary Malcontent
label: Glurp
description: After 10 years and eight albums, Tim Bracy and Shannon McArdle, the couple who formed the core of the Mendoza Line, have split: 30 Year Low is a mini-album of new material and it's packaged with Final Remarks of the Legendary Malcontent, which traces their relationship through a dozen and a half covers, live tracks, alternate takes, and rarities.

title: Prinzhorn Dance School
label: DFA
description: A duo from England dress down post-punk-- particularly the minimalism and anxious vocals of the Fall-- on this eerie DFA missive.

title: Guilt by Association
label: Engine Room
description: This hit-and-miss effort finds indie luminaries such as Devendra Banhart, Jim O'Rourke, Superchunk, and Will Oldham covering tracks by the Spice Girls, Mariah Carey, Paula Abdul, and Fall Out Boy.

title: Cozy Endings
label: Social Registry
description: Incorporating elements of jazz and dub, this eclectic group can recall some of the Beastie Boys' better homegrown funk instrumentals, as well as the dusky post-rock of Chicago's Tortoise / Isotope 217 contingent.

title: XI
label: Drag City
description: On his latest record, Neil Michael Hagerty hedges his post-modern tics in favor of three-minute, riff-based rawk that reminds us this is the same rock zealot who convinced Pussy Galore to re-record Exile on Main St. back in the day.

title: Steve McQueen [Legacy Edition]
label: Kitchenware
description: The defining record of 1985 sophisto-pop, now remastered and reissued with an extra disc of new acoustic renditions by the band's singer and songwriter Paddy McAloon.

title: Eardrum
label: Warner Bros.
description: After the regrettable Beautiful Struggle and the solid, net-only Madlib collaboration Liberation, Talib continues his slight return to form, sounding confident and relaxed as he receives guest help from Justin Timberlake, Kanye West, Just Blaze, Madlib, and Pete Rock.

title: Rumble in the Jungle / Ragga Jungle Dubs
label: Soul Jazz
description: Two recent compilations-- one from Soul Jazz and one from Greensleeves-- serve as primers for the still-fantastic combination of breakbeats, dub basslines, New York slang, Jamaican patois, and the faint taste of Detroit techno, Chicago house, and hardcore rave.

title: Grand Animals
label: New Line
description: Spoon-ish indie rock band goes transatlantic on its second album, living up to the group's name by indulging its jones for the jaunty hooks and clever wordplay of Anglophile pop.

title: Perseverance
label: Stones Throw
description: After 19 years-- enough time for a rap career to vanish into thin air four times over-- NYC underground fixture Percee P finally, finally releases his first full-length album of all-new material, crammed with elaborate battle-rap boasts and some of Madlib's hottest beats in years.

title: Heavenly Pop Hits: The Best of the Chills
label: Flying Nun
description: A reissue of a best-of isn't the most earth-shattering of releases, but any excuse to revisit one of the best of New Zealand's many legendary Flying Nun acts is a good one.

title: Because I Love It
label: Columbia
description: Despite being-- along with Beyonce and Rihanna-- one of the most charismatic and accomplished modern r&b singers, Amerie's latest album still is somehow unreleased in the U.S.

title: None Shall Pass
label: Definitive Jux
description: On his latest album, None Shall Pass, Aesop Rock's most distinguishable characteristic, his relentless verbosity, shows no signs of slowing for anyone-- be it the mainstream, the uninitiated, or even fans who couldn't keep up with Bazooka Tooth.

title: Gangsta for Life: The Symphony of David Brooks
label: VP
description: Jamaican dancehall star compiles singles and new material into a lengthy album, using dirge-like martial beats to develop a persona as a remorseful, weary thug.

title: Summer Records Anthology 1974-1988
label: Light in the Attic
description: After last year's Jamaica to Toronto compilation-- which focused on the funkier, r&b-influenced corners of Toronto's underground reggae scene of the 1960s and 70s-- Light in the Attic returns with a look at the nearby Summer Sound Studios and its heavier, more dubbed-out works.

title: Real Life
label: Reveal
description: After years of playing second fiddle-- actually five-string viola-- in bands like the Dambuilders and for famous friends such as Rufus and Antony, Joan Wasser steps up to the mic with a gorgeous debut.

title: Mentor Tormentor
label: Majordomo
description: One of the leading lights of the Silver Lake scene, Earlimart issues its fifth album, a record dominated by chamberish piano-and-string compositions and rainy-day pop.

title: Liars
label: Mute
description: These wildly unpredictable art-rockers infuse the murky experimentation of their last two albums with the raw two- and three-chord rigor of punk, 1960s garage, and early 70s hard rock.

title: Twilight of the Innocents
label: WEA
description: Sixth album by the UK rockers is allegedly their last-- they're going to remain a band but focus on singles-- and finds them finishing this part of their career on a reasonably strong note.

title: Future Rock
label: Kranky
description: Not unlike fellow technophilic dilettante Matthew Dear, Strategy's Paul Dickow divides his latest album between forward-looking pop songs and atmospheric instrumentals.

title: Crickets: The Best of the Fading Captain Series 1999 - 2007
label: Fading Captain
description: Two-disc collection of material from the infamously prolific Robert Pollard skims from the 20+ records in the Fading Captain series and adds a number of unreleased tracks; deluxe packaging includes photos and original album artwork.

title: Natural
label: Quarterstick
description: The Leeds collective circles the wagons once again, only this time it's the prospect of post-apocalyptic defeat that looms in the darkness.

title: All Y'all
label: Barsuk
description: The former Dismemberment Plan singer follows his inadvisable solo bow with another audacious record free of checks and balances, a product of him following his muse to wherever it would go.

title: Oh, My Darling
label: Rough Trade
description: This London, Ontario-based singer-songwriter is both a neo-madrigal folkie and a muted soul whisperer; at its best, her debut album for Rough Trade is an attractive admixture of aristocratic lilt and snapping rhythm.

title: Howl on the Haunted Beat You Ride
label: Cass
description: Eight years removed from their raucous, swaggering Sub Pop debut, this linchpin of Detroit's nu-garage rock scene's latest is informed by power-pop and psychedelia.

title: KMH
label: Music Gallery Editions
description: Originally created in 1979, this piece by Lubomyr Melynk-- whose work is reminiscent of Charlemagne Palestine and La Monte Young-- took the slow-changing repetitions and broad compositional structure of minimalism and made them busier, foggier, more imprecise.

title: Places Like This
label: Polyvinyl
description: More unorthodox arrangements from a diverse Australian assemblage that is able to appear at various times as a blippy dance-punk outfit, a marching band, an a capella group, a children's musical troupe, or a psychedelic commune-- sometimes all within the confines of one three-minute song.

title: Andorra
label: Merge
description: On his latest album-- and first for Merge-- Dan Snaith fully inhabits the 1960s, specifically the branch of sun-kissed pop that was aware of psychedelia but chose not to abandon the pillow-soft pleasures of AM radio, the Zombies, Free Design, the Mamas & Papas, and the Beach Boys.

title: The Last Holy Writer
label: Elefant
description: Former Field Mice member Bob Wratten returns once again with his wonderfully miserable outfit Trembling Blue Stars; their sixth album is typically consistent, with highpoints that are especially high.

title: Sleight of Hand
label: Sonic Unyon
description: Toronto band's fourth album is chiefly the vision of sometime Broken Social Scene member John Crossingham, who writes rock dreamscapes for bass, guitar, and a trio of male vocalists.

title: Under the Blacklight
label: Warner Bros.
description: Rilo Kiley return, now on a major label and boasting a sound polished like so many discotheque mirrors. It's all in good fun until you delve into the lyrics and discover that fun may be in bad faith.

title: This Is Next
label: Vice
description: Basically an ADA sampler with a promotional strategy that's at odds with those of the labels they distribute, this compilation seeks to exploit indie's recent surge in popularity while ignoring the cultural and technological shifts that have made this surge possible.

title: The Shining Path
label: Holy Mountain
description: The Shining Path

title: Roots & Echoes
label: Deltasonic
description: The latest from one of the UK's pet Proper Rock Music bands feels locked on an AM-radio dial in 1966, when soul music and paisley pop rotated alongside one another without incident.

title: Katun
label: Moribund
description: Mexican band, now a duo after the departure of two members following their 2006 debut Venganza, swings from black metal to death metal and back again.

title: On the Wing Now
label: Dim Mak
description: Filled with vast tunes that take an earnest aim at the human condition, the Los Angeles quartet's full-length debut builds on the potential of their previous two EPs while tapping a more varied array of musical influences.

title: When the Deer Wore Blue
label: Control Group
description: Danish indie band responsible for the wonderful Modest Mouse-like song "The Wonder" offers its third effort, which ostensibly covers many styles-- from garage psychedelia to pastoral pop to blues-rock-- but is remarkably static.

title: Kala
label: XL
description: Kala

title: The Lost Tracks of Danzig
label: Evilive
description: Two-disc set gathers unreleased tracks that never found a home on the theatrical metal band's proper albums; the highlights, which rank with their best material, are balanced by a healthy number of duds.

title: Get the Guests
label: Park the Van
description: Album number three from the Detroit trio finds them embracing honeyed guitar pop and moving away from garage rawness, despite the presence of White Stripes/Electric Six producer Jim Diamond.

title: Part-Monster
label: Important
description: The group's loudest and most straightforwardly songful effort yet, this album completes Piano Magic's transformation from their original status as Glen Johnson's revolving-door avant-indie "project" into a full-fledged rock band.

title: The Hair the TV the Baby & the Band
label: Merge
description: The San Fran group's first LP in over five years is a meta-album about growing old with grace that downplays the pansexual exuberance with which these indie poppers are most closely associated.

title: Challengers
label: Matador
description: Matador's all-star power poppers return with a record that's mellow mood and baritone guitar obsession mark it more as a sequel to frontman Carl Newman's solo record The Slow Wonder than the band's own Twin Cinema.

title: Turbo Fruits
label: Ecstatic Peace
description: Turbo Fruits

title: Dogs & Donkeys
label: Undertow
description: This might be the most ambitious and accessible work to date from this Sacramento-based composer and musician, who, in the past, has worked with UK singer Sharron Kraus and Charalambides' Tom Carter. Here he gets help from Wilco's Nels Cline, Low's Alan Sparhawk and Mimi Parker, and the Band's Garth Hudson.

title: Add This to Rhetoric
label: VHF
description: This collection gathers early, out-of-print 7"'s and cassettes from a band whose brainy brand of indie/punk/grunge/math could only have happened in the early 90s, yet still sounds uncannily fresh today.

title: Planet of Ice
label: Suicide Squeeze
description: After a handful of steady LPs and EPs, it seemed as if Minus the Bear were ready to take a chance or two and either come into their own and make their masterpiece or produce a true abomination. Either would have been preferred.

title: Underground Kingz
label: Jive
description: After a six-year absence that found the South become the dominant region in hip-hop, Houston legends Bun B and Pimp C sound equally frustrated and vindicated on their outstanding comeback album. Outkast, Scarface, Three 6 Mafia, Geto Boys, and Too Short are among the guests.

title: Can I Keep This Pen?
label: Ipecac
description: Third full-length from the Long Island rappers finds them singing a bit more while extolling the virtues of hybrid cars and Democratic party hopefuls; Ad-Rock from the Beastie Boys offers production assistance on two tracks.

title: Beautiful Targets
label: Tee Pee
description: Former Mercury Rev bassist Jason Russo still seems spiritually tied to his former group, using grandiose gestures to punctuate very simple emotions: namely, love and fear.

title: The Fate of Old Mother Orvis
label: Backwater
description: The latest second coming of prog sees the rise of Ipswich's uncanny fascsmilie of prog's first coming, whose second album sounds straight out of the UFO Club.

title: Oracle EP
label: Southern Lord
description: Described as an EP, this limited-edition release was inspired by a collaboration with NYC sculptor Banks Violette. The CD version adds the 46-minute "Helio)))Sophist", "an audial collage of performances in Europe from July 2005."

title: The Complete Motown Singles, Vol. 7: 1967
label: Hip-O Select
description: Hip-O Select's ongoing series of comprehensive singles collections gathers all of Motown's released A- and B-sides from 1967, as well as a few that were scheduled for release but never pressed. Where earlier volumes were liberally sprinkled with musical outliers, this one is almost terrifyingly focused on the Motown Sound, a certifiable and unmistakable aesthetic for a couple of years by this point.

title: Art Pop
label: Swim~
description: The third recording from Githead, a collaboration between Wire's Colin Newman, Robin Rimbaud (aka Scanner), and Minimal Compact's Malka Spigel, is less spare and more diverse than previous efforts Profile or the Headgit EP.

title: The Thieves of Kailua
label: Mill Pond
description: United State of Electronica contributor-- inspired by a trip to the Hawaiian islands-- creates a musicological experiment as socks-and-sandals 50th state getaway, told with the instrumental precision of a native session man.

title: Rekids Compilation One
label: Rekids
description: This celebration of the London dance imprint's first year of operation is a double-CD collection of the best material from 17 vinyl-only releases, including tracks by label head Radio Slave and Toby Tobias and remixes by Jesse Rose and Prins Thomas.

title: Late Night Tales
label: TK
description: The officially licensed chill comp meets the underground's current fascination with yacht rock, space disco, pastoral prog, Pacific Coast synth-pop, fairy folk, and perennially feted Krautrock on Hans-Peter Lindstrøm's new edition of the popular Late Night Tales series, which features tracks from Sly Stone, Dusty Springfield, Todd Rundgren, and Pitchfork's Dominique Leone.

title: Live at the Annandale Hotel
label: Absolutely Kosher
description: The Glasgow-based band, which released a handful of singles and the cult-classic LP Any Other City around the turn of the millennium, is legendary among critics, DJs, and post-punk completists, but far from an  indie household name. Hopefully this posthumous live album will act as a corrective.

title: Underhanded Romance
label: Eenie Meenie
description: Second album of would-be anthems from this San Francisco rock outfit works best when showing the band's wistful, melodic side.

title: Baby Comes Home
label: Ba Da Bing!
description: Ba Da Bing-- home of Beirut and Essie Jain-- finds its next constituent in 22-year old Lawrence, Kansas expat and Bobby Darin aspirant Patrick Cleandenim.

title: Hermaphrodite
label: Paw Tracks
description: Black Dice member's first solo album is noisy and predominantly abstract, but it also exhibits a joyful swing and pleasant ease, making it perhaps more accessible than anything from his primary band.

title: You Follow Me
label: Fat Cat
description: This deeply communicative collaboration with virtuoso drummer Jim White-- featuring  Steve Albini's stark and sinewy production-- is the most solid and striking thing Nina Nastasia has ever released.

title: We Are Him
label: Young God
description: On his sixth and arguably most engaging album as Angels of Light, former Swan Michael Gira seems more empowered and commanding than he has in a decade. Akron/Family help by providing the basic tracks, plus new friends or longtime collaborators Larkin Grimm, David Garland, and Bill Rieflin also collaborate.

title: Live in London: The BBC Recordings 1972-1973
label: Water
description: A singer-songwriter who wrote for the Turtles, Sill-- in her early 1970s heyday-- was compared to Asylum label contemporaries like Joni Mitchell, though her music had stronger spiritual overtones; this collection gathers three live radio recordings from the period.

title: Cornell 1964
artist: Charles Mingus Sextet With Eric Dolphy
label: Blue Note
description: This surprisingly high-quality recording, thought lost until discovered recently by Charles Mingus' widow, captures one of the jazz giant's finest bands at the height of its powers.

title: Total 8
label: Kompakt
description: Latest 2xCD Total compilation finds Kompakt's roster-- Superpitcher, Jürgen Paape, DJ Koze, and the usual suspects-- exploring the tactile, grotty ambience first popularized by Basic Channel and leaning too heavily on vocals.

title: Animality / Bleeding Heavens
label: Emd.pl
description: Animality / Bleeding Heavens

title: In Our Bedroom After the War
label: Arts & Crafts
description: Not out in record stores until late September, the Canadian indie pop band and its label Arts & Crafts wisely made its theatrical new album available for digital sales before it leaked.

title: Low Country Suite
label: Zoe
description: Virginia bluegrass faves settle down for something a little more comfortable even as they stretch their stylistic legs.

title: Going Places
label: Carpark
description: On his third album, French-Canadian producer Antoine Bédard makes serial collaboration sound like a good thing, working here with Stars' Amy Millan, M83, Final Fantasy, Beach House's Victoria Legrand, and Au Revoir Simone.

title: Ears Will Pop & Eyes Will Blink
label: Thousand Tongues
description: Los Angeles' Bodies of Water pummels past many more obvious/awesome points of comparison during the course of this preachtastic album-- their reverent throat-throng approach evokes a Monotheistic Spree, their anthemic exponential subchoruses harken back to that first New Pornographers record, and their rousing, art-pop-rock-alyptic ambition suggests the Arcade Fire.

title: Structure & Cosmetics
label: Sub Pop
description: New Zealand indie pop outfit follows tours with the Shins, Rilo Kiley, and Clap Your Hands Say Yeah with its Sub Pop debut, an accomplished, sonically detailed work of baroque pop.

title: Colossal Youth and Collected Works
label: Rough Trade
description: The latest reissue of this fantastic and bracing artifact is a 3xCD model, augmented with the other extant YMG studio recordings (and fascinating Simon Reynolds liner notes).

title: Keren Ann
label: Blue Note
description: On her self-titled, fifth album, Keren Ann crafts the spirit-- or spiritlessness-- of drowsy pessimism into a ragged, shadowy baroque, where songs may tumble in over harmonicas or drift off with a choir.

title: Space & Time
artist: Miss Alex White & the Red Orchestra
label: In the Red
description: Chicago garage rock linchpin unleashes her second In the Red album with an ear for the masters and a gutsy enthusiasm that compensates for any lack of creativity.

title: Space Ritual: Collector's Edition
label: United Artists
description: Crucial reissue from a band whose disorienting electronic drones and motorik rhythms were akin to their Krautrock contemporaries, but who also could make a racket as unrelentingly punchy and violent as anything from the Stooges' Fun House.

title: Set the Woods on Fire
label: Saddle Creek
description: Azure Ray's Orenda Fink embarks on a new chapter in her career: A new six-piece Saddle Creek band playing smoke-filled alt-rock and country pastiche.

title: The Hottest State OST
label: Hickory
description: The soundtrack to the film adaptation of an Ethan Hawke novel, this record features Bright Eyes, Feist, Norah Jones, M. Ward, Cat Power, Willie Nelson, and others-- all performings songs written by Jesse Harris. Your mom will love it.

title: Lady Croissant
label: Astralwerks
description: The Australian chanteuse-- who has three times enjoyed brushes with fame, thanks to 2002's Healing Is Difficult, soundtracking the final moments of "Six Feet Under", and her work with Zero 7-- issues a live mini-album.

title: Bad Football
label: Off
description: Second album from Robert Pollard and former Guided by Voices bassist Chris Slusarenko is remarkably consistent for a post-GbV side project; guests include Stephen Malkmus and Tad Doyle.

title: We Are Ever So Clean
label: Marmalade
description: Sunbeam reissues the work of the twee-est band of all time, a record on which virtually every song here can trace its DNA to the Beatles' "Penny Lane"/"Strawberry Fields Forever" single.

title: Ape-ology
label: Trojan
description: This Trojan package features reissues of Black Ark classics Roast Fish, Collie Weed & Cornbread and Super Ape, along with Return of the Super Ape and seven related bonus tracks.

title: Sojourner
label: Secretly Canadian
description: This 4xCD/1xDVD set comes packaged in a wooden container with popcorn-bag-style sleeves, postcard tracklists, and even a pewter medallion. Oh, the music: It culls tracks from the four recording sessions that fed Jason Molina's 2006 album, Fading Trails, and yet, these generous odds and ends make for a better listening experience than the release for which they were intended.

title: Fascinating Tininess
label: Eastern Developments
description: Atlanta-to-New York duo's debut is thick with beats, dense electronic production, and the rich vocals of Laurel Wells; label boss Guillermo Scott Herren, working under his Savath & Savalas alias, cameos.

title: The Shapes We Make
label: Kill Rock Stars
description: Former Helium singer again teams with Medications drummer Devin Ocampo, and they are joined by bassist Chad Molter on this delightful full-band effort.

title: New High & Ord
label: Load
description: On their Load Records debut, this L.A. outfit sometimes sounds like a skewed version of James Chance's Contortions, had that band been weaned on the SST and Dischord catalogues.

title: Walls
label: Bpitch Control
description: Berlin's Sascha Ring-- fresh off his fantastic collaboration with Ellen Allien, Orchestra of Bubbles-- mixes dutiful pop tracks in amongst a group of songs that comes across like an electronic dream-pop record worthy of M83, Slowdive, Junior Boys, and Schneider TM.

title: Share This Place: Stories and Observations
label: K
description: A multimedia project commissioned by the Portland Institute for Contemporary Art and the Seattle International Children's Festival, comprised of the songs contained herein and accompanying stop-motion video by Britta Johnson, Mirah's new record was inspired in part by the writings of French entomologist Jean Henri Fabré and the Capek brothers' anthropomorphic drama The Insect Play.

title: American Nervoso
label: Hydra Head
description: Pacific Northwest post-hardcore band included members who went on to Minus the Bear and These Arms are Snakes; reissue of this 1998 full-length adds demos and alternate versions.

title: Back Up Vol. 01
label: Mobilee
description: A DJ mix from Berlin surveys house and techno from new angles with old views-- and vice versa.

title: The Trials of Darryl Hunt OST
label: Young American
description: This hodgepodge of new tracks, live performances, and even an album track or two collects music "from and inspired by" the theatrical documentary; it's also a benefit compilation for the Darryl Hunt Foundation, which works for wrongfully convicted prisoners, and it features M. Ward, Andrew Bird, Clap Your Hands Say Yeah, Califone, and Dead Prez's Sticman.

title: Those the Brokes
label: Astralwerks
description: Astralwerks rescue the UK coffeehouse-ready quartet from potential U.S. label limbo, and the band repays them with a slimmed-down version of the late 2006 album.

title: The Stage Names
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Musicians' lives don't naturally translate to compelling movies, but in the right hands, they can make for powerful albums. On Okkervil River's autobiographical fourth full-length-- their most emotionally devastating yet-- frontman Will Sheff masters both self-reflexivity and twisted confessionalism while his band ramps up to an unhinged aggressiveness that was only hinted at on previous releases.

title: An Ethereal Oracle
label: Permanent Records
description: The second record from Missouri's Warhammer 48K-- and first for new Chicago label and store Permanent Records-- is every bit an apocalypse record, right down to its art-punk undercurrents and political overtones.

title: High Places EP
label: Ancient Almanac
description: High Places EP

title: An Electric Storm
label: Island
description: White Noise's landmark 1969 album*--* recorded in the months immediately prior to the widespread availability of keyboard-based synthesizers, making it one of the most painstakingly crafted electronic recordings of all time-- is finally given its proper due on this Island reissue.

title: Now-Again Re:Sounds Vol. 1
label: Now Again
description: Now-Again Records, the brainchild of onetime vinyl hoarder/Stones Throw manager/Funky 16 Corners compiler Eothen "Egon" Alapatt, here lets ST artists such as Koushik and Percee P loose on the best of its reissue catalog.

title: The Simpsons Movie: The Music
label: Adrenaline
description: Former Ultravox/Buggles keyboardist and current Hollywood film bigshot Hans Zimmer gets the call to score the Simpsons Movie. Meanwhile, Alf Clausen-- longtime composer of all original music for "The Simpsons"-- has probably fired his agent.

title: Axiom
label: Tee Pee
description: Former Bomp! band makes a marked effort to steer away from obvious touchstones on its latest record, a change from the heavy-handed homages that permeated 2005's Meditations.

title: Pebbles
label: Soft Abuse
description: New Zealander Stefan Neville crafts what is essentially an Xpressway tribute album, recalling the primal rock of This Kind of Punishment, Alastair Galbraith, and the Dead C.

title: While My Guitar Violently Bleeds
label: Locust
description: Sun City Girls leader's solo acoustic guitar work has focused more on craft than on innovation, and While My Guitar Violently Bleeds displays an impressive amount of skill.

title: Big Science
label: Warner Bros.
description: It was ahead of its time back in 1982, but now Laurie Anderson's debut (and especially its centerpiece "O Superman") sounds just right for a world gone totally wrong.

title: Werewolves and Lollipops
label: Sub Pop
description: One of the Comedians of Comedy-- and now a full-fledged animated film star thanks to his lead voice role in Ratatouille-- Patton Oswalt demonstrates how to make a comedy CD hold up over multiple listens on this Sub Pop release.

title: Underground Communication
label: OM
description: The Bay Area granola-celeb DJ releases his second album, full of intrusive subwoofer-rattling beats, vaguely-defined countercultural politics and attempts at 90s-style raptronica.

title: I Put a Record On
label: Monika
description: A fixture in Berlin's underground art and music scenes for roughly a quarter-century, Gudrun Gut finally issues a proper solo LP, a record that features her Marlene Dietrich-style purr and smeary, grayscale hazes of techno and dub.

title: Florist Fired
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Marmoset-- one of Secretly Canadian's first and finest discoveries-- finally follows its excellent 2001 album Record in Red with a new full length, albeit culled from sessions dating back to late 2003.

title: Hey Trouble
label: Licking Fingers
description: The Swedish indie pop group's third proper album-- and first without Victoria Bergsman-- greets head-on the group's legacy of Jesus & Mary Chain swirl and sashaying girl-group sweetness.

title: The Colour and the Shape [10th Anniversary Special Edition]
label: Capitol
description: Perfectly timed to herald modern rock radio's sea-change shift from grunge's roar to emo's wail, this double platinum release enjoys a 10th anniversary reissue with the addition of six B-sides.

title: Heartland
label: Metropolis
description: Now a trio, Client continue to craft chilly, elegant electro-pop that's poised and businesslike, full of hooks, and tries to conjure feelings of luxury and efficiency.

title: Dödsvisioner
label: Hydra Head
description: On his second album and first for his U.S. label Hydra Head, Sweden's Pär Gustafsson displays a debt to American metal stars such as Xasthur and Lurker of Chalice, as well as any number of Scandinavian hard rock aueturs.

title: I'm Your Man
label: Goner
description: Memphis singer/songwriter's second album is all over the place, with muddy guitar rock, acoustic folk in the Leonard Cohen vein, and hell-bent country that pours some out for Townes Van Zandt.

title: ¿Spicchiology?
label: Important
description: American shock-poppers Xiu Xiu and Italian post-rockers Larsen collaborate for a record that doesn't feel radically different than their XXL debut, Ciautistico!,  but does seem more developed.

title: Insound Tour Support 2.0
label: Insound
description: Insound resurrects its tour support series with this 10-track compilation of radio sessions, acoustic tracks, and live performances from the Portland punk band.

title: Wires Reply
label: St. Ives
description: Laptop pop band returns after a four-year hiatus and here they recall Midwestern peers the Flaming Lips, the Minus Story, and even Sparklehorse, with impassioned, effeminate melodies struggling against waves of washed-out keyboards and clamoring percussion.

title: The Inspiring New Sounds of Rio de Janeiro
label: Verge Records
description: Wide-ranging collection of bands and styles that spans twitching hip-hop to sunny funk-rock, crazed dub, and driving neo-samba.

title: Dr. No's Oxperiment
label: Stones Throw
description: After two solid solo albums, Madlib's younger brother hits paydirt with an unusual premise: An instrumental hip-hop record built entirely from samples of Mediterranean psychedelia.

title: Bishop Allen & the Broken String
label: Dead Oceans
description: The band's first LP since 2003's Charm School adds studio sheen to nine songs from their 2006 EP-a-month project, with three new-ish efforts to boot.  Paul Simon is clearly Bishop's patron saint, but is their bow-tie merely a camera?

title: Finding Forever
label: Geffen
description: Common and Kanye West continue the sound of 2005's solid comeback Be with a follow-up that attempts to inject it with a bit of Dilla-fied Soulquarians style.

title: Nothing Much and Something More
label: Minus
description: The prized minimal-techno label run by Richie Hawtin files a status report from the front lines of Berlin.

title: Forts
label: Gigantic
description: Former Brooklynites are now based in Berlin; here on their third album, which includes contributions from fellow transplant Julian Gross of Liars, they scrape away surface grime and put the emphasis on rhythm.

title: Cookies
label: Rough Trade
description: John McKeown spent the actual 90s in Glasgow's Yummy Fur, along with Paul Thomson and Alex Kapranos, who later went on to Franz Ferdinand. He's back with a new band and he's ready to party.

title: The Con
label: Vapor
description: The sisters Quin here craft a record reminiscent of 1980s power-pop, rounded with bubbly keyboard squeals and songs about relationships. Chris Walla (Death Cab for Cutie) serves as co-producer.

title: Marry Me
label: Beggars Banquet
description: Sidewoman to the stars (well, Sufjan Stevens and the Polyphonic Spree, at least) Annie Clark steps into the spotlight for her St. Vincent debut, with results so inventive and impressive you wonder what took her so long.

title: Noble Creatures
label: Yep Roc
description: Tenth album from the Austin quintet best known for a novelty cover of "Gin and Juice" finds the band moving past bluegrass as an endpoint and using the genre as a base for forays into other sounds and styles.

title: Unbeast the Leash
label: Monitor
description: Band affiliated with Baltimore's Wham City collective uses melodic pop-punk riffs wrapped in toylike synths and effects pedals to express an uncanny melancholy.

title: Feil Knapp
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: Norwegian songwriter and producer's excellent, Smalltown Supersound-issued debut is crisp, bright, airy, and shot through with light.

title: Fantastic Playroom
label: Modular
description: Though saddled with the latest tagline for 1981 nostalgia, new-rave, New Young Pony Club turn out a record that is meticulous and comfortable in its genre-specific craft, and excellent for it.

title: Deadverse Massive Vol. 1: Dälek Rarities 1999-2006
label: Hydra Head
description: The New Jersey duo's first collection of rarities and remixes reaches across six years to place two unreleased cuts alongside material from five out-of-print splits and a remix from Enon's In This City EP.

title: Introducing Kenge Kenge
label: World Music Network
description: Kenyan group works in the rhythm-driven benga style but steers the music away from non-native influences, creating hypnotic music designed for dancing that also tells a story.

title: Time On Earth
label: ATO
description: Australian band returns after a 14-year hiatus, picking up where it left off, buoyed as usual by Neil Finn's brilliant and beautiful songwriting.

title: Super Taranta!
label: SideOneDummy
description: Self-proclaimed "gypsy punks" offer another disc of eclectic, breakneck rock that's as exhausting to listen to as it must be to play.

title: War Stories
label: Surrender All
description: James Lavelle offers his most traditional, rock-oriented release yet, collaborating here with Palm Desert sonic mastermimd Chris Goss. Queens of the Stone Age's Josh Homme, Cult singer (and sometime Jim Morrison stand-in) Ian Astbury, and Massive Attack's 3D all guest.

title: What Is Free to a Good Home? EP
label: Last Gang
description: This five-song follow-up to last year's overlooked Knives Don't Have Your Back is a wonderfully singular work that proves the Metric leader and Broken Social Scene member can flourish outside of the constraints of collaboration.

title: Lion the Girl
label: New Line
description: L.A. band's second release adds a new drummer, bassist, and producer Steve Fisk to the decks for an effects-heavy, gauzy torrent of psych rock and punk remnants.

title: Moonlight Farm
label: De Stijl
description: This record-- created by a sugar beet farmer from Landskrona, Sweden and originally issued on vinyl last year-- beautifully evokes the best of the acid-folk private press.

title: Fancy Footwork
label: Vice
description: Follow-up to 2004's She's in Control again finds the electro-pop duo successfully mining the 80s for inspiration, incorporating talk boxes, 808s, canned percussion, and Prince-style atmospherics.

title: Emerald City
label: Barsuk
description: As with its predecessor, 2005's Pixel Revolt, nearly half of the tracks on this new John Vanderslice album make mention of, or allude to, the World Trade Center attacks, while the rest of the songs are awash in the debris and carnage from the tragedy and its aftermath.

title: Is Is EP
label: Fiction
description: This EP collects newly recorded songs written in 2004 between the Yeah Yeah Yeahs' 2003 debut Fever to Tell and their 2006 follow-up, Show Your Bones, and as such is more reminiscent of the raw danger of the group's debut than its patient follow-up.

title: New Wave
label: Sire
description: Self-professed anarchists and DIY devotees jump to a major label with this Butch Vig-produced record.

title: Atomic Yggdrasil Tarot
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The legendary, bountifully bearded Lungfish leader's swift follow-up to last year's Ancestral Songs continues the earlier's outer-space crunk transmissions. The disc also comes beautifully packaged with a 48-page hardcover book depicting a series of Higgs' totemic paintings and acrostics.

title: Eccentric Soul: The Prix Label
label: Numero Group
description: Another trawl through a forgotten Midwestern soul label's dusty archives-- this time the Columbus, Ohio, imprint Prix-- and once again the Numero Group unearths some lost classics.

title: Absolute Garbage
label: Geffen
description: One of the more distinctive bands to emerge from mid-90s modern rock cobbles together its best-known tracks for this terribly titled compilation.

title: Planet Earth
label: Sony
description: So far this year Prince has wowed at the Super Bowl, returned to First Avenue for the first time in decades, and gave this album away in UK newspapers. Unfortunately, his new music is unlikely to generate as much conversation.

title: Aelita
label: Morr
description: Markus Acher's recordings with Tied & Tickled Trio generally begin in improvisation and end in careful arrangement, and Aelita is no exception, working with xylophone, glockenspiel, and mellotron to aim for a record of movement, suspense, and heady atmosphere.

title: Streams
label: Fusetron
description: This two-disc set distills 30-odd hours of 36 podcasts the Brooklyn band recorded and released for free between 2003 and 2006.

title: All the Birds Were Anarchists
label: Mosz
description: Trio of Barbara Morgenstern, Stefan Schneider, and Paul Wirkus creates electronic music that alternates improvisation with a more robust structure of composed melody and songcraft.

title: The Freed Man
label: Homestead
description: The expanded reissue of Lou Barlow and Eric Gaffney's Sebadoh debut now features 52 tracks (up from 32), turning something once familiar into a gargantuan 79-minute lo-fi opera.

title: Sticking Fingers Into Sockets EP
label: Arts & Crafts
description: Cardiff-based band that idolizes North American indie has its infectious debut EP -- which features a Pavement cover-- produced by Broken Social Scene's Dave Newfeld. The result is superbly crafted indie pop that brings to mind Love Is All, Deerhoof, and Bow Wow Wow.

title: Burning Off Impurities
label: Temporary Residence
description: Globally-minded Portland band's instrumental rock takes the scenic route, journeying from the Middle East to an Italian vision of the Old West while making some intriguing stops along the way.

title: The Great Koonaklaster Speaks: A John Fahey Celebration
label: Table of the Elements
description: The fourth tribute to guitarist John Fahey released in the last 16 months turns out to be the best, as artists like Jack Rose, Lichens, and Pumice gather to offer original tracks that speak to the man's influence.

title: Men's Needs, Women's Needs, Whatever
label: Warner Bros.
description: The UK band follows its 2005 Edwyn Collins-produced breakthrough The New Fellas with a major-label debut helmed by Franz Ferdinand's Alex Kapranos and mixed by alt-rock heavyweight Andy Wallace-- and it features perhaps the unlikeliest indie-celeb cameo since Laetitia Sadier showed up on a Common album.

title: Silent Shout Deluxe Edition
label: Mute
description: Silent Shout Deluxe Edition

title: Death of the Sun
label: Dicristina
description: Death of the Sun

title: Nu-Med
label: JDub
description: Founded by drummer/programmer Tamir Muskat and woodwind player and former Gogol Bordello member Ori Kaplan, Balkan Beat Box adds its name to the ever-lengthening list of groups drawing inspiration from Eastern European sounds while rigorously avoiding sounding traditional.

title: Lucas
artist: Skeletons and the Kings of All Cities
label: Ghostly
description: Leader Matt Mehlan's Girl-Faced Boys are now Kings of All Cities, and Lucas is a tangled tale of intriguing outsiders building a place of their own.

title: 5 Years Get Physical
label: Get Physical
description: German dance label Get Physical-- which helped usher this decade's move from electro-house to minimal-- celebrates its fifth anniversary with a 2xCD set-- one of new tracks from the label roster and the other a set of remixes, including efforts by Herbert, the Rapture, Moby, Señor Coconut, and Fujiya & Miyagi.

title: An End Has a Start
label: Fader
description: Big-selling post-punk revivalists from Birmingham, England return with a more theatrical second album, their sound sometimes approaching the arena-filling grandeur of U2.

title: Rise to Your Knees
label: Anodyne
description: This unlikely comeback album strikes a fairly comfortable balance between the spare, spritely Meat Puppets of yore and the more polished and forceful Meat Puppets of the mid-1990s.

title: Dance Positive
label: Marriage
description: Picking up where his previous full-length Beneath Waves left off, Dance Positive features Blau putting his unique spin on 10 D+ songs penned by Bret Lunsford, running them through a gauntlet of stylistic and experimental mettle.

title: Keep Reachin' Up
label: Light in the Attic
description: Third solo album for a singer who spent much of the 90s dropping guest vocals for The The, Deee-lite, Leftfield and other acts, and it's soul music with decidedly classic-sounding arrangements and production, mature compositions, and ingenius string orchestration.

title: New Waves EP
label: Sincerely Yours
description: Swedish pop band spikes its shiny digital beats to vaguely tropical synths, sugar-sweet melodies, and-- like a modern-day Malcolm McLaren or KLF-- Situationist politics, so much so that it's difficult to separate the music from the group's broader arsenal of cultural weaponry

title: The Singles, Volume Three: 1964-1965
label: Hip-O Select
description: Latest volume of Hip-O's mail-order-only complete-JB-singles series consists of both barrel-scraping and three of Brown's biggest hits, including at least one song that pretty much transformed all pop music after it.

title: UFOs at the Zoo: The Legendary Concert in Oklahoma City
label: Warner Bros.
description: The Flaming Lips' first live document.

title: Still Alive
label: Anticon
description: First solo album in eight years from the Maine producer brings back the sound of the trip-hopping 90s.

title: Idealism
label: Astralwerks
description: After a spate of singles, including early releases on Daft Punk-loving French imprint Kitsuné, this Hamburg house-rock duo pulls together work new and old for their first album.

title: Efdemin
label: Dial
description: Debut solo album from Phillip Sollmann-- who is also a member of the duo Pigon-- revels in the swift attack, fat decay, and lingering tail of struck instruments, whether real or synthesized.

title: Saturday Night Fever
label: Rhino
description: To celebrate its 30th anniversary, Rhino reissues the classic soundtrack, the most popular document of the disco era.

title: The Else
label: Idlewild
description: Recent converts to children's rock, Johns Linnell and Flansburgh here go somewhat gracefully into their middle ages by recalling their tighter, tauter early days, when they were closer to Devo than Elmo.

title: The Midnight Room
label: Sub Pop
description: Italian explorers have the psychedelic references to go with the band name inspired by Syd Barrett, but ultimately aim for a more hermetic and claustrophobic sound.

title: At My Age
label: Yep Roc
description: The one-time Jesus of Cool continues his quest to chill out.

title: Extricate/Shift-Work/Code: Selfish
label: Fontana
description: Three albums originally released on Fontana in the early 1990s are reissued with the usual assortment of bonus tracks and b-sides, offering a deeper look at one of the iconic band's least-examined periods.

title: The Friends EP
label: Chocodog
description: Hoping to whet appetites for their first full-length in four years, Ween releases a five-song set including tongue-in-cheek stabs at Hi-NRG dance-pop, reggae, and new romantic balladry.

title: Family Tree
label: Tsunami
description: This 28-track collection of lo-fi home recordings-- many of which have been available on bootlegs for years-- was produced on a reel-to-reel at Drake's parent's estate, recorded on cassette while Drake was studying in Aix En Provence, France, or made in conjunction with other members of the late singer-songwriter's family.

title: Storyteller & the Gossip Columnist
label: Greyday
description: On his second full-length, Portland-based Krist Krueger writes songs about the thirst for experience, fleshing out his lyrical ideas with orchestral flourishes and bent structures.

title: In Camera
label: Hardly Art
description: The inaugural release for Sub Pop's new imprint, Hardly Art, this indie pop album is somehow both wide-eyed and indebted to 60s folk-pop as well as weird, druggy, and mesmerizing. In Camera's throbbing guitars, muted vocals, and mawkish arrangements sound more like the Velvet Underground and Nico (or Karen Dalton, or Serge Gainsbourg) than anything you'd ever dig up on Twee.net.

title: Sirens of the Ditch
label: New West
description: First solo record by former member of Drive-By Truckers dips into heavy Southern rock riffage but leans more toward soul and acoustic singer/songwriter territory.

title: Ga Ga Ga Ga Ga
label: Merge
description: The Austin band, which has cultivated an intense fan base while continuing to experiment, do so again here; this record finds band leader Britt Daniel and producer/drummer Jim Eno's tendencies toward studio-based devilry coming full-flower, each listen revealing craftsmen reveling in detail.

title: Goodbye
label: Domino
description: Goodbye

title: Sacchrilege EP
label: Lex
description: Tight, relatively straightforward EP culminates Bryan Hollon's seven-year transition from pandemonium to order.

title: In Dub
label: Lo
description: The mysterious Black Devil Disco Club stretches out their unlikely comeback by enlisting some remix help that brings the music up to date without robbing them of their retro-futuristic kitsch appeal.

title: Promised Works
label: Touch and Go
description: Two out-of print EPs from Brian McMahan's atmospheric post-Slint outfit are reissued on one disc by Touch and Go, offering another chance to hear this unfairly overlooked band.

label: Cooking Vinyl
description: Pixies leader cherrypicks the best sounds from his first nine solo albums, plus adds a bonus disc of recently recorded live versions of newer material.

title: Our Love to Admire
label: Capitol
description: After the tight, familiar turns of 2004's Antics and a major label deal, these dapper NYC rockers' lofty aspirations are finally kicking in. Horns, extended outros, strings, an oboe, and album art featuring more than three colors-- welcome to the new world of Interpol.

title: Burn Your Own Church
label: Playlouderrecordings
description: French dance act-- in the biggest year for French dance acts in a decade-- reacts to the significant departure of founder Ivan Smagghe by bulking to an actual instruments-and-all band.

title: Inventions for the New Season
label: Orchard
description: Chops-heavy instrumental band from Athens, Ga., with new drummer Gerhardt Fuchs of !!! and the Juan MacLean, releases its third full-length.

title: Crystal Healing
label: Three Lobed
description: Tantilizing drone figures and ghostly melodies from an abstract folk project including members of Double Leopards, Vanishing Voice, and Magik Markers.

title: Duet for Guitars #2
label: Ow Om
description: M. Ward's first album finally gets reissued, and fans will likely enjoy discovering (or rediscovering) the songwriter's not surprising but surprisingly solid roots.

title: Zeitgeist
label: Reprise
description: A comeback of sorts, the only actual reunion taking place here is between Billy Corgan and his most famous brand; drummer Jimmy Chamberlin was already involved in both of Corgan's post-Pumpkins projects, and James Iha/D'Arcy preferred to stay in hiding.

title: Excerpts from the Broken Bone Choir
label: self-released
description: Former members of the Black Water and Sky Burial release a remastered set of shoegaze-y, gothic dirges.

title: Lose All Time
label: Paper Bag
description: Album number two from aggro-new wavers sheds a few exclamation points and exhibits signs of maturity, but still retains its share of explosive basslines and nifty hooks.

title: Let's Drag Our Feet
label: Magic Marker
description: Seattle trio's second album is a guitar-heavy collection of family snapshots and pretty, lo-fi messes.

title: Best of Bowie: 1980-1987
label: EMI
description: This third installment of this budget-comp series starts with selections from his last "1970s" record, Scary Monsters, before picking highlights from David Bowie's chart-aiming 80s work.

title: Rushup Edge EP
label: Rephlex
description: Strongly believed to be a new project authored at least in part-- and probably completely-- by Richard D. James, aka the Aphex Twin, this certainly sounds like a continuation of and expansion upon the ground covered two years ago with dogged thoroughness on the 11-volume Analord series.

title: Well Well Well
label: O'Brothers
description: Chicago power-pop band-- centered around a trio of multi-instrumentalist brothers-- craft well-executed songs, rarely pushing the envelope much further than the conceits that Cheap Trick are godhead and the pre-Village Green Preservation Society Kinks could've used a few more volts in 'em.

title: Plastic Bag in the Tree
label: Hush
description: Loose instrumental project from Decemberists' Chris Funk effectively combines dusty wagon trail stateliness with extraterrestrial blips and squiggles.

title: Octopus
label: Astralwerks
description: Melting down the 1960s and 70s and pressing them into something new, this English band's third full-length is an engaging collection of modern psych-pop.

title: The Blue Thumb Recordings
label: Hip-O Select
description: The late Arthur Lee's eclecticism is on display on this 3xCD collection, which features two of his band's post-peak LPs, Out Here and False Start, plus a disc of live performances recorded in England in 1970.

title: T.I. vs. T.I.P.
label: Atlantic
description: The follow-up to King-- one of 2006's best rap albums-- works on the thin and dubious concept that T.I. the businessman and T.I.P. the unreformed hustler are two completely different entities, and that the strain of balancing the two personas is enough to tear Clifford Joseph Harris Jr. apart.

title: On the Plains
label: Range Life
description: Kansas native Brendan Hangauer is a hopelessly romantic Midwestern kid who likes to party and address last night's regrets in fleet verses and big, grinning choruses.

title: Amateur
label: Rune Grammofon
