description: This often excellent Norwegian duo's fifth album features numerous tracks made using instruments neither member knows how to play, an oddly fitting approach for a couple of guys who often explore the intersection between the electronic and the acoustic.

title: Au
label: Aagoo
description: Portland's Luke Wyland, with the help of some friends, makes an engaging  avant-folk album inspired by the taken-for-granted elements of the natural world.

title: What Is?!
label: Hazelwood
description: With a musty vintage charm and spiky sense of humor this Montreal-based guitar punk band is-- along with Icky Thump, Black Lips, Jay Reatard, and the solo work of King Khan collaborator Mark Sultan-- breathing life back into good old fashioned rock'n'roll.

title: Grow Up and Blow Away
label: Last Gang
description: Metric's lost debut of sorts, recorded between 1999 and 2001, gives us a chance to get to know them more intimately-- as a charming singer/songwriterly band poised to arrive a little too late for the 1990s alterna-rock boom, when they would have fit in snugly with bubble-poppers, like Letters to Cleo, and scorers of imaginary films, like Self.

title: Anonymous
label: Ipecac
description: Underground supergroup featuring Mike Patton, Duane Dension (Jesus Lizard), and John Stanier (Helmet, Battles) ditches freak-metal for a record that interprets Native American compositions.

title: Radio Moscow
label: Alive
description: Hook- and riff-filled guitar rock band has its debut record produced by Black Keys member Dan Auerbach.

title: Starvation Under Orange Trees
label: Howells Transmitter
description: Jon Berrnson's third album fronting Ray's Vast Basement seems in the vein of Bruce Springsteen the storyteller, right down to its last period detail.

title: The Cloud of Unknowing
label: Tompkins Square
description: This is a long-overdue gift for fans of acoustic guitar music; Blackshaw-- growing into his prodigious own at the startling age of 25-- has finessed his abilities and 12-string acoustic guitar into a veritable solo symphony, schooled equally in complex 20th century composition and uncommon beauty.

title: We Are the Night
label: Astralwerks
description: Despite their innovative 90s repertoire, the Chemical Brothers have spent much of this decade keeping pace. Now, sporting guest spots from Klaxons, Midlake, Fatlip, and Willy Mason, they return with their sixth album.

title: Drawing Voices
label: Hydra Head
description: Aaron Turner from Isis meets Craig Dongoski for a conceptual project in which sounds created in the act of drawing are processed into modulating drones.

title: Spider Smile
label: Morr
description: More sour-sounding sonics from the Berlin duo, this time addressing American-style high society and decadence.

title: The Boy With No Name
label: Sony
description: The melodramatic Glaswegians return, with Nigel Godrich in tow, for their first album since 2003's iffy 12 Memories.

title: Hymns for a Dark Horse
label: Burly Time
description: North Carolina duo's debut album will likely garner loads of comparisons to Devendra Banhart and Vetiver, but this brand of folk is more Appalachian than British and less concerned with psychedelia than melody.

title: Dylanesque
label: Virgin
description: Former Roxy Music singer-- long adept at transforming other people's material, e.g his fantastic take on Bob Dylan's "A Hard Rain's A-Gonna Fall"-- here attempts an entire record of Dylan covers.

title: We the Best
label: Koch
description: Second album from Miami hip-hop figurehead, packed once again with posse cuts including verses from Lil Wayne, T.I. and Fat Joe, falls far short of its predecessor.

title: The Flowers of Hell
label: P&C
description: Symphonic rock project features members of the Early Years, Tindersticks, and British Sea Power as well as production assistance from Sonic Boom.

title: Tied & True
label: Bloodshot
description: Bar band from the D with a flair for imaginative covers tackles songs by Irma Thomas, Bettye Lavette, the Cookies, the Flirtations, and the Equals.

title: Open Field
label: Rough Trade
description: Solo debut from former Concretes singer Victoria Bergsman is co-produced by one of her "Young Folks" collaborators, Björn Yttling, and features a track written by Camera Obscura's Tracyanne Campbell.

title: Build a Nation
label: Megaforce
description: The seminal hardcore band issues its first comeback under its true name since 1995's forgettable God of Love. Beastie Boys' Adam Yauch produces.

title: Colour It In
label: Geffen
description: Meet England's hot new things, same as the old hot new things.

title: Compass Rose Bouquet
label: Quack
description: Michiganders with an historical bent manage hooks that occasionally scrape the Shins/New Pornographers stratosphere of catchiness.

title: My Ion Truss
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Midwestern group's third full-length release on Jagjaguwar and their fifth overall finds them finally entering the studio with a bona fide producer (John Congleton, who has worked with Explosions in the Sky and the Polyphonic Spree). The result is their most vibrant and full-bodied rock album to date.

title: Phantom Limb
label: Relapse
description: Grindcore band makes a strong pitch for the Metal Album of the Year honors with a record that's such a quantum leap even beyond Pig Destroyer's earlier, already pretty fuckin' awesome records that it might as well represent a quantum leap for the whole goddamn genre.

title: Tennessee Fire & At Dawn Demos / Mont de Sundua
label: Darla
description: My Morning Jacket fans are given a glimpse into the creation of the band's first two albums on Darla Records' long-delayed Tennessee Fire and At Dawn Demos, while the Removador label reissues recordings from Jim James' pre-MMJ band.

title: Pick Up Sticks
label: Kill Rock Stars
description: Vancouver collective has a unique sound-- an all-out large band assault with a lurching, dissonant quality that accentuates its busyness and density.

title: Gentleman on the Rocks
label: CoCo Art
description: Two members of defunct emo group Jet By Day reinvent themselves for a sonically pretty collection of guitar-based pop and rock that is strongest at its most hodge-podge. Orenda Fink of Azure Ray, Dan McCarthy (Tilly and the Wall, Bright Eyes), and Jacob Thiele of the Faint guest.

title: Bumps
label: Stones Throw
description: Tortoise's three percussionists aim to pull off a half hour's worth of only rhythmic material on this, a breakbeat record of sorts issued by Stones Throw.

title: Intermission: The Best of the Solo Recordings 1990-1997
label: Beggars Banquet
description: Nearly unequalled in partnership, Go-Betweens songwriters Robert Forster and the late Grant McLennan managed to squeeze in equally strong solo careers when they weren't working together. This double-disc from Beggars Banquet collects some of their best material, recording while the Go-Betweens were on hold.

title: The Mix-Up
label: Capitol
description: Adam Yauch, Mike D, and Adam Horovitz are joined by longtime keyboardist Money Mark and percussionist Alfredo Ortiz on their first all-instrumental non-compilation full-length.

title: We Are All Hopeful Farmers, We Are All Scared Rabbits
label: Xeric
description: This time the revolving cast of experimentalists centered around Ben Chasny and former Deerhoof member Rob Fisk includes Tom Carter of Charalambides and Glenn Donaldson of Jewelled Antler collective, among others.

title: Mi Sueño
label: Nonesuch
description: The Cuban singing legend's final album is a collection of boleros, a song form he'd only attempted on record once before.

title: Honigpumpe
label: Kompakt
description: A storied electronic-music veteran makes a strong case for late-period resurrection on another new classic for the German techno label Kompakt.

title: Desire
label: Interscope
description: This long-delayed sophomore album is a best-of-both-worlds record that combines a backpacker's sense of social justice and overclocked verbiage with a mainstream star's outsized charisma and furious delivery.

title: Easy Tiger
label: Lost Highway
description: More consistent and of higher quality than much of Ryan Adams' recent output-- 2002's Demolition, 2003 twofer Rock N Roll and Love Is Hell, and 2005's 29-- the prolific singer/songwriter's latest has a sonic landscape that makes any room feel oh so tastefully arranged, like an overpriced bar a few punks still go to anyway.

title: Cue
label: Kranky
description: Experimental electronic musician here is inspired by "library" records, taking descriptions of the intended effect for various tracks, building new tracks, and attempting to arrive at the same moods from other angles.

title: The Scenery of Farewell EP
label: Saddle Creek
description: The Saddle Creek duo, recently a lightning rod for controversy, return with a record of acoustic tracks recorded at sound checks and radio appearances.

title: Collective Psychosis Begone
label: Misra
description: Debut album from a very promising Misra band clearly inclined toward the bookish end of the musical spectrum. Hallelujah's ensemble structure and learned lyricism echoes the stage-packing sounds of Arcade Fire, Danielson, Bright Eyes, and the Decemberists.

title: Playtime Is Over
label: Big Dada
description: If this really is the grime producer's swan song, * Playtime Is Over* caps off Wiley's career in a low-profile fashion, considering that the progression he's taken since he dropped the "Eskimo" riddim on an unsuspecting underground in 2002 can be measured in inches.

title: After Dark
label: Italians Do It Better
description: Possessed by a genuine love of classic dark electro and vintage electronics, the new Italians Do It Better label reimagines the Italo-disco of the 1970s and 80s as stark, retro-futurist noir electro. Sparse, skeletal, and consumed by a constant sense of creeping dread, After Dark is the sleek soundtrack to lives of moral ambiguity in post-urban shadows. Rising stars Glass Candy, the Chromatics, and Mirage appear.

title: Fantastic Hawk
label: Absolutely Kosher
description: Bedroom auteur Eli Simon ditches his Guided By Voices-like lo-fi aesthetic-- best realized on 2005's overlooked Holiday Machine EP-- for a full-studio approach.

title: Buried Treasure
label: Offshore
description: Latest comp from Offshore, which continues to be among both the most inventive purveyors of 21st century drum'n'bass-- techno-tinged percussion that splits the difference between groove and experimentalism-- and one of the best entry points into the genre for newcomers.

title: The Narcotic Story
label: Hydra Head
description: Eugene Robinson returns with a record that's sparser than his band's more metallic styles, and, paradoxically, much heavier.

title: Ma Fleur
label: Ninja Tune
description: J. Swinscoe's downtempo outfit-- which escaped the trappings of its peers by feeling more like expansive, carefully constructed suites than collections of songs-- returns after a five-year drought.

title: Attack Decay Sustain Release
label: Interscope
description: Following Klaxons and Justice, the third of this year's big indie-dance crossovers issues its debut album. SMD's debut maintains an unerring devotion to always-hooky pastiche in the name of a good time and to pop's unbreakable and road-tested formalism when it comes to things like song length and the need for a kick-ass chorus.

title: Commuter Anthems
label: Rune Grammofon
description: Rune Grammofon duo Eivind Opsvik and Aaron Jenning construct their work directly on the faultlines that separate each musical genre-- here, including folk, jazz, and country-- from the next.

title: Omns
label: Kranky
description: Rob Lowe of 90 Day Men here works at the familiar intersection of abstract folk and drone, but uses delays and samples to create heavily layered tracks in real time.

title: Given to the Rising
label: Neurot
description: Ninth album from tremendously influential Bay Area metal band moves away from the more atmospheric direction of recent records; the more direct and hard-hitting approach yields what may be their best album in a decade.

title: Champion Sound: Deluxe Edition
label: Stones Throw
description: Stones Throw reissue and expand this 2003 through-the-mail collaboration between Madlib and the late Jay Dee.

title: It's a Bit Complicated
label: Downtown
description: On their sophomore effort, Art Brut have wisely managed to incrementally expand their sonic palette while singer Eddie Argos evinces a slightly more grown-up perspective-- and yet, the group never strays too far from its original M.O.

title: Future Clouds & Radar
label: Star Apple Kingdom
description: Former Cotton Mather frontman, having recovered from a serious spinal injury, returns with a lengthy double album of Beatles-inspired guitar pop

title: Learning to Cope With Cowardice
label: On U Sound
description: After the Pop Group disbanded, frontman Mark Stewart joined forces with dub producer Adrian Sherwood and their first collaboration, recent reissued, is still a profoundly disorienting act of oblique cultural cold war criticism.

title: Si, Para Usted: The Funky Beats of Revolutionary Cuba, Volume One
label: Waxing Deep
description: Funky and psychedelic Cuban tracks from the 1970s and 80s, rarely if ever heard off the island, are lovingly assembled by the Waxing Deep label.

title: The Sun
label: Temporary Residence
description: Six years after their elegant high-water mark, Happiness, Kieran Hebden (Four Tet) and Adem Ilhan (Adem) reunite with fellow Fridge man Sam Jeffers on a new record of moody acoustic-electronic instrumentals.

title: The Fragile Army
label: TVT
description: Pre-release buzz for the Spree's third LP centered as much on the band's shift from robes to black combat garb as on their new songs, and here the group channel its positive collective energy into a more focused political solidarity.

title: Please, Please, Please
label: Kompakt
description: On his third mix for Kompakt, Thomas again takes his time getting to the point, offering atmosphere and ambient drift on an intimate, home-listening mix that features tracks from Pantha Du Prince and Ricardo Villalobos, as well as an Ada remix of a Smiths cover and a Thomas/Geiger mix of a Fleetwood Mac cover.

title: Kraut Slut
label: Static Discos
description: Seekers Who Are Lovers' Ángel Sánchez Borges returns under the name he uses for instrumental journeys into beat-driven minimalism on this, his first release for the Tijuana-based label Static Discos.

title: Gutterfly
label: Quannum
description: Portland-based Quannum associates change their pitch up with an album steeped in the flared-out funk of blaxploitation soundtracks, even while the lyrical focus remains socially conscious.

title: This Bliss
label: Dial
description: Pantha du Prince sidesteps the naturalist preoccupations of much recent German techno with this fusion of the human and the mechanic.

title: Icky Thump
label: Warner Bros.
description: After the straightforward radio-rock trappings of the Raconteurs, the back-to-basics Icky Thump packs an unexpected freshness, resulting in the best White Stripes album in years.

title: Immaculate Machine's Fables
label: Mint
description: With energy and vitality to spare, Kathryn Calder-- niece of Carl Newman and sometimes New Pornographer-- here turns pop songs into proverbs.

title: Tomorrow No One Will Be Safe
label: PACrec
description: Taken from a 2004 American jaunt, this live album combines the talents of a Boston-based sound artist and a Norwegian guitar-and-electronics duo.

title: Granddance
label: Dangerbird
description: This Australian indie band makes a stateside splash with its second album of big, dramatic, and complex rock.

title: Good Girl Gone Bad
label: Def Jam
description: Def Jam star and Jay-Z protégé's new album has a lot more to like about it than just its summer mega-hit "Umbrella".

title: Maths + English
label: XL
description: The former grime wunderkind's third record features his most Americanized production yet and a Yank-luring guest turn from Houston rappers UGK; shame it's not for sale in U.S. stores.

title: Family Trees Or: Cope We Must
label: Dim Mak
description: Singer/songwriter Sean Tillmann (Har Mar Superstar) returns on a palatable and benign indie pop project that essentially sounds like dorm-room pick-up band skiffle.

title: City of Echoes
label: Hydra Head
description: The excellent and consistently developing guitar duo of Laurent Schroeder-Lebec and Trevor de Brauw are here hamstrung by an unraveling rhythm section.

title: Sketchi
label: Temporary Residence
description: On this limited-release Temporary Residence record, the shapeshifting Rjyan Kidwell tackles hollowed-out studio-reggae and the results are menacingly dark.

title: Speicher 3
label: Kompakt Extra
description: The latest collection of recent Speicher singles-- digitally mixed by Kompakt's Michael Mayer and Jörg Burger-- features tracks by German techno heavy-hitters such as Superpitcher, Jürgen Paape, and Mayer himself.

title: Wild Mountain Nation
label: Lidkercow Ltd
description: On their third album, Portland-based Blitzen Trapper unleash a cock-eyed stylistic blitzkrieg that comes closer to catching the carefree fuck-off sprawl of Pavement's Wowee Zowee than any record in recent memory. Spanning midwestern country-rock, mild-mannered indie pop, jagged art-rock, and West Coast swoon, Wild Mountain Nation swears allegiance to multiple touchstones of indie rock without limiting itself to just one.

title: Buncha Beans
label: Drag City
description: After a five-year absence, the Louisville group returns with a Drag City-released album of hee-haw party-rock.

title: Soul Sides, Volume 2: The Covers
label: Zealous
description: Oliver Wang's encyclopedic and historically minded blog Soul Sides issues its second album, a covers record that features Al Green vs. the Beatles, as well as tracks by Marcia Griffiths, Spanky Wilson, and O.V. Wright.

title: Electric Dress
label: No Fun
description: Noise mavens come together in Japan to make a racket with analog machines; what could have been claustrophobic or suffocating is instead a balanced improvisation, akin to a thoughtful free jazz session.

title: Kitsuné Maison 4
label: Kitsuné
description: The latest compilation from Paris-based label Kitsuné is another solid collection of previously 12"-only releases that stretch across the indie-dance axis, including tracks performed or remixed by Feist, Thieves Like Us, Crystal Castles, Dragonette, Boys Noize, and Darkel.

title: Daydream Nation: Deluxe Edition
label: Enigma
description: A deluxe, remastered version of the indie rock classic, this original 1988 album was the first full articulation that the underground music of the Reagan era-- hardcore punk, high-art avant garde, quirky college rock, DIY, weirdo regional scenes-- was converging into a new, exciting Alternative Nation.

title: The Dark One
label: Darla
description: The first Alsace Lorraine record since 2001 features Argentinian vocalist Isol, and the same winsome literary pretension and odd humor of the band's debut.

title: Ongiara
label: Nettwerk
description: Canadian acoustic trio's third album gets arrangements from Owen Pallett and help from several other instrumentalists, but its pared down, slowed down tunes make this quite a wash-out.

title: Can't Wait Another Day
label: Merge
description: The veteran indie pop band releases this Merge album just after the recent death of its drummer, San Fadyl.

title: Weirdo Rippers
label: Fat Cat
description: Over the course of five EPs issued on five different labels-- the highlights of which are compiled here-- this Los Angeles duo's mastered a low-tech immensity that allows its songs to seem much bigger than their constituent parts.

label: Vice
description: The French duo-- who have received hilariously horrified reactions from some in the dance music community-- take French dance and blows it out by embracing 21st-century stadium-rock production, filtering heavy rock through disco until it sounds more Judas Priest circa 1983 than Stardust circa 1998.

title: We Can Create
label: Mute
description: Full-length debut from Northamptonshire's James Chapman continues with the beat-driven, psyche-tinged bedroom electronica exhibited on earlier singles.

title: James & the Quiet
label: Ecstatic Peace
description: James Toth's supposed final record under the Wooden Wand mantle is a stripped-down and song-based companion to 2005's Harem of the Sundrum & the Witness Figg.

title: Soft Punk
label: Troubleman Unlimited
description: Harsh noise figurehead builds new tracks by sampling punk rock recordings-- crowd cheers, drum rolls, drumstick counts-- and inserting them on top and inside of his own.

title: Version
label: Columbia
description: The hip-hop/nu-soul producer who played a large role in recent albums by Lily Allen and Amy Winehouse enlists some famous friends for a covers album that includes takes on songs by Radiohead, the Smiths, and Coldplay, among others.

title: Era Vulgaris
label: Interscope
description: Josh Homme and co. follow their first post-Nick Oliveri album-- the quality Lullabies to Paralyze-- with a more diverse record, one that tries its best to be everything all at once, often within one track.

title: Imperious Delirium
label: Wildflower
description: The venerable, apparently indestructible Australian punk band has never really gone away, but it returns again all the same to show that it's not really going anywhere, either.

title: Ice Station
label: Flameshovel
description: The Chicago band's first effort since 2004, essentially a collaboration between Craig Klein and Telefon Tel Aviv's Joshua Eustis, is a taut, widescreen narrative of a journey from Siberia to China.

title: Split Lips, Winning Hips, a Shiner
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: Eight months after issuing their self-titled debut, the Asthmatic Kitty band has streamlined their songs, honed in on the best parts of their jumbled structures, and elaborated those sections with engaging instrumentation, dynamic vocals, and smart lyrics.

title: Arms Down
label: Absolutely Kosher
description: Matt LeMay and co. again touch upon 90s-vintage indie rock influences on their second Absolutely Kosher release. Beirut's Zach Condon, the Wrens' Charles Bissell, and occasional Broken Social Scene keyboardist Chris Brown guest.

title: The Singles
label: Epic
description: Marking the band's 30-year anniversary, last year's 19xCD The Singles box set has now been squished onto one reasonably-priced, 20-track long-playing disc.

title: Cold Summer
label: Def Jam
description: The new record from Young Jeezy's group mostly does away with the sweeping production and the success-above-all exhortations of Let's Get It: Thug Motivation 101 and The Inspiration.

title: Bad Blood in the City: The Piety Street Sessions
label: Hyena
description: Jazz/funk pioneer James Blood Ulmer continues his exploration of the blues, with an emphasis on the state of New Orleans and guitar/production help from Vernon Reid.

title: Lightning Dust
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Black Mountaineers Amber Webber and Joshua Wells seek better living through histrionics, not chemistry; fortunately, this self-titled Jagjaguwar debut is just as potent a blast from the past as their full-time band.

title: Hope for Men
label: Sub Pop
description: The second album from this recent Sub Pop signing is sourced in the early-80s sludge of Flipper and Black Flag and the tightly wound treble-spray of late-80s/early-90s noise-rock bands like the Jesus Lizard.

title: Excellent Italian Greyhound
label: Touch and Go
description: After seven years-- an eternity in punk rock-- Steve Albini, Todd Trainer, and Bob Weston return, digging in their heels, relishing their in-jokes, and doing what they do best.

title: Keeper of Youth
label: SideCho
description: Former Anniversary frontman Josh Berwanger makes a state-of-the-indie-career album that leans toward backward-glancing classic rock freighted with punk dissent.

title: Kajak
label: Morr
description: Iceland native Benedikt Hermannsonn's 14-piece band returns with a second album mixing whispy, ruminative strums with brass, strings, and fiercely emotive rhythms.

title: The Art of the Slap
label: Stereolaffs
description: For almost a decade, WFMU radio host/comedy writer Tom Scharpling and Superchunk drummer Jon Wurster have built on the uncomfortable shock-jock dynamic in an escalatingly absurd and elaborate fashion; here, they collect their best work.

title: Funf
label: Domino
description: Clinic compile odds and ends from the steady flow of three-song singles that have accompanied each of their albums, covering the period from their breakout Internal Wrangler through last year's Visitations.

title: With Lasers
label: Domino
description: Brazilian indie trio follow last year's Diplo-issued Melô do Tabaco EP by consummating their love of baile funk with their Domino Records full-length debut.

title: Five Roses
label: Secret City
description: Panda Bear's everywhere-praised Person Pitch might be trippier, or the Crayon Fields' Animal Bells more charming, but this debut from Think About Life's Graham Van Pelt is as upfront as either about its debt to 2007's oft-name-checked Brian Wilson.

title: Bayani
label: Rawkus
description: Seattleite MC Geologic drops regional references ranging from Xavier McDaniel to front-line accounts of the World Trade Organization demonstrations over producer Sabzi's glossy update of late-70s r&b.

title: Shortwave Music
description: Created in the early 1980s and first released on vinyl in 1997, this reissue collects pieces created with altered loops of Muzak combined with the crunchy surface texture of shortwave broadcasts.

title: Double Up
label: Jive
description: After the pious Chocolate Factory (2003) and Happy People/U Saved Me (2004)-- as well as five years with multiple counts of child pornography hanging over his head-- R. Kelly continues to embrace his flightier fancies.

title: Asa Breed
label: Ghostly
description: Techno star's latest album further explores pop accessibility, bringing a new sense of songform to his shapeshifting production work and drawing comparisons to LCD Soundsystem, Beck, and Caribou.

title: What the Hell Do I Know? EP
label: Ace Fu
description: New from Ace Fu, this small-town Pennsylvania band has a banjo player as a frontman and makes its stock trade in Dust Bowl balladry.

title: Poly.sci.187
label: Anticon
description: Loquacious Anticon rapper Sole abandons his voice altogether on the latest release in the Mansbestfriend series, replacing it with politically-charged archival audio and re-emerging as a DJ Shadow for the Huffington Post set.

title: D-I-Y: Do It Yourself
label: Soul Jazz
description: Soul Jazz offers a single-disc look at the late 1970s UK D.I.Y. movement-- at the time, a revolutionary political gesture. Included are tracks by Scritti Politti, Swell Maps, and Kleenex, among others.

title: Fort Nightly
label: Say Hey
description: This NYC six-piece writes great songs that merge rhythmic intensity with grandiose melodrama in a seamless and inventive package.

title: Memory Almost Full
label: Hear Music
description: The living legend follows 2005's mostly acoustic Chaos and Creation in the Backyard-- a retreat to homespun simplicity-- with a Starbucks-issued record that turns out to be a lot more idiosyncratic than its coffee-chain marketing plan suggests.

title: Harmonium
label: Lovitt
description: Harmonium

title: Let in the Light
label: Quarterstick
description: On her latest Quarterstick release, this singer/songwriter's production skews twilight, the arrangements tend to be solo, and her lyrics bend towards the poetic and the metaphorical.

title: Everyday I Said a Prayer for Kathy and Made a One Inch Square
label: Empyrean
description: Wheat's fourth album attempts to reconcile the divide between their sleek Hope & Adams and its more refined major-label followup by giving musical weight to Levesque's songs while avoiding obvious pop structures.

title: Live From Austin, TX
label: New West
description: New West's extensive Live From Austin, TX series offers a three-year-old Guided By Voices concert that attempts to finally translate the group's on-stage power into a seminal disc.

title: Z
label: Ecstatic Peace
description: Z

title: The Heart Is the Place
label: Better Looking
description: Oxfordshire band's third proper full-length sounds like the work of a band rehearsing for Keane-level background-rock stardom.

title: Liar and the Thief
label: self-released
description: Athens-based Amanda Kapousouz-- who also performs Celtic-tinged acoustic folk under her own name-- builds each of her songs around the violin, which she loops and manipulates into a versatile range of sounds that coalesce into dark melodies and exotic rhythms.

title: Något Dåligt Nytt Har Hänt EP
label: Hybris
description: Swedish pop group follows its 2006 full-length debut, Jag Vet Hur Man Väntar, with an EP that expands on its predecessor's sound, coming across polished without sounding slick, busy without sounding overloaded, and cerebral but warm.

title: The Sun and the Moon
label: Island
description: The Bravery's self-titled debut flourished in the new-wave niche carved out by the Killers, but on follow-up The Sun and The Moon, the band appears at a loss for a next move, jilted by a dance rock scene that's grown less and less forgiving with every soulless, four-on-the-floor wannabe anthem.

title: Tromatic Reflexxions
label: Domino
description: Tromatic Reflexxions

title: Reflector
label: Dischord
description: This Dischord trio-- which features former El Guapo and Supersystem member Justin Moyer-- offers a muted debut that could be the cleanest-sounding record that the legendary D.C. label has ever released.

title: It Had Wings
label: Migration Media
description: Benjamin Trueblood and friends create naturalistic sound art by running birdsong, minimal percussion, humming voice, flute, and recorder through pedals and laptops.

title: Dear Companion
label: Drag City
description: Espers singer offers another solo collection of traditional ballads, unlikely covers, and well-crafted originals.

title: Silverfish Trivia EP
label: Prom Is Coming
description: The latest self-released Robert Pollard record is an EP that occasionally finds the former GBV leader pushing himself out of his comfort zone.

title: Unbreakable (A Retrospective)
label: Rhino
description: This best-of collection democratically gathers tracks from every facet of the band's career along with two newly recorded songs, and it acts as sort of a last laugh for a group unfairly maligned throughout much of the 1990s.

title: Of Honey and Country
label: Go Midnight
description: Seattle singer-songwriter Amy Blaschke joins forces with multi-instrumentalist and arranger Nick DeWitt from Pretty Girls Make Graves for an album of gnarled folk dirges.

title: Blasts of Holy Birth
label: La Société Expéditionnaire
description: For his second full-length, guitar connoisseur Lou Rogai invites members of Man Man and Rachel's for an evocative set of pieces that sing loudest when the vocals desist.

title: Poste e Telegrafi
label: Important
description: Poste e Telegrafi

title: The Warmth of the Sun
label: Capitol
description: The Warmth of the Sun

title: So Real: Songs From Jeff Buckley
label: Sony
description: Playing more like a label-mandated promotional release for an up-and-coming artist than a thorough retrospective of one of rock's contemporary greats, this best of showcases the arc of Buckley's career in a chronologically scattered and not-particularly-enlightening way.

title: A Tribute to Joni Mitchell
label: Nonesuch
description: The original Lady of the Canyon is buried under a mudslide of slavish imitation and ill-conceived arrangements.

title: Ode to Ochrasy
label: Mute
description: This album marks the point where these Swedish garage-rockers trade in their leathers for Nehru jackets, and tidy up the student-squat squalor of 2004's Hurricane Bar with some incense and expensive-looking import rugs.

title: Afrikan Majik
label: Antenna Farm
description: A bit heady, suggestive of hallucinogenic chemicals, all over the stylistic map, and too long in several spots, this adventurous album has a bit of something for everyone.

title: No Shouts, No Calls
label: Too Pure
description: UK band fuses Krautrock-esque sonics with a flair for continental pop, creating a record of passionately orchestrated songs.

title: Plague Park
label: Sub Pop
description: Wolf Parade's Dan Boeckner teams with his fiancée, poet Alexei Perry, on this textural, minimal Sub Pop release.

title: 1986 EP
label: Record Makers
description: Conceptually heavy French Touch producer follows his outstanding Teddy Boy EP with a far less rewarding effort.

title: GAame
label: Gigantic
description: Brooklyn band employs its own secret language, and in the process its grunts, howls, and cries become part of the rhythm of GAame-- an album where rhythm is privileged above all.

title: Operator Dead, Post Abandoned
label: No Quarter
description: Led by avant-garde violinist C. Spencer Yeh, this No Quarter band's lo-fi droneology recalls the collaborative work of Tony Conrad and Faust.

title: The Great Unwanted
label: Ruffa Lane
description: The Great Unwanted

title: Voxtrot
label: Beggars
description: The Texas band behind the fantastic Raised by Wolves and Mothers, Sisters, Daughters & Wives attempts to transfer its mastery over the quick-hit efficacy of the EP to the album format.

title: Flight of the Bass Delegate
label: City Slang
description: Rather than coming across as dabblers, this Chicago band's genre-hopping seems the work of a group that's well at ease with each of its stylistic switches.

title: ...Mixing
label: Sonar Kollektiv
description: Instead of burrowing deeper into the as yet still under-explored mystical aesthetic of tracks like "Rej" and "Fiori", this mix covers a wide variety of historical and stylistic ground.

title: Mapmaker
label: Jagjaguwar
description: On its latest album, this post-hardcore band does everything it can to diversify its sound without sacrificing the winning formula the group's established.

title: Dandelion Gum
label: Graveface
description: Graveface band veers toward a mutant electronic version of sunny folk-pop that somehow also sounds claustrophobic, sickly, and a little bit damaged.

title: DJ Kicks
label: !K7
description: This London band's lovable hybrid of dance and pop craft a DJ Kicks that's a mulched-up whirlwind of pretty much everything they hold they hold near and dear.

title: Through the Belly of the Sea
label: Orange
description: The Gainesville indie pop band attempts the rarest of ironic indie hybrids: a concept album based on the Choose Your Own Adventure book series. To seek more information on this curio, click above.

title: A Raining Sun of Light and Love For You and You and You
label: Tee Pee
description: On its first official studio release the neo-kosmische Brooklyn band draws inspiration from turn-of-the-70s progressive psychedelia.

title: Retina Riddim
label: Social Registry
description: This began only as a film project and, like Panda Bear's Person Pitch, is a synthetic collage masquerading as an organic outburst.

title: Tio Bitar
label: Kemado
description: After extensive touring, reissuing older material, and recasting their breakthrough album, 2004's Ta Det Lugnt, Gustav Ejstes and company finally release their follow-up, on which they explore the mellower side of psychedelia.

title: Betty Davis / They Say I'm Different
label: Just Sunshine
description: Betty Davis / They Say I'm Different

title: The Dead Will Walk, Dear
label: Bloodshake
description: Band from Richmond, Va. juxtaposes delicate indie folk with tales of extreme violence and mayhem, updating the murder ballad for the era of the slasher film.

title: All That to the Wall
label: Flameshovel
description: By moving away from the sound of their rambunctious stage show and refining their vocals, the Narrator manage their most cohesive and listenable collection of songs to date.

title: Pterodactyl
label: Brah
description: Brooklyn noise-rock band isn't so noisy, really, as a melodic sweetness and nerdy fragility hover within its chiming guitars and cymbal crashes.

title: Do You Trust Your Friends?
label: Arts & Crafts
description: For some reason, Stars decide to take a three-year-old album and commission their own tribute to it.

title: Boxer
label: Beggars Banquet
description: Matt Berninger and co. follow their 2005 grower Alligator-- an excellent album that we initially underrated-- with another patient record full of clever turns of phrase and dramatic intensity, here even more restrained and controlled.

title: Trueno Oscuro
label: Load
description: This Carlos Giffoni-led experimental group's noise/rock amalgam leans farther toward the rock side than any previous Monotract release, as nearly every song here has a big, bold beat supplied by mix-dominating drummer Roger Rimada.

title: Everything Last Winter
label: Atlantic
description: London quintet goes from winsome guitar-pop group to unwieldy big-room behemoths on its major-label debut.

title: Strjon
label: Rune Grammofon
description: On his third full-length album for Rune Grammofon, Supersilent's virtuoso trumpeter explores the genesis of his own life, drawing from a wealth of home-taped sounds from his youth.

title: Cendre
label: Touch
description: The second collaboration between Ryuichi Sakamoto and Christian Fennesz is vastly different from their 2005 EP Sala Saint Cecilia. Like Harold Budd and Brian Eno's Ambient 2/Plateaux of Mirror and The Pearl, Cendre consists of one person playing delicate pieces on an acoustic piano while another fills the ample spaces with electronic treatments.

title: Miss Diamond to You
label: Permanent Vacation
description: Sheffield singer collaborates with Mu's Maurice Fulton for a record stuffed with hooks, accentuated by a never-intrusive mix of rock drums, funky bass, and synth patches used both sparingly and to perfect accompanying effect.

title: Ingleside Terrace
label: Dischord
description: With the addition of third member and songwriter Ben Gilligan, this D.C. Dischord band takes a long step forward in its short evolution. Fugazi's Brendan Canty-- older brother to one of the group's members-- handles production.

title: Burning Birthdays EP
label: self-released
description: Self-released EP from a rising NYC band artfully crafting more 00s indie record-collector rock.

title: Cult Cargo: Grand Bahama Goombay
label: Numero Group
description: Numero Group expand its Cult Cargo series-- an outpost of its Eccentric Soul work that focuses on non-U.S. sounds-- with a look at Bahamian music that lightly Caribbean-ized American soul and funk.

title: Rumpelzirkus
label: Stattmusik
description: Minimal house's first great defector since Matthew Herbert, this Stattmusik artist's debut LP carries an air of the carnivalesque, or at least the tongue-in-cheek, that verges on the outright bizarre.

title: Release the Stars
label: Geffen
description: Continuing in the tradition of 2003/04's double-shot of Want One and Want Two, Release the Stars finds this singer-songwriter flitting between opposite poles-- lovestruck and glib, opulent and gimmicky, overblown and undercooked-- with rumpled uncertainty.

title: Whistleblower
label: Huume
description: The Finnish electronic whiz best-known as Luomo revists his dubby ambient guise.

title: Prezens
label: ECM
description: The guitarist returns to the ECM label with an album of cyber-jazz improv.

title: Säkert!
label: Razzia
description: Hello Saferide aka Annika Norlin returns with a new moniker and a Swedish-language indie pop record.

title: Time Out Presents: The Other Side Los Angeles
label: Deaf Dumb and Blind
description: Paired with a Peanut Butter Wolf-hosted travel DVD, this "reflection of Madlib's L.A." oddly features a handful of artists from places like Detroit and Jamaica.

title: Da Drought 3
label: Young Money Entertainment
description: Love him or hate him, the divisive NOLA rapper's latest mixtape-- a sprawling 29-track, 100-plus minute behemoth-- ups the ante of last year's DJ Drama-produced Dedication 2 in every way possible.

title: Remixes Compiled
label: Hefty
description: Collection includes distinctive reworkings of Nine Inch Nails, Slicker, Apparat, and Bebel Gilberto.

title: No One Will Know Where You've Been
label: Kill Buffalo
description: Indie-country album showcases the Roadside Graves' affection for the American landscape-- both physical and musical-- and hearkens back to the days when long-distance drivers were at the mercy of whichever classic rock or country station carried the strongest signal.

title: Private Cinema
label: Hometapes
description: Danish quintet's first U.S. release is an evocative mix of prog, post-punk, and folk.

title: Fight for Anarchy EP
label: Jagjaguwar
description: This vinyl-only, six-track EP follows the Vancouver band's excellent Southern rock-tinged, self-titled Jagjaguwar debut.

title: Mirrored
label: Warp
description: This foursome's first full-length is a mix of over-the-top whimsy, extreme rhythms, vise-tight musicianship, and a 21st century man-machine interface between live and laptop. And although it may not mark the introduction of the world's first bionic rock group, Battles have done more to extend the idea of a flesh-and-blood band enhanced by computer technology than anyone since the late, lamented Disco Inferno.

title: Seymore Saves the World
label: Royalty, Etc.
description: Side-project of Superdanger's Scott Hefte includes former Tapes 'n Tapes bassist Shawn Neary and focuses on piano-based tunes filled with teenage angst.

title: Golden Pollen
label: Anti-
description: Prefuse 73's Guillermo Scott Herren sings and plays a variety of traditional Latin American stringed instruments, percussion, vibes, and synths.

title: There's No Home
label: Gnomonsong
description: Singer/songwriter integrates influences from outside folk and cultivates a strong sense of mystery on her second album for Devendra Banhart and Andy Cabic's Gnomonsong label.

title: Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten
label: Sony
description: The soundtrack to Julien Temple's well-received Joe Strummer documentary serves as a portrait of the legendary Clash singer's life and mind.

title: Sky Blue Sky
label: Nonesuch
description: Despite the experimental pedigree of their new lineup, Wilco's sixth album finds them receding into the comfort zone. The result is an album that exposes the dad-rock gene the band has always carried but attempted to disguise-- the stylistic equivalent of a wardrobe change into sweatpants and a tank top.

title: Yes Yes to You
label: Absolutely Kosher
description: Led by powerhouse vocalist Kari Holloway, this Absolutely Kosher band finds lyrical inspiration in the early 1960s and musical roots in the power pop of the 1970s.

title: We Walked in Song
label: Badman
description: Veteran college rock band's latest is, even by its standards, especially spare in presentation, drawing on a tradition that includes Appalachian folk and gospel hymns to breezy bossa nova and the third Velvet Underground album.

title: The Mary Onettes
label: Labrador
description: Guitars-and-keyboards band from Sweden recall the synth-pop 1980s and other dreamy, indie-romantic touchstones.

title: Human the Death Dance
label: Epitaph
description: After the fire-breathing 2005 album A Healthy Distrust, the MC's first for Epitaph, the old Sage Francis-- the quirky, quipping storyteller-- triumphantly returns. Guests include Buck 65, Sixtoo, Alias, and cLOUDEAD's Odd Nosdam.

title: Spiderman of the Rings
label: Carpark
description: Tapping directly into the great lineage of batshit bubblegum pop, Baltimore art kid Dan Deacon's Spiderman of the Rings is one of this year's happiest, catchiest, and weirdest records, repeatedly hitting pleasure centers with track after track of gleeful, electronics-infused hyperpop and candy-coated sound experiments. Plus, you can mosh to it.

title: Kiss the Crystal Flake
label: Camera
description: California power pop band returns from indefinite hiatus to record its first album since 2001's excellent The Green Hills of Earth.

title: Above the Trees
label: Hometapes
description: On his third album, this singer/songwriter-- who, like Will Oldham, often undersings to remarkable effect-- finally features more prominently in his austere songs.

title: Dirty South Dance
label: Obey
description: The accomplished DJ-- who's turned the art of turntablism back toward its original party-rocking focus-- here blends contemporary hip-hop and blog house into a mixtape that recalls the Perfect Beats-era sound.

title: Betti-Cola / Come Out Come Out
label: Mint
description: As heard on these expanded reissues, the Vancouver band that once included Neko Case on drums gives cuddlecore a good name.

title: God Save the Clientele
label: Merge
description: After two albums, various EPs, and the godlike singles collection Suburban Light, this London band inches away from articulating a rich and complex world informed by magical realism, memory, and the ache of nostalgia toward a new, brighter light, broadened in both sound and outlook.

title: VI
label: Drag City
description: Sixth album from proggy indie metal mainstays loses some synths but adheres closely to their established sound, now oddly in step with the times.

title: LP1
label: Virgin
description: Four young women from France draw inspiration from the spirit of early punk.

title: Alone in the Dark Wood
label: ATP
description: On her fifth Fursaxa full-length, Tara Burke again uses atmospherics to weave songs and melodies to create environments.

title: ...And the Family Telephone
label: Suicide Squeeze
description: The band's third effort, and its first for Suicide Squeeze, is an engaging folk-pop pastiche of surrealism and religious symbolism.

title: New Moon
label: Kill Rock Stars
description: This set of unreleased material from the late singer/songwriter collects two CDs' worth of material recorded around the same time as Elliott Smith and Either/Or, and makes for a worthy and welcome addition to a stunningly consistent catalog.

title: Modern Love and Death
label: Hail Social
description: Philadelphia-based quartet trade the post-post-punk herky-jerky of their self-titled 2005 Polyvinyl debut and move toward synth-pop.

title: Supastarr EP
label: Mad Decent
description: Diplo's Mad Decent offers an EP from its second signee, a 22-year-old producer who has found fame in the 410 area code making Baltimore club music.

title: Monstrance
label: Ape
description: The XTC leader finally fully liberates his love for Pharaoh Sanders and Albert Ayler on this 2xCD album, which also finds him reuniting with former bandmate and Shriekback co-founder Barry Andrews.

title: Everybody
label: Thrill Jockey
description: On their first album in four years, the eccentric Chicago post-rock/pop band adds a new warmth to their sound while putting more focus on melody, resulting in perhaps their most immediate record.

title: Volta
label: Atlantic
description: Far from the accessible pop record it's been touted as, the iconoclastic singer's latest outing rarely revisits the celebratory spirit of its first single, despite welcome guest spots from Timbaland, Antony, Lightning Bolt drummer Brian Chippendale, and Konono No. 1, among others.

title: Solace in Sore Hands
label: Fat Cat
description: Second album from Malmö, Sweden's finest Americana band retains its earthen imagery while experimenting with more aggressive sounds.

title: Star Destroyer
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Brooklyn-based Jagjaguwar band's ambitious debut sounds like hipster prog that ignores nearly everything prog's about (dramatic climaxes, technical proficiency, rich instrumentation).

title: Imagine Our Love
label: Matador
description: Becky Stark and the rest of her Matador band finally follow their reputation-making Cavalry of Light EP with their debut album.

title: Icons, Abstract Thee EP
label: Polyvinyl
description: Rather than coming across like a set of castoffs from this year's outstanding Hissing Fauna, Are You the Destroyer?, this tour EP instead reads like the condensed version of its parent album's themes and sound.

title: Mosaic
label: Matador
description: Mosaic

title: Let's Just Be
label: Lonely Astronaut
description: The singer-songwriter follows 2004's Our Shadows Will Remain-- a lucid meditation on living in a time of war-- and 2006's Nuclear Daydream with a much less-focused effort.

title: Little Pop Rock
label: Chemikal Underground
description: Jesus and Mary Chain's Jim and William Reid back up their younger sibling, Linda, on this album of metronomic pop and unhurried charms.

title: Ola Podrida
label: Plug Research
description: Film composer David Wingo-- best known for his work with director David Gordon Green-- helmed this cohesive, confident album full of folky, quiet guitars and thoughtful lyrics that coalesce into complete songs.

title: Quique: Redux Edition
label: Too Pure
description: One of the key 1990s "Lost Generation" UK post-rock bands gets a 2xCD reissue of its masterful debut album.

title: Songs of Leonard Cohen / Songs From a Room / Songs of Love and Hate
label: Columbia
description: Legacy reissues the first three albums from the legendary singer-songwriter, adding a few bonus cuts in the process.

title: Lynn Teeter Flower
label: Saddle Creek
description: Azure Ray vet and "Grey's Anatomy" sweepstakes winner offers another album of morose mid-tempo pop. Conor Oberst guests on a track.

title: Blood Is Clean
label: Kranky
description: On this solo project, Honey Owens (Jackie-O Motherfucker, Nudge) shapes her solitary environment with spare, dreamy traces of voice, guitar, and free-spirit drones.

title: Lazarus Beach
label: Skybucket
description: Like labelmates and fellow Birmingham natives 13ghosts, this group of childhood friends favors a slightly ramshackle approach that incorporates disparate styles-- power pop, 70s singer/songwriter, prog, indie guitar rock, and even some smooth southern soul-- into a compelling clutter.

title: Baby 81
label: RCA
description: Another album of re-heated rock'n'roll cool from the Bay Area trio.

title: Tears of the Valedictorian
label: Absolutely Kosher
description: More namechecked than heard, Carey Mercer, Spencer Krug, and the rest of this B.C. band follow a series of small-scale studies with one of their best full-lengths to date.

title: The Trick
label: Vice
description: Brooklyn proto-punk band continues to improve and strike a better balance between moody micro-epics and full-on rock'n'roll.

title: Glitter Glamour Atrocity
label: Fuck Off & Di
description: Moments of Hawkwind-like freak out and deliberately paced ambience sit alongside one another but rarely mix on this NYC band's consistently engaging debut album.

title: Vision Swim
label: Troubleman Unlimited
description: The spirits of repetition and improvisation color the latest from this guitar, pedal, and analog machine-loving symphonic band.

title: The First Original Silence
label: Smalltown Superjazz
description: Thurston Moore, Jim O'Rourke, Mats Gustafsson, Terrie Ex of the Ex and others avoid the common pitfalls of improv-rock by emphasizing the "rock" rather than the "improv."

title: The Singles, Volume Two: 1960-1963
label: Hip-O Select
description: Second volume of the Godfather of Soul's A- and B-sides features one of his best backing bands and an incredibly diverse array of sounds and song styles.

title: Revenge!
label: Yep Roc
description: Live album finds the alt-country singer/songwriter poking fun at showbiz tropes with generally dire results.

title: The Shaky Hands
label: Holocene
description: Portland quintet's gleefully pensive debut upholds the down-home indie aesthetic-- playful melodies and unadorned production-- of bands like the Unicorns.

title: All This Could Kill You
label: Sounds Familyre
description: Danielson's Daniel Smith handles production duties and Sufjan Stevens guests on this husband-and-wife team's debut LP, which is rooted in the profound minutiae of life with children.

title: Death Proof
label: Warner Bros.
description: The latest Quentin Tarantino soundtrack skids across decades, countries, and cultures, taking in Italian B-movie soundtracks, American pop-soul, and British glam.

title: Beyond
label: Fat Possum
description: After numerous, soul-crushing comeback albums-- see, for example, this year's Stooges LP-- this reunited trio had little business releasing a record as eerily faithful to their own past as this one, but here it is, in all its low-key glory.

title: Ten Readings of A Warning
label: Dangerbird
description: The overshadowed former guitarist of Grandaddy releases his first solo effort on Dangerbird with contributions from a handful of indie VIPs.

title: Brand New Towns
label: Bella Union
description: Friend of Norah Jones escapes guilt by association by crafting downbeat pop gems that further solidify Denton, Texas' place as that big state's indie epicenter.

title: Ghosts of Marumbey
artist: Mike Tamburo and the Universal Orchestra of Pituitary Knowledge
label: Music Fellowship
description: Guitarist Tamburo collected more than 200 hours of material from a dozen contributors-- including Keenan Lawler and Fathmount-- to craft a record that echoes with the sounds of John Fahey, La Monte Young, and Robbie Basho.

title: Open Your Box
label: Astralwerks
description: This remix album-- featuring Basement Jaxx, Pet Shop Boys, Danny Tenaglia, and Felix Da Housecat, among others-- is in debt to 90s deep house as much as the disco (not disco) that Ono herself helped to create.

title: The Reminder
label: Interscope
description: Leslie Feist follows her half-covers/half-originals album Let It Die with a record that's equally diverse yet more full-blooded, all sung in a voice that could make even Dick Cheney weep.

title: The Book of Bad Breaks
label: Anticon
description: Anticon group follows its excellent More Deep Cuts by still messing with sound, but this time the experimentation is decidedly more noise-oriented and distortion-heavy.

title: Nine for Victor
label: Soundatone
description: The unpredictable improv group here trims its 70-minute set from the 2005 Victoriaville Festival into a nine-song, 45-minute album that features short chunks of music cut off before they can climb or crest.

title: In Your Time
label: Kemado
description: The band formerly known as Tarantula A.D. translates a knowledge of its strengths and weaknesses into a surprisingly refined album.

title: Poor Aim: Love Songs
label: Slender Means Society
description: K reissues the first collaboration between Khaela Maricich and Jona Bechtolt (YACHT), a record originally released in 2004, and here buffered by remixes from Lucky Dragons, Strategy, and Alan Fortarte of White Rainbow, among others.

title: The Collection
label: Epic
description: Legacy gathers reissued, expanded versions of seven albums from one of the greatest acts in pop music history, a group that created a vital fusion of rock and r&b packaged with an in-yer-face integrationist aesthetic.

title: Enjoy Eternal Bliss
label: Burnt Toast Vinyl
description: On its four-track, roughly hour-long debut album, this English band adheres closely to the tension/release kind of post-rock.

title: Cup
label: Monitor
description: Collection of B-sides, singles, and compilation tracks from a London band that combines metal sludge, post-rock guitar squall, and punk energy.

title: Walkabout
label: Endless Flight
description: Peerless Glaswegian duo follow their eclectic How to Kill the DJ and Psyche Out mixes with a record of uncompromising and unadulterated synthetic electricity.

title: Pullhair Rubeye
label: Paw Tracks
description: Husband-wife duo-- he's from Animal Collective, she was in Múm-- record an album, then release it with all the songs running backward. Seriously.

title: Woke on a Whaleheart
label: Drag City
description: Smog man's first release under his birth name is also his least experimental: Anchored by rich string arrangements courtesy of Royal Trux's Neil Michael Hagerty (who also co-produced), the album is a relatively straightforward collage of country, folk, and classic Austin indie.

title: The Voyage of Icarus
label: Locust
description: Locust compiles the highlights from a long-forgotten Milwaukee group first assembled back at the dawn of the 1970s, its members drawn together by an attempt to common passions for progressive British folk-rock, Middle Earth lore, and Christianity.

title: Eyes Set Against the Sun
label: Warp
description: DJ-turned-ambient enthusiast releases fourth full-length for Warp, inspired by classical themes and the processes of nature.

title: 20 Ways to Float Through Walls
label: Crammed Discs
description: Belgian label Crammed Discs assembles a hugely eclectic sampler of music from all over the globe, including contributions from Konono No.1 and the Flat Earth Society.

title: I Believe in You, Your Magic Is Real
label: Marriage
description: One half of the Blow seems to take a cue from Max Tundra and remember that home computer music and poppy fun need not be mutually exclusive entities, producing an album that strives for, and fleetingly reaches, the lovable heights of Tundra's Mastered by Guy at the Exchange.

title: Dumb Luck
label: Sub Pop
description: No Ben Gibbard, but Conor Oberst, Jenny Lewis, Grizzly Bear, and Lali Puna all make appearances on Jimmy Tamborello's follow-up to 2001's Life Is Full of Possibilities.

title: At the End of Paths Taken
label: Zoe
description: A loose concept album about family from the Timmins clan finds them taking risks with sound and subject matter.

title: Kingdom of Fear
label: Fierce Panda
description: Numerical shouting, background ululations, cowbell-- yup, it's a dance-punk record.

title: Nux Vomica
label: Rough Trade
description: Pop-noir band led by Finn Andrews, son of XTC's Barry Andrews, sounds more like the Bad Seeds or the Gun Club than his father's group.

title: SC100
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Indiana's excellent Secretly Canadian belatedly celebrates its first 100 releases-- and its first 10 years-- with a compilation that features 18 of its artists covering each other's songs. Feature appearances by Songs:Ohia, Jens Lekman, Danielson, Damien Jurado, and the late Nikki Sudden.

title: Favourite Worst Nightmare
label: Domino
description: Sheffield band follows its record-breaking debut with another assured album that seems to glimpse the possibility of greatness even when it fails to attain it.

title: Astronomy for Dogs
label: EMI
description: Three former members of the still underappreciated Beta Band recovene and revisit familiar psychedelic experiments, displaying impressive knowledge of pop's history but adding little to it themselves.

title: Collected Remixes
label: Anticon
description: Anticon producer reworks tracks by John Vanderslice, 13 & God, Lali Puna, and others.

title: We Made This Ourselves
label: Ba Da Bing!
description: Chamber folk debut from London-born/New York-based singer is sometimes reminiscent of British legend Sandy Denny.

title: The Complete Peel Sessions
label: Castle
description: John Peel faves, these quintessential 80s UK indie workhorses compile a 6xCD box set that includes covers of Orange Juice and Altered Images among 12 complete radio sessions, a John Peel birthday bash, and three full-length concerts.

title: Joanna Newsom & the Ys Street Band EP
label: Drag City
description: The inimitable singer-songwriter quickly follows the formally ambitious Ys with a three-song EP consisting of one new song and two old ones, recorded live in the studio with four members of her acoustic touring band.

title: Listening to Donald Judd
label: Sub Rosa
description: A sound-artist travels to Marfa, Texas, where sculptor Donald Judd made minimalism big.

title: Cape Fear
label: Arena Rock
description: Toronto band evokes early 90s lo-fi and classic indie signifiers, adding synths, keyboards, and other electronic gadgets to the classic guitar, bass, and drums setup.

title: Ten New Messages
label: V2
description: Eschewing most of the punkish energy and instantly gratifying hooks that marked their early singles and debut album, Capture/Release, this UK band here tackles more "worthy" pursuits.

title: Twelve
label: Columbia
description: The recent Hall of Fame inductee records an album of covers that range from the obvious (songs by Jefferson Airplane, Neil Young, and Paul Simon) to the really obvious (Jimi Hendrix, the Rolling Stones, the Doors).

title: Return of the Mac
label: Koch
description: More than a decade ago, a teenage Prodigy-- half of the existential Queensbridge duo Mobb Deep-- was one of the fiercest and murkiest rappers in New York. But after six years of car-crash career decisions, Prodigy's made the comeback no one saw coming.

title: Make Another World
label: Sanctuary
description: Long-running and long-suffering Scottish band patches together another album of decent R.E.M.-like cuts and near-misses.

title: Costello Music
label: Interscope
description: Another post-Libertines UK guitar-rock band, these guys are chart toppers at home but remain most familiar to U.S. listeners from iPod ads.

title: Animal Bells
label: Chapter
description: Melbourne quartet grasps at the Beach Boys' ocean-flecked harmonies, the Zombies' dreamy eloquence, and the Association's gentle melodies.

title: The Adventures of Ghosthorse and Stillborn
label: Touch and Go
description: The sisters Casady brighten the sylvan hip-hop warble of their divisive earlier efforts with help from Devendra Banhart.

title: Live at Fingerprints
label: Vagrant
description: Keeping their winning streak alive, the Hold Steady plug into something special for a fleeting unplugged EP.

title: The Days and Nights of Everything Anywhere
label: Polyvinyl
description: Fifth album from mathy Portland band mines the last two decades of indie rock for inspiration.

title: What's the Time, Mr. Wolf?
label: Motown
description: The London trio's U.S. debut is a long-playing introduction to frontwoman Shingai Shoniwa, aka the next big female rock star.

title: Eccentric Soul: Twinight's Lunar Rotation
label: Numero Group
description: Numero Group's estimable Eccentric Soul series continues with a 2xCD, 40-track collection of non-hits from Chicago's late-1960s/early 70s Twinight label, best known for the work of Syl Johnson.

title: Part Two: The Endless Not
label: Mute
description: A quarter-century after hanging up its synthesizers, the curtain goes up on this pioneering industrial/noise group's second act.

title: Myths of the Near Future
label: Geffen
description: London three-piece are the most recent manifestation of the British rock press' perennial compulsion to rediscover the very stuff it stereotypically ignores, dance music. But don't hold that against them.

title: Life in Cartoon Motion
label: Island
description: This chart-topping UK pop debut seems the smug product of Broadway auditions, karaoke sessions, and Robbie Williams.

title: Pink in the Sink
label: Hush
description: Touring member of Kind of Like Spitting mixes low-key indie folk with loops, beats, and samples, covering Beyoncé's "Crazy in Love" along the way.

title: Mice Parade
label: Fat Cat
description: Adam Pierce's seventh album as Mice Parade is also his most traditionally song-oriented. Stereolab's Laetitia Sadier and Múm's Kristin Anna Valtysdottir provide guest vocals.

title: Total Joke Era / lp
label: Important
description: Important issues the first two albums from a duo consisting of Thurston Moore and Andrew MacGregor, who records as Gown: One is a CD of experimental guitar work, and the other its limited-run vinyl counterpoint.

title: Year Zero
label: Interscope
description: Trent Reznor shuns radio-friendly alt-rock and settles into his role as a cult star, releasing a complex record about a dystopian near-future.

title: Saltbreakers
label: Nonesuch
description: Singer-songwriter borrows signifiers from her more famous, rewarding pals at the expense of carving an identity of her own.

title: The Chaos in Order
label: Yardley Pop
description: Debut from a band featuring frontwoman/songwriter Shana Levy, formerly of Irving and occasionally of Rilo Kiley and dios (malos), tackles emotional and romantic dilemmas.

title: Spells
label: Vagrant
description: Former alt-country group tries to balance its college rock charm with its AAA sound and ambitions.

title: FabricLive 33
label: Fabric
description: Philly collective make for a perhaps odd entry into one of London club Fabric's DJ series, and they respond with a mix of familiar touchstones ("Bostich", "The Breaks", "The Dominatrix Sleeps Tonight") and cuts from their friends and contemporaries (CSS, Hot Chip, Bonde do Role, Simian Mobile Disco).

title: Fluorescent Grey EP
label: Kranky
description: This stubbornly visionary band follows its stunning sophomore album Cryptograms with a set of four intensely focused songs recorded during their predecessor's mixing.

title: Ghost
label: Morr
description: Ben Cooper of Electric President issues a solo record for Morr in which he indulges his more trad songwriting ambitions.

title: Widows
label: Marriage
description: Eclectic project connects dots between musique concrète, crudely recorded folk, and beat-driven electronics.

title: Ash Wednesday
label: XL
description: The LA-based singer/songwriter issues an assured debut, rife with allusions to John Wesley Harding and the early work of Loudon Wainwright III.

title: Sensuous
label: Everloving
description: First album in five years from the Japanese experimental pop eccentric isn't quite the departure that 2002's Point was from Fantasma, but it feels like a natural next step.

title: Coat of Many Colors / My Tennessee Mountain Home / Jolene
label: Buddha
description: RCA reissues three of the most well-loved albums of the country legend's career-- adding bonus tracks and doing remastering work on each.

title: The Antique Barking Swirls of Dawn
label: Honeymoon Music
description: Philly indie pop group moves from E6 wannabees to exploring and tapping psych at its purest roots, adding shades of stoner rock and shoegaze.

title: Sing, Memory
label: Figment
description: Former Black Box Recorder chanteuse makes her solo bow with help from ex-Auteurs member James Banbury.

title: King for a Day
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Thrill Jockey showman continues to display both an impressive wit and a ceaseless dedication to his musical craft.

title: Palo Santo: Expanded Edition
label: Matador
description: Newly signed to Matador, this former Misra band reissues its underrated 2006 album as a 2xCD set, re-recording five of the original songs and adding bonus material.

title: Fourteen Autumns and Fifteen Winters
label: Fat Cat
description: Fourteen Autumns and Fifteen Winters

title: Tower [ft. Verde]
label: Last Visible Dog
description: Tower [ft. Verde]

title: Most Wanted
label: Greensleeves
description: Greensleeves offers an excellent point of entry to this legendary-- and unlikely-- 1980s dancehall star.

title: Why Bother?
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Thrill Jockey's gothic electro-pop band continues to get progressively stranger and more insular, here slightly backing off on the group's punk charge and goth affectations.

label: 4AD
description: Former NYC no wavers draft famed alterna-rock producer Alan Moulder (U2, Depeche Mode, Smashing Pumpkins) for their high-gloss, ornamental new record.

title: Dead Horse EP
label: Domino
description: The remix EP to last year's striking album So This Is Goodbye lends further weight to the notion that Junior Boys are one of those rare bands that are in continuous conversation with the musical world around them.

title: We All Belong
label: Park the Van
description: Philadelphia pop collaborative's fourth album is a Beatles tribute filled to the brim with aching guitars and a few gritty blues renditions.

title: Art Brut Fe De Yoot
label: Big Dada
description: The man behind 2004's demented Bush Meat returns with another surreal take on Britrap, getting assistance here from Swiss electronic improv duo Stade.

title: Wars
label: Polyvinyl
description: Oakland post-hardcore band works with intricate structures, jazzy stop-starts, and dramatic crescendos on its latest record.

title: Super Roots 9
label: Commmons
description: Eight years after the last Super Roots EP, Eye, Yoshimi, ATR, and Yojiro deliver SR9, diving headfirst into an ocean of drums, voices, and cycles upon cycles of subtle rhythmic variation.

title: Live at Amoeba Music EP
label: Interscope
description: The famed West Coast record store presents live, in-store versions of four songs from 2006's best rock record, Return to Cookie Mountain.

title: These Friends of Mine
label: Nettwerk
description: Seattle-based singer-songwriter releases a tepid fourth album of personal narratives about love, death, and displacement; Sufjan Stevens co-produces and pitches in on backing vocals and assorted instruments.

title: Check In
label: Setanta
description: Dublin boy/girl quintet alternates chunky guitar pop with shrill electro-punk while lyrics focus on playful sexuality.

title: Sparrow Trout Heart Sprout
label: Achord
description: Prolific Akron Familyman Seth Olinsky recorded this 3xCD set in late 2004 and early 2005 as a limited CD-R, eventually consenting to have it remixed and given a proper release.

title: The Undisputed Truth
label: Rhymesayers
description: Minneapolis MC continues to explore his inner landscape with tales of personal disillusionment, righteous political anger, and emotional calamity.

title: Cassadaga
label: Saddle Creek
description: Featuring the slickest production of any Bright Eyes album to date, Cassadaga is a logical continuation of Conor Oberst's country-rock evolution.

title: Born Identity
label: Sound Ink
description: Debut solo album includes production from fellow Antipop Consortium alum Earl Blaize and a brief cameo from TV on the Radio.

title: Time Taunts Me
label: Trekky Records
description: Ari Picker (the Never)'s first release as Lost in the Trees is orchestral and ambitious, as he builds his songs from contrasting sections and maintains consistent sonic themes across the breadth of the record.

title: Heimische Gefilde
label: Traum Schallplatten
description: The German techno producer behind 2005's outstanding Kreucht & Fleucht mix pits nature against itself on this collection of 12" singles.

title: Night of the Furies
label: Merge
description: The third and best album from the North Carolina husband/wife duo is an unexpected turn toward new romantic synthpop, a fitting pallette for a collection of darkly romantic songs about love, betrayal, and loss.

title: Grinderman
label: Anti-
description: With the Bad Seeds on the sidelines, Nick Cave grows a mustache, straps on a guitar, and gets down with his bad self, featuring a handful of Seeds helping out and a few helpings of Stooges-styled flophouse fun.

title: Wire Waltz
label: Hacktone
description: Lap steel savant Megan Hickey mines slo-mo alt-country that emphasizes sleepy atmosphere over tunes.

title: Red Gone Wild
label: Def Jam
description: The id-driven hip-hop vet's long-delayed follow up to 2001's disappointing Malpractice finds him continuing to work with old friends like Method Man, Erick Sermon, and Biz Markie.

title: Think Before You Speak
label: Brille
description: South London band's spiky guitars, attack/release choruses, and hiccupping vocals recall the debuts from the Futureheads and Maxïmo Park.

title: Because of the Times
label: RCA
description: Former Southern Strokes aim to become the Southern U2 on this, their third album.

title: Remixed & Covered
label: 5RC
description: This 2xCD set is, as the title suggests, split between remixes and covers of Jaime Stewart's theatrical electro-pop group's music, and it features contributions from Devendra Banhart, Sunset Rubdown, Marissa Nadler, Why?, and Kid606.

title: Human Like a House
label: Dulc-I-Tone
description: Bay Area duo debuts with an album of pretty, stripped-down folk rendered with a simplicity that proves problematic.

title: Young Galaxy
label: Arts & Crafts
description: Orderly dream-pop from this Arts & Crafts band, which features former Stars touring guitarist Stephen Ramsay.

title: Aman Iman: Water Is Life
label: World Village
description: Formed in a Libyan refugee camp in the early 1980s, the guitar-centered Tinariwen collective can be heard as hypnotic and politically charged desert blues.

title: Our Earthly Pleasures
label: Warp
description: The last members of the Paul Epworth-produced post-wave triumverate to emerge are also the last to follow up their debut, and like Bloc Party and the Futureheads before them the group strives for grander statements with its sophomore album.

title: Score
label: !K7
description: A collection of music penned for a series of independent films from 1997 to 2007, this is more in line with 2003's big band-inspired Goodbye Swingtime than the producer's better-known works.

title: Buck the World
label: G-Unit
description: Nashville rapper's sophomore album showcases his gruff, damaged baritone and his darker, violent side.

title: Soft Skeletons
label: Frenchkiss
description: Frenchkiss band offers an album about death and dying, a morose focus at odds with the band's raucous garage-punk.

title: Peace and Love
label: Kong Tiki
description: Side project from Norway's 80s-obsessed New Violators turns the clock back an additional decade, capturing the crunchy guitar riffs and piano boogie of classic rock with astonishing accuracy.

title: The Abbatoir Blues Tour
label: Mute
description: This powerful band's 2xCD/2xDVD live set showcases two sides of the group-- one hard and harsh, the other more sentimental.

title: And Their Refinement of the Decline
label: Kranky
description: On their first album in almost six years, Kranky's drone stars explore the difference between music and sound, turning in an effort that's much more minimal and muted than 2001's outstanding The Tired Sounds of...

title: Wrong-Faced Cat Feed Collapse
label: Anticon
description: Anticon label expands beyond hip-hop with an album of experimental rock tunes from bedroom producer and Why? cohort SJ Esau.

title: Howling Bells
label: Liberation
description: Australian band makes countrified rock touched by noir-- think Lush, Mazzy Star, Grant Lee Buffalo-- on their import-only debut.

title: Soldier-Talk
label: Radar
description: Drag City reissues this long-lost 1979 album, which features contributions from Lora Logic and Pere Ubu.

title: The Meaning of 8
label: Earthology
description: Minnesota-based art-rockers' sixth album in seven years is another affecting study in excess, but lacks some of the eccentricities they built their rep on.

title: Shock Value
label: Interscope
description: Timbaland's equivalent of the Neptunes' Clones LP features guest spots from Justin Timberlake (on three tracks), Dr. Dre, 50 Cent, Nelly Furtado, and Missy Elliott. And then there's the rock bands: Fall Out Boy, The Hives, and She Wants Revenge. And then there's Elton John. And Magoo.  : /

title: Crepuscule With the Dead Science EP
label: Slender Means Society
description: This five-song EP-- released about a million years ago-- features a pair of songs recorded during sessions for the Seattle band's 2005 Frost Giant album, plus an additional three tracks.

title: Rich Boy
label: Interscope
description: Rising r&b producer Polow Da Don works here with this Southern MC, and is once again by far the best thing about his tracks.

title: Rvng Prsnts MX5
label: Rvng Intl.
description: Optimo's JD Twitch lent a hand with the recording for the latest mix CD from New York's Rvng boutique, which opens with a track by Robert Fripp & Brian Eno and features everyone from the Cars to Chic to Crass.

title: The Time Has Come: 1967-73
label: Sanctuary
description: Bert Jansch's legendary British group-- which explored the intersections between folk, blues, and jazz-- is the subject of this mammoth 4xCD retrospective.

title: Last of the Breed
artist: Willie Nelson, Merle Haggard, and Ray Price
label: Lost Highway
description: These three country legends-- no strangers to collaboration with one another-- offer a 2xCD set that includes two Nelson/Haggard tracks plus 20 covers of tracks penned by Lefty Frizzell, Floyd Tillman, and Kris Kristofferson, among others.

title: Western Xterminator
label: Drag City
description: Second album from Jennifer Herrema's post-Royal Trux band finds her gravitating toward populist, hooky, fist-pumping heavy metal.

title: The Far Now
label: Merge
description: Former Clean leader's latest Merge release is solid and understated, with many of its songs exploring a single musical figure or idea with grace and restraint.

title: Vieux Farka Touré
label: Modiba Productions
description: Debut album from the son of the late Ali Farka Touré contains what turned out to be his legendary father's final recordings.

title: Waitin' to Inhale
label: Rap-A-Lot
description: The fourth solo album from this Houston rapper and perennial underdog is both his most beautiful and most disturbing to date.

title: Ed Rec Vol. 2
label: Vice
description: French Touch imprint Ed Banger offers its second label compilation, and it's another hit-and-miss bag that features tracks by the excellent Justice, SebastiAn, and Mr. Flash, among others.

title: Now It's Time
label: Birdman
description: Despite the double billing-- the band name Tarnation graces a CD spine for the first time in more than a decade-- this album feels like a solo record rather than that 90s group's riotous alt-country.

title: Visqueen
label: Ipecac
description: NYC post-hardcore band releases its first album since moving from Relapse to Mike Patton's Ipecac. The change doesn't signal a new direction, however, as the group remains rooted in tightly wound punk-metal.

title: Applause Cheer Boo Hiss EP
label: Dependent
description: YYYs- and blogger-approved Montreal band finally has its muscular 2006 EP issued in the States.

title: Back to Black
label: Interscope
description: Back to Black

title: Traffic and Weather
label: Virgin
description: Adam Schlesinger's group follows its surprise hit "Stacy's Mom" with a record of more of the same-- chugging verses, big choruses, and utter mediocrity.

title: Quixoticism
label: Sonic Boom
description: Former Joggers and Fruit Bats member offers wordily titled, soft-spoken guitar ditties that twist pop trends and the works of his folk forebears.

title: Ekranoplan
artist: The Assemble Head in Sunburst Sound
label: Tee Pee
description: Produced by the Fucking Champs' Tim Green-- who has also worked with Melvins, Six Organs of Admittance, and Comets on Fire-- this Bay Area band's first wide release recalls the thunderous throttle of Blue Cheer and 13th Floor Elevators.

title: Hibernaculum
label: Southern Lord
description: Legendary Seattle drone-metal group follows its excellent 2005 comeback Hex, or Printing in the Infernal Method with a four-track collection of re-recorded songs and a DVD documenting the band's post-Hex European tour.

title: Book of Dogma
label: Soma
description: This proto-IDM group-- whose members went on to form Plaid-- has its rare EPs Virtual, Age of Slack, and Techno Playtime reissued alongside other hard-to-find tracks on this 2xCD release.

title: Ruff Draft
label: Mummy
description: Stones Throw reissues the late producer's transitional 2003 EP-- recorded after the disappointment of having two major-label releases shelved-- adding a handful of bonus tracks and a disc of instrumentals.

title: The Slow Bang
label: Orange Twin
description: Young singer-songwriter shares her fellow Georgians Cat Power and Liz Durrett's penchant for hushed vocals and minimal arrangements.

title: Arriving at Night
label: Hefty
description: Australian electronic composer makes his Hefty debut, a record full of pleasing tones that flow by with frictionless grace.

title: Memory Theatre
label: Important
description: Karl Bauer crafts thick drones made with violin, electronics, and voice, sometimes accompanied by primitive percussion, and here he's compiled three of his hardest-to-find releases-- 2006's "Chemical Theatre" 12-inch and 2005's Oranur and Object Phantom CD-Rs.

title: Brett Anderson
label: Drowned in Sound
description: After a much-hyped but largely uneventful reunion with his former creative partner Bernard Butler, the ex-Suede singer issues his first proper solo album.

title: From Here We Go Sublime
label: Kompakt
description: Combining elements of the best ambient music with the emotive nostalgia and accessibility of Fennesz's Endless Summer and Boards of Canada, From Here We Go Sublime may wind up 2007's most luxuriant electronic record.

title: Or Give Me Death
label: Barsuk
description: West Coast synth rocker David Terry adds more members to his lineup, warming up to pop with a set of traditional anthems and some of the offbeat, punchy electronics from his first two albums.

title: Goliath, I'm On Your Side
label: Broken Sparrow
description: Second album by the Portsmouth, NH indie band mixes slow, melodic alt-country and sublime instrumentals.

title: Present the Paisley Reich
label: Siltbreeze
description: Recent Matador signings issue a second excellent Siltbreeze album of shouty boy-girl punk that recalls the Swell Maps, the Fall, and Huggy Bear.

title: The Upsetter Selection-- A Lee Perry Jukebox
label: Trojan
description: Already the subject of countless anthologies, box sets, primers, and cash-ins, here-- as part of Trojan Records' ongoing series of celebrity curated anniversary compilations-- the infamous Black Ark producer selects his own best work for this 2xCD collection.

title: Armchair Apocrypha
label: Fat Possum
description: Chicago violinist and songwriter follows his breakthrough album, The Mysterious Production of Eggs, by adding more guitars and deeper textures to his production, tricks he's been employing live for the past couple of years.

title: Fulton Lights
label: Catbird
description: Andrew Spencer Goldman's ambitious project attempts to harness the dark despair of urban alienation, but more often replicates the unsettled angst of coffee-shop poetry.

title: Black Pompadour
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Baritone-voiced frontman Jim Elkington and crew return for a third record filled with classic rock grandeur and serious moping.

title: All Things, Forests
label: Misra
description: Brooklyn-based indie poppers keep things interesting by injecting ambiguously lovelorn and twee-leaning songs with rock power.

title: Dangerous Game
label: Norton
description: The former Shangri-La's lead singer records her first album in decades, with help from Greg Cartwright and the rest of Reigning Sound.

title: Person Pitch
label: Paw Tracks
description: On his third solo outing as Panda Bear, Animal Collective's Noah Lennox balances blossoming melodic pop with wildly experimental sound techniques, hitting on a stunningly unique sound that's both overwhelming and inspirational.
